column17: On 11 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR), resulting in three fatalities between 11-13 August. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. Fatalities split across three events. [size=no report]

On 12 August 2020, riots erupted in Boditi and Gununo towns (Wolayta, SNNPR), denouncing the arrest of local officials by federal troops several days before. Rioters burned tires and blocked roads. [size=no report]

On 12 August 2020, Federal troops shot protesters in Gacheno town (Wolayta, SNNPR), injuring 2. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. [size=no report]

On 12 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR), resulting in three fatalities between 11-13 August. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. Fatalities split across three events. [size=no report]

On 12 August 2020, riots erupted in Boditi and Gununo towns (Wolayta, SNNPR), denouncing the arrest of local officials by federal troops several days before. Rioters burned tires and blocked roads. [size=no report]
On 12 August 2020, Federal police officers broke into the house of the director of Maccaa Tuulamaa (charity/political organization) in Burayuu (Oromia), beating the director severely.

On 13 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR), resulting in three fatalities between 11-13 August. Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. Fatalities split across three events. [size=no report]
On 13 August 2020, police responded to clashes by rival youth groups in Degehabur (Dhagaxbuur) in the Somali region, killing 1 person. It is unclear what prompted the violence. [size=no report]

On 14 August 2020, security forces fired on protesters in Sodo city of Woliayta (SNNPR). Protests were triggered by the arrest of several Wolayta regional leaders by federal government troops. According to local medical officials, the total fatalities that occurred in Sodo region between August 9-14 was 21 persons. Fatalities split across events to specific reports of fatalities with that period. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromo Regional Special Forces
column17: On 15 August 2020, Oromia regional special forces shot and killed a young civilian in Bako Tibe woreda, West Shewa.

On 17 August 2020, hundreds of demonstrators gathered in Degehabur (Dhagaxbuur) city of Somali regional state demonstrating the death of a young man who was shot by police forces several days prior. Demonstrations were sparked when the police officer accused of the shooting was released from custody. Clashes between security forces and demonstrators occurred later in the day (no injuries reported). [size= hundreds]

On 17 August 2020, Ethiopian military forces opened fire on protesters in Shashemene town, killing an unspecified number across two days of demonstrations. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus. Unknown fatalities coded as 3 and spread across two days. [size=no report]
On 17 August 2020, protesters demonstrated in Ambo city (West Shewa, Oromia), denouncing the arrest of several Oromo leaders. [size=no report]

On 17 August 2020, Ethiopian security forces opened fire on protesters in Haro Maya (East Harerghe, Oromia), wounding 12 and killing 2. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention. [size=at least 12]

On 18 August 2020, Ethiopian security forces opened fire and assaulted protesters in Ciro (Chiro), killing 2 and wounding 24. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention. [size=at least 24]

On 18 August 2020, for the second day, Ethiopian security forces opened fire on protesters in Haro Maya (East Harerghe, Oromia), killing 1 and wounding 9 others. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention. [size=at least 9]

On 18 August 2020, Oromia regional special forces forcibly dispersed demonstrators who were blocking roads in Bale Robe (Bale, Oromia), following reports that Oromo leaders had contracted coronavirus in detention. No injuries or fatalities reported. [size= no report]

On 18 August 2020, Ethiopian military forces opened fire on protesters in Shashemene town, killing an unspecified number across two days of demonstrations. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted the coronavirus. The demonstration has been ongoing for the second day. Unknown fatalities coded as 3 and spread across two days. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, Ethiopian military forces shot at protesters in Aweday, killing 8 people and injuring 18. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention. [size=at least 26]
On 18 August 2020, security forces have shot and killed a local Imam and his nursing wife at their place of residence in Gedeb Asesa, West Arsi zone.

On 18 August 2020, security forces opened fire on protesters in Dire Dawa city, killing at least 2 people (some sources claimed 4 fatalities, lowest estimate taken). Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, Oromia special forces shot at protesters in Kobo town (Harar), killing 2. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, riots occurred in Asosa, Asebot, Dengego, Dire Teira, Dodola, Gelemso, Ginir (Oromia), Haromaya, Hirna, following news that several high profile Oromo political prisoners had contracted coronavirus while in custody. Rioters blocked roads, burned tires, and destroyed vehicles. Police intervened. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, riots occurred in Asosa (Benshangul-Gumaz), Asebot, Dengego, Dire Teira, Dodola, Gelemso, Ginir, Haromaya, Hirna, following news that several high profile Oromo political prisoners had contracted coronavirus while in custody. Rioters blocked roads, burned tires, and destroyed vehicles. Police intervened. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, riots occurred in Asosa, Asebot (Oromia), Dengego, Dire Teira, Dodola, Gelemso, Ginir, Haromaya, Hirna, following news that several high profile Oromo political prisoners had contracted coronavirus while in custody. Rioters blocked roads, burned tires, and destroyed vehicles. Police intervened. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, riots occurred in Asosa, Asebot, Dengego, Dire Teira, Dodola (Oromia), Gelemso, Ginir, Haromaya, Hirna, following news that several high profile Oromo political prisoners had contracted coronavirus while in custody. Rioters blocked roads, burned tires, and destroyed vehicles. Police were injured. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, riots occurred in Asosa, Asebot, Dengego, Dire Teira, Dodola, Gelemso (Oromia), Ginir, Haromaya, Hirna, following news that several high profile Oromo political prisoners had contracted coronavirus while in custody. Rioters blocked roads, burned tires, and destroyed vehicles. Police intervened. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, riots occurred in Asosa, Asebot, Dengego, Dire Teira, Dodola, Gelemso, Ginir, Haromaya and Hirna (Oromia), following news that several high profile Oromo political prisoners had contracted coronavirus while in custody. Rioters blocked roads, burned tires, and destroyed vehicles. Police intervened. [size=no report]

On 18 August 2020, riots occurred in Asosa, Asebot, Dengego (Oromia), Dire Teira, Dodola, Gelemso, Ginir, Haromaya and Hirna, following news that several high profile Oromo political prisoners had contracted coronavirus while in custody. Rioters blocked roads, burned tires, and destroyed vehicles. Police intervened. [size=no report]

On 19 August 2020, for a third day, Ethiopian security forces opened fire on protesters in Haro Maya, killing 2 and wounding 26 others. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention. [size=at least 26]

On 19 August 2020, security forces opened fired at protesters in Dire Dawa city, killing 1 person. Protesters were denouncing the arrest of many Oromo leaders, amid rumors that many had contracted coronavirus in detention. [size=no report]
On 23 August 2020, Ethiopian security forces shot and killed a 10 year old Muslim child in Bedesa, West Hararghe (Oromia). No further details on the incident.
Around 24 August 2020 (as reported), a Muslim scholar in was shot and injured by security forces in Sheshamene. A second person (a student at the mosque) was also hurt in the incident.

On 24 August 2020, Ethiopian security forces violently dispersed a funeral in Badesa, West Hararghe, killing a Muslim Imam who was presiding over the funeral. A second person was injured in the incident.
On 2 September 2020, a young girl was killed by Ethiopian security forces (Assumed military) with a bullet to the back of her head in Alemaya town (East Hararghe, Oromia).

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Liyu Police
column17: On 3 September 2020, Liyu police killed five civilians in Raaso town (Afder, Somali).

On 9 September 2020, suspected members of the Benishangul Gumez People's liberation movement attacked and kidnapped several civilians in Bulen and Wenbera Woreda (Metekal, Benishangul). 4 people were killed in the attack on Bulen.

On 9 September 2020, suspected members of the Benishangul Gumez People's liberation movement attacked and kidnapped several civilians in Bulen and Wenbera Woreda (Metekal, Benishangul). No fatalities were reported.
On 9 September 2020, Ethiopian Defence forces attacked unidentified militants in Benishangul region, Assossa zone. 2 soldiers were reportedly killed, with 3 injured and taken to a hospital in Assosa.

Around 9 September 2020 (between 6 September - 13 September), at least 30 civilians were shot and killed by unidentified militants in Metekal zone, Benishangul/Gumz woreda. The victims were largely from the Amhara ethnic group, a minority in the region. 16 civilian fatalities were coded in attacks attributed to specific locations within Metakal zone, the remaining 14 are coded in this estimate.
On 10 September 2020, Oromo militias attacked ethnic Somali communities in the village of Golmaayo in the Tulu Guled area (Fafan, Somali), killing one man.

On 11 September 2020, ethnic militias from Konso region clashed with Oromo militias from Ale special woreda. Clashes reportedly took place in Karkerte, Delbena, Gawada (Illalubor, Oromia), Iyana, Goroze and Gergam villages (woreda). 4 fatalities were reported (spread across two known locations).
On 11 September 2020, ethnic militias from Konso region clashed with Oromo militias from Ale special woreda in Arkide and Gelabu woredas, Konso region, resulting in the death of 2 people.

On 11 September 2020, ethnic militias from Konso region clashed with Oromo militias from Ale special woreda in a number of villages in Ale special woreda (Oromia region). 4 fatalities were reported (spread across two known locations).
On 13 September 2020, Afar militiamen attacked ethnic Oromo farmers near Bati (Oromia), killing one man. Several other farmers were wounded in the attack.
On 14 September 2020, Ethiopian military forces shot and killed a farmer in Begi, West Wollegga (Oromia).

On 16 September 2020, clashes erupted between local youth and police in Abala town (Afar) after youth began gathering wood to celebrate a local holiday. Police forces attempting to disband the celebration opened fire during clashes, killing 3 young men and injuring between 6 and 9 others. [size=at least 9]
On 17 September 2020, a young man was killed after being beaten by police in Weliso prison, Southwest Shewa (Ethiopia) while in custody.
On 19 September 2020, residents in Munessa, Arsi zone (Oromia) staged a protest against the Prosperity party. [size=no report]

On 24 September 2020, an unidentified armed men attacked security forces in Negez Kebele, located in Dangur Woreda, Metekal zone (Benishangul/Gumz), taking control of the area shortly after security forces fled. No information on fatalities.

On 24 September 2020, an unidentified armed men attacked civilians in Negez Kebele, located in Dangur Woreda, Metekal zone (Benishangul/Gumz), killing 15 people. Attacks on civilians came following an exchange of gunfire with local security (coded separately). Some additional sources reported as many as 22 civilian fatalities (most conservative estimate taken).
On 6 October 2020, unidentified armed men attacked civilians in Dangur Woreda, Metekal, killing 14 and wounding 8 more. One of the killed was reportedly a Chinese national.

column6: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Shane Splinter Faction)
column17: Around 7 October 2020 (as reported), armed men suspected of being associated with Shane/OLF kidnapped two government representatives in Ginde Beret woreda (West Shewa, Oromia), later killing one.
On 8 October 2020, Ethiopian federal military forces clashed with unidentified armed groups responsible for killing civilians in the Dangur woreda area, Benishangul, killing 14 and arresting 2 more.
On 8 October 2020, military forces opened fire on students conducting a protest in Asasa, West Arsi (Oromia), wounding one person in the foot. [size=no report]

On 10 October 2020, military forces opened fire on unarmed Qeerroo protesters in Bale Robe town (Bale, Oromia), killing one person. Protesters were demanding the release of political prisoners. [size=no report]

On 10 October 2020, unidentified armed men wearing government uniforms opened fire on transport trucks in the town of Ali Doro (North Shewa, Oromia), killing one driver, injuring three others, and damaging up to 10 vehicles.

On 12 October 2020, an unidentified armed men opened fire on civilians in Mandura Woreda, Metekal zone (Benishangul/Gumz), killing 12. Some reports indicate that the victims were ethnic Amhara (a minority in the location), labeling the attack as ethnically motivated, while local authorities denied ethnicity being a driving factor in the attack. The shooting allegedly arose after in response to the theft of a firearm.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On 16 October 2020, police forces in Daro Lebu, West Hararghe, beat several youth after suspecting them of organizing protests following the killing of a popular Oromo musician. One of the youth later died of his injuries.
On 18 October 2020, unidentified armed militants attacked civilians in Gura Farda, Bench zone in SNNPR, killing 31 across two days (fatalities split between 18 October and 21 October).

column6: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Abba Torbee Splinter Faction)
column8: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column9: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromo Regional Special Forces
column17: On 19 October 2020, suspected members of the OLF Shane (Abbaa Torbee faction) shot and killed two police officers in Nekemt town, East Wellega (Oromia). One of the deceased was a member of the Oromia state police and the other, a member of Oromia region's special (LIYU) police force.
On 21 October 2020, unidentified armed militants attacked civilians in Gura Farda, Bench zone in SNNPR, killing 31 across two days (fatalities split between 18 October and 21 October).

column8: OLF: Oromo Liberation Front (Abba Torbee Splinter Faction)
column17: On 23 October 2020, security forces engaged in an armed gunbattle with ""Abba Torbe"" militants in Nekemte town, East Wellega (Oromia), killing 4.

On 24 October 2020, Qerroo youth held a protest denouncing the police shooting of a taxi driver in Aweday, East Hararghe (Oromia), and the death of 4 young men in Nekemt the previous day. [size= no report]

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Oromia State Police
column17: On 24 October 2020, Oromia state police shot and killed a taxi driver in Awadey, East Hararghe (Oromia), for unknown reasons.

column6: Police Forces of Ethiopia (2018-) Prison Guards
column17: On 24 October 2020, prison guards in Ebuntu, East Wollegga (Oromia), reportedly beat a prisoner to death. The prisoner had been arrested during unrest following the killing of a popular Oromo musician.

column6: DMLEK: Democratic Movement for the Liberation of Eritrean Kunama
column17: DMLEK fighters launched a surprise attack on an enemy garrison between Shambqo and Bimbina, destroying the garrison and putting a water tanker out of action on 4 July.

column6: DMLEK: Democratic Movement for the Liberation of Eritrean Kunama
column17: Democratic Movement for the Liberation of the Eritrean Kunamas destroyed a military truck travelling between Aqurdet and Emberemi [in western Eritrea] on 13 July. Reports indicated that four soldiers were also killed in the attack.

column6: IPEDJ: Islamic Party of Eritrea for Development and Justice
column17: Islamic Party of Eritrea for Development and Justice launched a surprise attack on military forces around Serena, between Mukut and Tselim Resi on 23 July. Reports indiccate five soldiers were killed.

column6: DMLEK: Democratic Movement for the Liberation of Eritrean Kunama
column17: Fighters of the DMLEK [opposition Democratic Movement for the Liberation of the Eritrean Kunamas] are said to have launched an attack against military forces in Western Eritrea (proximate location; no name given).
After a group of Eritreans kidnapped several German tourists in neighboring Ethiopia they brought them back to Eritrea. They were origionally kidnapped at Erta Ale volcano.

Ethiopia reports they have attacked a Eritrean armory at an undisclosed location ""10 miles inside Eritrea"" and destroy three camps housing militia and military. Eritrea dismisses Ethiopias attack as ""hallucinations"".

The Ethiopian Defence Forces have launched an attack on Eritrean forces in Badme, the Badme Primary School was completely burnt down when it came under artillery attacks from Eritrean army at 3 p.m. Sources differ over the number of casualties.
Violent clashes occurred between revelers and about 400 demonstrators who were protesting othe Government of Eritrea as a dictatorship.

Israel has opened military bases in Eritrea to monitor and avert rival Irans hostile activities in the Red Sea. According to the US-based strategy consultancy firm, Israel has deployed its intelligence units, docks and small naval units at the selected bases in Dahlak Island and Massawa port of Eritrea.

Israel has opened military bases in Eritrea to monitor and avert rival Irans hostile activities in the Red Sea. According to the US-based strategy consultancy firm, Israel has deployed its intelligence units, docks and small naval units at the selected bases in Dahlak Island and Massawa port of Eritrea.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Eritrea (1993-)
column17: Movement of forces: Some 200 disaffected Eritrean troops with two tanks on Monday surrounded the Ministry of Information in the capital Asmara. No shots were fired, and there are no reports of violence taking place.

Arrests: The Eritrean government has detained a leader of one of the factions of the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF), [Brig-]Gen Kemal Gelchu, a close friend of the general informed Ethiopian Review today.

30 Protestants arrested in Eritrea, homes invaded, said to total 50 within one month, however the first 20 appear to have occurred in January. No news as to the date or location of these January arrests were available via this or other reliable sources

Arrests: Residents arrested for reading posters calling for street demonstrations to support calls made during the actions taken by military officers on Monday, 21 January, when a group of protesting soldiers raided the Ministry of Information in Asmara.
Eritrean civilians of Christian faith reportedly victums of violence against civilians by Eritrean police forces, having been detained and physically harmed as a result of their religion.

On one night in 2013 after school exams, more than 12,000 students were arrested and forced to travel on foot for over 21 days to the military training centre Sawa. Two students drowned crossing a river, while another two died from snake bites. On arriving at their destination, the group was put in open prison camps without proper shelter. 34 more died, while there were 17 unwanted pregnancies.
Government agents murdered 80 members of the Eritrean Navy on a broad day light in public in Northern red sea region of Bardoli vicinity

Three members of the Eritrean air force defected on Tuesday by flying a military aircraft to Saudi Arabia becoming the latest defectors from the Horn of African nation. The three Eritrean air force members have asked for political asylum in Saudi Arabia
Eritrean border guards shoot dead 10 civilians attempting to cross the border into Ethiopia.
Freedom Friday (Arbi Harnet) had a weekend of on-street activities including graffiti and posters calling for collective action to challenge the root cause of mass migration.
Freedom Friday (Arbi Harnet) had a weekend of on-street activities including graffiti and posters calling for collective action to challenge the root cause of mass migration.

An Eritrean opposition group has reportedly raided a government owned garage facility in the capital Asmara. Eritrean National Salvation Front (ENSF) in a statement said its armed wing has carried out the attack on Wednesday at the garage located in Qohawta neighbourhood in retaliation to the regime's oppression against citizens including deny economic rights of the people. The statement didn't disclose if there were causalities from government side following the attack but it admitted one of its fighters have sustained light wounds.

Tension remains high on Ethiopian and Eritrea border after a series of clashes in mid-March. The situation deteriorated on the second weekend of the month (March 14 or 15) following a surprise attack by Eritrean military around Badme area. Several personnel of an Ethiopian National Defense Forces (ENDF) unit were killed by the ambush, as HornAffairs was able to confirm from firsthand sources.
An unidentified target near Barentu [in western Eritrea] was hit on 20 March by Ethiopian missiles shot from Tigray [Regional State, bordering Eritrea] in Ethiopia. The missile did not cause damage.

The mining complex at Bisha [in western Eritrea] in Eritrea was hit on 20 March by Ethiopian missiles shot from Tigray [Regional State, bordering Eritrea] in Ethiopia. The mine sustained a slight damage.

A military facility located between the villages of Tukhul and Wutuh in the Mai Edaga [both in southern Eritrea] area was hit on 20 March by Ethiopian missiles shot from Tigray [Regional State, bordering Eritrea] in Ethiopia. The military facility was heavily destroyed.

column6: RSADO: Red Sea Afar Democratic Organisation
column17: Gunmen from the Red Sea Afar Democratic Organization (RSADO) attacked a government military garrison in the northern Red Sea region, killing six intelligence agents and wounding a number of others. Various types of military hardware were also captured. The attack was reportedly in retaliation to government oppression against members of the Afar minority in the Alhan area.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Eritrea (1993-)
column17: Members of the security forces shot and killed at least 11 people in the capital, Asmara. The killings took place when several national service conscripts tried to escape while they were being transported in an army truck. In addition to the conscripts, bystanders were also killed. The killings had not been investigated by the end of 2016.

column16: AFP; Meskerem; All Africa; Shabait; Atlantic Council; Eritrea Television
column17: Clashes broke out between Eritrean and Ethiopian forces in the Tsorena front, along the two countries border. Both sides blamed each other for the attack. Eritrea confirmed that 18 Eritrean soldiers had died in the attack. In a retaliatory attack the fllowing day, Eritrea allegedly crossed into Ethiopia at Kudu Haiwa, killing 200 Ethiopian soldiers, injuring 300 and capturing 52. A more conservative estimate by Horn Affairs puts the casualties as 30.
Armed Houthi forces stationed in the island of Hanish and Zagar allegedly fired mortar rockets on the headquarters of the Eritrean naval forces in Assab port, causing serious property damage.
Property destruction: Armed Houthis from Yemen allegedly attacked Assab international airport, in the Southern Red Sea Region of Eritrea. No report of casualties.

In October 2016, a helicopter gunship reportedly hit a boat carrying Eritrean Afar fishermen travelling along the Eritrean coast near Edi and Bara-Assoli, killing one person and injuring seven others.
Security forces arrested a Jehova's witness in January 2009 and imprisoned him at the Me'eter camp in Asmara. He is believed to have died in detention in Asmara on 30 November 2016 from mistreatment.

Defection: Two Eritrean diplomats defected from the regime of Isaias Afeworki after returning from their assignment as charge d'affaires in Eritrea's embassy in Djibouti and as first secretary in Eritrea's permanent mission at the African Union and the United Nations' Economic Commission for Africa. The two had felt threatened by the security forces in their last visit to Asmara and requested political asylum in the US. Date unclear - report dated 27 January.

Security forces arrested and detained 122 Christians for worshiping in unregistered churches in the southern town of Adi Quala throughout May 2017. An evangelical mother arrested in this context died two months later, in early August 2017, while imprisoned at the Metkel Abiet camp, allegedly from torture and mistreatment. A new campaign of house-to-house arrests reportedly targeted Christians throughout Eritrea in May and June, with 177 Christians, along with 20 children, arrested in total. It is estimated that a total of 3,000 Christians are imprisoned in Eritrea in degrading and inhumane conditions.

Movement of forces: Qatar has pulled its troops out of a peacekeeping mission on the border of Djibouti and Eritrea after both countries sided with Saudi Arabia in a row that has left Qatar cut off from the rest of the region diplomatically. Djibouti lodged a complaint with the UN shortly after the pullout, saying that Eritrean troops had taken full control of Dumeira Mountain and Dumeira Island in the absence of Qatari troops, a breach of the UN Security Council resolution.

In July, students in Adi-Halo, Debarwa area, left rocks on the road to protest the lack of accommodation at a new college of agriculture and machinery they were sent to, many involuntarily. Military forces intervened. No apparent clash until October, when the protests escalated.

In October, tensions escalated Adi-Halo, Debarwa area, as students protesting the lack of accommodation in the area since July began throwing stones at the military guards. The Eritrean opposition radio Medrek reports that the military responded by forcibly moving the students to Naro in the far north for military training.

column16: Madote (Eritrea); Hagerawi Dihnet; Red Sea Afars Democratic Organisation
column17: Following the government-imposed forced closure of an Islamic school in Asmara students and residents protest the action. A few of the demonstrators allegedly threw stones and brandished weapons at security forces according to pro-government media, while the government forces fired shots in the air to disperse the protesters. Dozens were arrested several. An activist group claimed that 28 people were killed and over 100 injured during the protest. However, this information was not verified in the following weeks and Information Minister Yemane Gebremeskel dismissed the reports of casualties.

Around 15 November, two weeks after the government arrested the chairman of Al-Dia, a proviate Muslim school in Asmara, students at the school protested peacefully and marched toward government offices. They were met by security forces firing into the air. Dozens were arrested.
The chairman of Al-Dia, a private Muslim school in Asmara, was arrested on 1 November 2017. At the beginning of March 2018, his body was returned to his family.

On 11 June, Ethiopian residents of Badme town on Ethiopia's northern border protested Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed's move to hand over the town to Eritrea. Over ten thousand people were reported to have taken part in the demonstration and most of them were members of the Kunama tribe [a tribe which lives in Ethiopia and Eritrea].

Agreement: on 9 July, Ethiopia and Eritrea declared in a joint statement that they are no longer at war after a series of historic meetings in Asmara to end decades of acrimony and conflict. They also announced that trade, diplomatic and communication linkages would be re-established.
On September 6, in Asmara city (Aneba, Eritrea), Djibouti has agreed to peacefully resolve its dispute with Eritrea over a territory in the Red Sea.
17 September. Berhane Abrehe, a former Finance Minister and author of two books critical of the President, was arrested by government forces in Asmara.
19 December: Eritrean minister of mines was shot and seriously injured by unidentified armed men in his home in Asmara.
In early May 2019, Eritrean Police Forces arrested 141 Christians in Asmara (Asmara, Maekel), during a period in which the government is increasingly attempting to limit religious activities.

On 3 June 2019, Eritrean Police Forces arrested 30 Christians at three separate churches in Asmara (Asmara, Maekel), and the arrestees were told they would only be released if they disavowed their faith.
On 23 June 2019, Eritrean Police Forces arrested 70 Christians in Keren (Keren, Anseba), in an ongoing crackdown against religious minorities.
On 18 August 2019, Eritrean Police Forces arrested 80 Christians in Asmara (Asmara, Maekel) in an ongoing crackdown against religious minorities.

On the 4 February 2020, Eritrean Police Forces shot and killed a man who had been caught as a defector from the Eritrean Military Forces in Mendefera (Mendefera, Debub). The man was arrested but escaped, after which the Eritrean Police Forces enacted the ""shoot-to-kill"" policy and shot him.

On 2 April 2020, the Eritrean government announced a nationwide lockdown to combat the spread of coronavirus. This came after the closure of the Asmara International Airport on 26 March and the closure of land borders.

column9: Afar Ethnic Group (Eritrea); Fishermen (Eritrea); Labour Group (Eritrea)
column17: Around 15 May 2020 (month of), Eritrean police forces arrested dozens of fisherman and camel riders leading caravans carrying food to the Afar people near Assab (Debub Deb.Keih Bahri, Debubawi Keih Bahri). Local activists allege the arrests come within a greater context of lack of medical care, deliberate witholding of food and water supplies, and arrests all targeting the Afar ethnic minority.

Around 30 June 2020 (end of month), Eritrean police forces arrested 30 Christians at a wedding in Asmara (Asmara City, Maekel) in an ongoing trend of arresting Christians who are not part of the Catholic, Evangelical Lutheran, and Orthodox denominations approved by the state.
5,000+ youth and opposition protesters, calling for an end to the regime of President Guelleh, clash with police. One death reported, arrests made. The event lasted two days.

column7: UMD: Union for Democratic Movement Party; UAD: Union for a Democratic Alternative Party; UMD: Union for Democratic Movement Party
column17: The UAD and UMD political parties protest the regime and majority political party. Police violently disperse them. One police officer, one protester killed.
Anti-regime protests occur in suburban Djibouti City. No report of police intervention or violence.
Opposition parties call for a boycott of national elections, claiming the voting system is ""rigged"". Leaders of both groups were briefly detained by authorities.

column7: UAD: Union for a Democratic Alternative Party
column17: Union for a Democratic Alternative Party candidates boycott voting in elections, believing the process is corrupt or rigged against them. The candidates also held rallies encouraging their supporters to do the same.

column7: FRUD: Front of the Restoration of Unity and Democracy
column17: FRUD party boycotts voting, believing the electoral system is rigged against them.

column6: FRUD: Front of the Restoration of Unity and Democracy
column8: Military Forces of Djibouti (1999-) Presidential Security Unit
column17: About ten FRUD-arme rebels attacked the Day presidential residence, wounding 4 presidential guards
On 30 December 2012, Djiboutian security forces fired on peaceful young demonstrators in the city of Obock, killing a 14 year-old and seriously injuring many others

The poet Farah Moussa Bouh, an MRD sympathiser, was arrested on 17 January 2013 at Balbala. He was beaten during the arrest along with his wife, Hawa Omar Abdillahi. Mr Bouh alleges he was subsequently tortured by police while in detention

As demonstrators gathered on Monday afternoon, police charged the crowd using batons and tear gas with people scattering into neighbourhoods of Djibouti city, Farah said, adding that some 300 people had been arrested on Monday. Monitoring groups estimate that 6 people died in the clashes on 25th and 26th.

Movement for Development and Liberty (Model) leaders Sheikhs Abdirahman Bashir and Abdirahman God were arrested for ""disturbing public order"" on Monday for protesting alleged fraud during last Fridays legislative elections.

Students from the University of Djibouti protested before the Supreme Court on Tuesday (February 26th), demanding the release of opposition leaders arrested Monday.

According to this interpretation, police used tear gas on several occasions to disperse demonstrators. One of the areas of highest tension, the spokesman said, is southwest of Balbala. Monitoring groups estimate that 6 people died in the clashes on 25th and 26th.

Maydaneh Abdallah Okieh was the victim of violence during his detention at the police criminal brigade,"" the news agency reported. ""For the last 48 hours, Maydaneh has been subject to inhuman and degrading treatment in extreme and barbaric conditions.""

USN meeting was violently dispersed by police and the office was ransacked.

Djibouti Republican Guard has suddenly opened fire today at the Djibouti International Airport, injuring two people, including a senior officer.
Agreement: Government releases opposition MPs who were arrested in February.

The President and the Spokesman for Mouvement des Jeunes de lopposition were arrested in their homes and beaten by police. They were denied access to a lawyer or doctor and placed in Gabode prison until one was released Dec 14th.
The regime in Djibouti organized protests in support of the head of states fourth term bid

There were protests in Djibouti led by the opposition Union for National Salvation party against a third term bid for the head of state. Police shot one of the protesters and later on arrested around 20 people.

column6: FRUD: Front of the Restoration of Unity and Democracy
column17: Arrests: FRUD militants burnt down three vehicles belonging to a road construction company near the town of Tadjura. 20 people have been arrested in connection tp this attack, including people suspected of being close to the group

Arrests: Young members of the Union for National Salvation (USN) and the Opposition Youth Movement (MJO), as well as two USN leaders, were arbitrarily detained in Gabode prison following a first instance trial after having been arrested on 18 September for having participated in a demonstration. they were released on 11 October

Seven people have been arrested over suspected links to the rebel Front for the Restoration of Unity and Democracy (FRUD). In total, 15 people have been put behind bars for their alleged link to FRUD. they have allegedly been systematically tortured since their arrest

Police violently arrested six minors aged between 13 and 15 years from the Movement for Democratic Renewal (MRD) - a National Salvation Union (USN) party - in the Balbala Sheikh Moussa neighbourhood in Djibouti City, at a peaceful celebration before ransacking the parties premises. The minors were held at Gabode prison in harsh conditions
Police violently arrested a young member of the Youth Opposition Movement (MJO). He was held at Gabode prison in harsh conditions and severely beaten during the course of his arrest.

column9: LDDH: Djiboutian League of Human Rights

Up to 27 people were reportedly killed and 150 injured in clashes between police, troops and armed members of the Yonis Moussa community in Balbala. Numbers provided by the International federation for Human Rights (FIDH) and the opposition are three times higher than authorities. Authorities reported that opponents attacked them armed with knives, machetes and two Kalashnikov guns, while the opposition emphasised they were attending a banned religious gathering when security forces attacked them. 17 people were arrested following the clashes, including members of the opposition coalition Union for National Salvation (USN).

Kadar Abdi Ibrahim, publication co-director of the Aurore newspaper, was arrested by police in connection with the publication of a photograph of a seven-year-old girl who died during the violent dispersal of a religious ceremony by the police and the Djibouti army on 21 December 2015. He was reportedly tortured in detention. He was later condemned to a two-month suspended prison sentence, while the publication of this monthly newspaper was also suspended for two months.
Agents of the Gendarmerie in Ali Sabieh allegedly arrested and beat a civilian without charge.

column8: FRUD: Front of the Restoration of Unity and Democracy

Clashes have recently opposed, in Bakoumba city in the province of Upper Ogooue, rioters and the local branch of the police after they had arrested the youth who had closed the road that connects the city to the rest of Gabon.

Several primary and secondary school teachers protested Wednesday outside the office of Minister of National Education, Seraphim Moundounga. They demanded payment of the premium incentive for the teaching profession (Pife) that they have not benefitted from since 2010.
A Maltese-flagged tanker was attacked Monday afternoon by pirates off Cap Lopez, Port Gentil. Two days after the incident the ship and crew (24 Indians) were found.

Employees of Africa Clean staged a sit-in in front of their headquarters in Libreville. The staff demanded wage increases, increases in total premiums on risk, quality, tooling, cash, detoxification and housing assistance.
The police arrested thirty students who organized a peaceful march to demand scholarships.

At Omar Bongo University students of the Faculty of Law and Economic Sciences broke windows and started fires in protest against high exam failure rates. Police used tear gas and five policemen were injured.
Journalists begin a sit-in and hunger strike outside the Office of the Prime Minister over pay issues.
A riot erupted in Libreville prison as prisoners felt their hunger strike was going unnoticed. Gendarmes arrived as reinforcements and used tear gas. 2 inmates escaped.

Many high school and college students took to the streets in Libreville between Wednesday and Friday in a walk to demand an end to the teachers strike which has disrupted classes from the beginning of the school year in October 2013.

As a result, the Gabonese government has decided to close public schools on October 15th until further notice to maintain public order.

Students demonstrated in the streets of Libreville against reforms introduced by the Ministry of Education. Some demonstrators engaged in acts of vandalism. Police fired tear gas and several arrests were made. Reforms postponed as a result.

Workers from the Public Works workers' syndicate (SYFO/TP) approached the provincial Public Works ministry in Ogooue-Ivindo, protesting the refusal to negotiate over workers' concerns after a 72-hour strike.
Students protested at the National Commerce school in Port-Gentil, calling for payment of scholarships

University students, former members of the National Social Security Fund and teachers hold a hunger strike at St. Marys Cathedral in Libreville. Police evicted strikers at 3am on September 13. No serious injuries reported.

Students from Omar Bongo University rioted outside of the Treasury in Libreville on Oct. 12, 13, and 14, demanding payment of grants. Rioters threw projectiles at police vehicles; police fired tear gas. No injuries reported.

March in streets of Port-Gentil to support for President Ondimba.

Protesters wanted to go into the courthouse in Libreville to file a complaint concerning the alleged falsification of President Bongo Ondimbas birth certificate. Police fired tear gas and bullets. No reported injuries.

At least one student was killed in clashes at an opposition rally, where police fired tear gas to disperse protesters demanding the resignation of the president. At least 20 were arrested in scuffles between police and demonstrators, while shops were looted and cars set on fire.

Ping says the authorities paid the youth to assault his home and that police refused to intervene; it is unclear whether opposition supporters or the police ended the attack, detaining several people.

column7: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column17: Supporters of Gabonese presidential candidate Jean Ping clashed with security forces in Libreville following the declaration that President Bongo had won the presidential elections. Several hundred protesters attempted to storm the offices of the election commission but were repulsed by police using tear gas and stun grenades. The demonstrators elswhere in the city set the parliament buildings on fire, while there were reports of looting, vandalism and arson. Police allegedly also opened fire on protesters at one point, wounding at least 6. Tanks were also reportedly present during the events. At least 1 person was killed during the violence.

Arrests: Security forces have detained as many as 200-300 people outside the capital (where at least 600 were arrested) in relation to the violent protests following the re-election of President Bongo.

column7: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column9: Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard
column17: Clashes continued between protesters demonstrating against the re-election of President Bongo and security forces in te Nkemob district of Libreville.

column6: Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard
column9: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column17: Police and Republican Guard personnel opened fire on the campaign headqaurters of presidential candidate Jean Ping, killing 2 and injuring more than a dozen. One of those injured later died in hospital according to a Red Cross worker. They later arrested dozens of members of the UPC in the building. Jean Ping also claimed they ransacked the building after storming it.

column6: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column9: Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard
column17: 2 protesters were killed in overnight clashes between protesters and security forces in Libreville over the results of the election. Both were killed by gunshot, one by the Republican Guard as they fired tear gas and live rounds to disperse protesters; the other by unidentified assailants in a drive-by shooting.
In Oyem, a policeman was hospitalized after being shot in the head during ongoing unrest over the election. Official sources said the policeman came out if the coma on September 9.

In Port Gentil, some youths barricaded shops to prevent looting while others blocked roads and threw rocks at police, who responded with tear gas, during ongoing protests over the results of the election. At least one youth was reportedly killed by the security forces during the unrest in the Ngadi Ball area of the Beacon district of Port-Gentil.
Continued protests and rioting were reported in Libreville over the weekend.
Dozens of ""angry relatives"" gathered outside the Libreville courthouse for news of their relations after rioting in Libreville following President Bongos re-election.
Rioting was reported in the Plein-Ciel area of Libreville, including violence and looting.

Rioters attacked Hausa and Muslim minority areas of Bitam following the re-election of President Bongo. A large warehouse of a food supplier and a thrift store were both burned down during the rioting, although no casualties were reported. Mosques and business owned by the Hausa/Muslim community in the areas were also targeted by molotov cocktail, stone and club wielding youths.

column7: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column17: Opposition supporters gather outside Jean Pings headquarters in Libreville and hold a vigil for those killed in the anti-government protests.

column7: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column17: A thousand supporters of opposition leader Jean Ping dressed in white marched Saturday in Libreville, in tribute to the victims of post-election violence that rocked Gabon after the presidential election of 27 August.
As many as a thousand people marched in Libreville to support the re-election of President Bongo. The demonstrators were allegedly mostly young and were protected by the police.

Suspected arsonists started a fire in the Potos market of Franceville destroying a significant part of it. Youths from the area looted goods from the area during the disorder created by the flames. It is believed the fire was related to the regions stance during recent post-election unrest.

Strikes: Unions decreed an unlimited general strike. Believing to be ""despised"" by the government, unions in the education sector have decided to return to unlimited general strike two weeks after the launch of a first warning strike.

column7: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column17: Many people are boycotting AFCON matches on the call of Jean Ping, the former opposition presidential candidate (UFC), to protest against the government over the outcome of recent elections.
High school students protested in Libreville, Port Gentil and Kambarene (centre) to demand better studying conditions.
High school students protested in Libreville, Port Gentil and Kambarene (centre) to demand better studying conditions.

High school students protested in Libreville, Port Gentil and Kambarene (centre) to demand better studying conditions. Police intervened in the Port Gentil march and dispersed it using tear gas. Several students were reported injured.
High school students protested in Oyem to demand better studying conditions.
Students of the Agathe Obendze Technical High School in Franceville protested and marched in solidarity with students in other areas protesting against the government.
Students in Moanda (Haut-Ogooue) protested and marched to demand payment of their scholarships and an end to the ongoing teachers strike.
Nearly 200 trade unionists were dispersed by the police from a May Day demonstration.

column7: LVDPG: Voice of the Gabonese People
column17: Members of LVDPG attempted to hold a demonstration against the Gabonese government. The demonstration was prevented by the police, who arrested 20 activists.
Thousands of people in Port Gentil participated in a general strike and a protest against the high cost of living and the increasing unemployment.
People demonstrated to support president Ali Bongo after a report on air on Thursday shed light on his biased re-election.
Several hundred supporters of Jean Ping attempted to welcome their leader at the airport, but were dispersed by the police, who fired teargas at the crowd. 2 people were injured.

A riot control vehicle was parked outside the police headquarters in Port Gentil, in anticipation of a show of strength from Jean Ping's supporters. It was doused in gasoline and set alight by unidentified assailants.
Supporters of opposition leader, Jean Ping, protested in Libreville to commemorate the anniversary of the disputed election. The police dispersed them.
Supporters of opposition leader, Jean Ping, protested in Port-Gentil to commemorate the anniversary of the disputed election. The police dispersed them.
36 Jean Ping supporters were arrested at a demonstration in Libreville.
Students at the Omar Bongo University are preventing other students from enrolling, in order to protest the increase in enrollment fees.
Students and police officers clashed in the outskirts of Libreville. Students protesting the increase in university fees broke windows and fought the police.
A Nigerien man attacked 2 Danish tourists in a market in Libreville. He claims to have attacked them in retaliation for US attacks on Muslims.
Taxi drivers in Libreville barricaded the main highways to protest the increase in fuel prices.
Clashes broke out between the police and taxi drivers protesting the increase in fuel prices in Bikele.
On 27 March, several teachers barricaded the entrance to the Ministry of Education and observed a sit-in over their financial situation. Four were arrested.
On 3 April, trainee teachers held a sit-in on the Ministry of Education premises. They were violently dispersed by security forces and several arrested. No reported injuries.

column7: SNEC: National Union of Teachers and Researchers
column17: On 13 April, the National Union of Teaching Researchers (SNEC) at the Omar Bongo University picketed after suspending activity on 9 March over lack of payment.
Around 25 April, in Sotega district of Libreville, a police officer beat a woman over the head during an altercation between the members of the two families as part of a land dispute.

Non-violent activity: on 30 April, the constitutional court dissolved the national parliament and called for the government to step down after its failure to organise legislative elections. On 1 May, the government resigned and on 4 May, a new interim government was installed.
On 1 May (Labour Day), agents of Radio Gabon and Gabon Televisions chant slogans hostile to the Minister of Communication, Alain Claude Bilie-By-Nze in Libreville.
On 12 May, protesters held demonstrations to demand the release of Blaise Wada in Bakoumba.
On 14 May, students protested in the 5th arrondissement of Libreville outside BICIG Oloumi against the non-payment of their scholarships since 2017. 28 were arrested by police forces.
On 22 May, teachers at the Ecole Nationale Superieure in the 1st arrondissement of Libreville went on strike to demand 3 years of unpaid leave. They blocked access to the school.
On 23 May, students from the Owendo Institute of Technology staged a sit-in outside the Gabonese National Scholarship Agency over the 9-month suspension of their scholarships.

column6: Military Forces of Gabon (2009-) Republican Guard
column17: On 28 May, shots were fired by an unknown group wounding a Republican Guard agent while he was on a surveillance mission in the 1st district of Libreville.

Property destruction: on 3 June, the HQ of former presidential candidate, Jean Ping, was vandalised in Bas-de-Gue-Gue in the first arrondissement of Libreville reportedly by supporters of President Ali Bongo.

column6: Police Forces of Gabon (2009-) Prison Guards
column17: On 5 June, prisoners in the central prison of Franceville in Haut-Ogooue, launched an assault on prison guards in protest at the non-delivery of food rations for several days.
Property destruction: on 16 June, the home of Fefe Onanga, opposition and political activist was set on fire in an arson attack in the Grand village district of Port-Gentil. No injuries reported.

column7: SYNAFOPRA: National Union of the Agents of the Ministry of Civil Service and Administrative Reform; NAR: New Republican Alliance
column17: On 11 July, several organizations of the Gabonese civil society and political personalities including SYNAFOPRA and NAR in Awendje in the 4th arrondissement of Libreville, protested against the austerity measures taken by the Council of Ministers on June 21, which they say are aimed more at ""making Gabonese workers more precarious"".
On 23 July, angry people from Gamba in the province of Ogooue-Maritime barricaded roads and streets to denounce the prevailing unemployment affecting the small oil town.

column7: SYNAPS: National Union of Health Personnel; SYNAGREF: National Union of Clerks; SENA: National Education Union; SYNAMONPS: National Union of Non-Permanent Health Workers; SYNACNAMGS: National Union of the National Health Insurance and Social Security Fund; Teachers (Gabon); Health Workers (Gabon)
column17: On 27 July, the National Union of Clerks (Synagref); the National Education Union (Sena), the National Union of Non-permanent Health Workers (Synamonps); the National Union of the National Health Insurance and Social Security Fund (Synacnamgs) and the National Union of Health Workers (Synaps) gathered to protest against government austerity measures.
On 14 August, a greek tanker carrying 17 Georgian sailors was possibly attacked and the sailors kidnapped by pirates in Gabonese waters.
28 October. A group protests for polio awareness along the seafront in Libreville.

On Nov 23 a hundred Gabonese protested in Libreville against the ""manipulation of the constitution"", amended by the Constitutional Court to overcome the absence of President Ali Bongo, hospitalized for a month in Riyadh.

26 November. Officers of the General Directorate of the National Center for University Works barricaded the access of the Ministry of Higher Education in Libreville to protest over non-payment of salaries

10 December. The trade union confederation Dynamique Unitaire (DU) launched a three day national general strike to protest over economic impacts of austerity programs and demand the resignation of the President of the Constitutional Court, Marie-Madeleine Mborantsuo, who, in the absence of the head of the The State, modified the Constitution
11-14 December. CESE members protest, demanding the resignation of Rene Ndemezo'o Obiang, the office chair.
11-14 December. CESE members protest, demanding the resignation of Rene Ndemezo'o Obiang, the office chair.
11-14 December. CESE members protest, demanding the resignation of Rene Ndemezo'o Obiang, the office chair.
11-14 December. CESE members protest, demanding the resignation of Rene Ndemezo'o Obiang, the office chair.

December 18. Police prevent a Dynamic Union protest against government austerity measures. Heavy police presence blocked roads, exit from vehicles and marching by protesters in Libreville near Rond point de la democratie.

column7: SOGATRA: Gabonese Transport Society; Labour Group (Gabon)
column17: December 27. Members of SOGATRA public transport service riot over salaries and kidnap the transport minister, Justin Ndoudangoye, in Libreville. The minister was released on the same day.

07 January. Rioters burn tires, clash with police and set fire to a car in Libreville in a neighborhood near the radio station in support of the attempted coup. Rioters were dispersed by police using tear gas.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Gabon (2009-)
column17: 07 January. After a group of 6 soldiers led by Lieutenant Ondo Obiang Kelly attempt a coup in Libreville by taking over the state radio station, military forces launch an assault against the radio station, killing 2 and arresting others involved.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of Gabon (2009-)
column17: 07 January. A group of 6 soldiers led by Lieutenant Ondo Obiang Kelly, the deputy commander of the Republican Guard, attempt a coup in Libreville by taking over the state radio station, chasing gendarmes and holding journalists hostage. Military forces take back the radio station from soldiers involved in the coup hours later, killing 2 and arresting others involved. Unknown number of ""Gendarmes neutralized"" coded as 3.

column7: SOGATRA: Gabonese Transport Society; Labour Group (Gabon)
column17: 11 January. Agents of SOGATRA protest in front of Tresor buildings in Libreville over salary disputes.

column7: SNLS: National Company of Social Housing
column17: 11 January. SNLS employees protest in Libreville by blocking access to their office over salary disputes.

column7: SNLS: National Society for Social Housing
column17: 17 January. SNLS workers go on strike and protest in Libreville over jobs after the SNLS merged into the National Real Estate Company (SNI).

21 January. Three members of the opposition party group, National Union, are arrested by Gabon police in Libreville in connection with the January 7th coup d'etat. The three men are Firmin Ollo (current president of the youth movement of the National Union), Ballack Obame (a former student leader of National Union) and Mathurin Ovono (also a former student leader). They are later released on January 23.

Week of January 21. Students demand payment of their scholarships from the National Institute of Health and Social Action Training, demonstrating at the entrance of the building for a week (coded as 2 events)

Week of January 21. Students demand payment of their scholarships from the National Institute of Health and Social Action Training, demonstrating at the entrance of the building for a week (coded as 2 events)

30 January. Heavily armed police in 3 trucks raid Razel area of Owendo, a town on the outskirts of Libreville, breaking into and raiding homes, schools, churches and shops as well as making arrests and firing rounds at civilians.
03 February. Protesters block streets in Lamarene against the ethnic imbalance in municipal posts, favouring the Galois and Merie ethnic groups over the Akele.
04 February. Gabon teachers protest in front of Sainte Marie Cathedral in Libreville over salaries for three days. Police intervene each day to disperse the demonstration.
05 February. Gabon teachers protest in front of Sainte Marie Cathedral in Libreville over salaries for three days. Police intervene each day to disperse the demonstration.
06 February. Gabon teachers protest in front of Sainte Marie Cathedral in Libreville over salaries for three days. Police intervene each day to disperse the demonstration.

column7: PSI: Tax Personnel Syndicate; Labour Group (Gabon)
column17: 28 February. Several unions strike and demonstrate in Owendo demanding the release of a study on finance authorities. Demonstrators block the port in Owendo. [size=no report]
01 March. Transport workers from the National Regional Transport Company protest near the airport in Libreville over months of unpaid wages. [size=no report]
06 March. Teachers protest by arranging a sit-in in front of the prime minister's office in Libreville, demanding years of unpaid salaries. [size=no report]

07 March. During a government meeting with teachers' unions in Libreville, teachers gather outside the building and prevent the government ministers and trade union members from leaving. [size=no report]
11 March. Dock workers in Owendo of Komo-Mondah protest against the poor working conditions and employment security of the Bollore firm. [size=no report]
21 March. Employees of the Cleaning and Hygiene Company protest in Port Gentil of Bendje over salaries. [size=no report]
08 April. Students protest in Libreville over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Bitam over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Oyem over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Mouila over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Tchibanga over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Lambarene over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Franceville over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Moanda over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
08 April. Students protest in Port Gentil over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
09 April. Students continue to protest in Libreville over the reduction of university grant funding. Police dispersed the demonstration. [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Bitam over the reduction of university grant funding. Some students were injured as they clashed with police who fired teargas [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Oyem over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Bitam over the reduction of university grant funding. Some students were injured as they clashed with police who fired teargas [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Tchibanga over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
09 April. Students protest in Lambarene over the reduction of university grant funding. [size=thousands]
15 April. Striking teachers protest in Libreville of Komo-Mondah demanding better wages. [size=no report]
19 April. A group of pensioners protest in Libreville at the office of CNSS over payment of their pensions. [size=no report]

07 June. Students riot against police forces with rocks and other projectiles at Omar Bongo University in Libreville over distribution of scholarship funds. Police forces use tear gas to disperse the riot. [size=no report]

11 June. Students demonstrated in Libreville at University of Omar Bongo to demand scholarships, shutting down exams. Gendarme forces intervened to disrupt the demonstration, with reports of clashes and violence with students. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of Gabon (2009-) Prison Guards
column17: 21 June. Police forces tortured a civilian to death in a Franceville, Passa prison.
15 July. Police arrested the leader of the FPG party, Gerard Ella Nguema, before a planned political march in Libreville.

column9: MPDRR: Patriotic and Democratic Movement for the Refoundation of the Republic
column17: 08 August. Police forces arrested Jean-Francois Ntoutoume Emane, the former Prime Minister and opposition party leader of MPDRR, and two of his sons in the Tahiti area of north Libreville.
On October 25, 2019, the populations of Libreville staged a peaceful protest against the rape of a teeneager by a known businessman. [size=tens]
On November 5, 2019, the workers of Averda Company protested in Libreville, to demand the payment of 3 month salary arears. [size=no reports]

On November 18, 2019, the populations of Mimongo town (Ogoulou, Ngounie), blocked access to administration offices and erected roadblock as they demonstrated to demand better living conditions. [size=no report]

On 21 November 2019, around twenty Gabonese government officials, including the government spokesman, were arrested in the city of Libreville (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) in the context of an anti-corruption investigation.

On 2 December 2019, the police forces arrested the former Chief of Staff of Gabonese President, as well as the former Minister of Water and Energy, and former Oil Minister, in Libreville (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire). This occurred shortly after their dismissal from the government. They are accused of corruption.

column7: Labour Group (Gabon); SOGATRA: Gabonese Transport Society
column17: On 8 January 2020, a group of retired workers of Gabonese transport company staged a protest in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their retiring allowance. [size=no report]
On 10 January 2020, a group of students protested in Owendo town (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against a reform of the baccalaureate exam. [size=no report]

On 23 Jan. 2020, the population of PK7 area of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) erected barricades and burnt tires as they were demonstrating against an attempted abduction of a boy. The police forces intervened to remove the barricades and stop the fires. [size=no report]

column16: Gabon Media Times; Africa 1; AFP; Gabon Actu; Gabo News
column17: On 24 Jan. 2020, the population of PK9 area of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) erected barricades and burnt tires as they were demonstrating against a wave of abduction of children (denied by Gabonese authorities). They clashed with the police and Gendarmerie forces who made use of tear gas. One person was burnt to death, and one other was beaten and injured, and later died of his wounds. A woman was killed by a stray bullet. (total of 3 fatalities). [size=no report]

On 28 Jan. 2020 (or around), the police forces arrested 210 people suspected to be linked to the recent violent demonstrations that resulted in the death of 2 people in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire), after the rumours of children kidnappings.

On 5 Feb. 2020, members of the Dynamique Unitaire labour union staged a protest in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against the government's austerity measures. The security forces [coded: Police Forces] intervened and arrested several protesters. [size=no report]

On 3 March 2020, locals seized transport equipment of an oil company operating in Lambarene town (Ogooue et Lacs, Moyen-Ogooue), as they demonstrated to demand a better redistribution of oil industry incomes. [size=no report]
On 7 March 2020, in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) the government of Gabon announced the 'temporary' closure the borders with Cameroon due to the coronavirus.

On 9 March 2020, students of the national health institute blocked the entrance of their school in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) as they demonstrated to demand the payment of their scholarships. [size=no report]

On 30 March 2020, a group of taxi drivers demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against what they describe as racketeering by security forces reportedly facilitated by coronavirus related measures. [size=no report]

On 17 April 2020 (or around), police intervened as residents demonstrated in Ntoum commune of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire). They claimed that the government's distribution of food vouchers during the coronavirus lockdown was not well organised, and many residents were not taken into account. [size=no report]

On 20 April 2020, residents erected barricades and blocked a main road as they demonstrated in Ntoum commune of Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire). They claimed that the government's distribution of food vouchers during the coronavirus lockdown was not well organised, and many residents were not taken into account. Security forces (assumed Police Forces) made use of tear gas to disperse them. One woman was reportedly injured. [size=no report]

On 30 April 2020, unidentified individuals burnt the tribune of honour of the Engong Stadium in Oyem town (Ntem, Woleu-Ntem), and shared the video on the social media. The reason of this incident was not reported.
On 2 May 2020, residents captured and beat one suspected thief to death in Port Gentil town (Bendje, Ogooue-Maritime). [size=no report]
On 4 May 2020, teachers demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Education in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their salaries. [size=no report]

On 27 May 2020, several public workers demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the regularisation of their administrative situation. The security forces fired tear gas to disperse them. One labour union leader was arrested. [size=several]
Around 28 May 2020 (week of), the military forces severely beat up and injured two people in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire), for violating the counter coronavirus curfew.

On 31 May 2020, villagers repelled the prefect of the Djouori-Agnili division who was bringing food support to Kabaga village, near Bongoville (Djouori-Agnili, Haut-Ogooue), in the context of counter coronavirus state support. They destroyed his gifts and threw it against his car. This was reportedly a reaction to the recent death of an influential local politician in prison. [size=no report]

On 24 June 2020, tens of citizens demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) against a vote at the National Assembly to decriminalize homosexuality. The police forces intervened to disperse the demonstrators. 4 were arrested. [size=tens]

On 25 June 2020, more than a hundred students demonstrated in Masuku neighbourhood of Franceville town (Passa, Haut-Ogooue) against a vote at the National Assembly to decriminalize homosexuality. [size=more than a hundred]

On 25 June 2020, students of the national teachers' school demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their scholarships arrears. They disrupted ongoing courses and erected barricades to block the schools entry. [size=no report]

On 26 June 2020, students of the national teachers' school demonstrated for the second day in a row, in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their scholarships arrears. They erected barricades and burnt tires in front of their school. The security forces (assumed Police Forces) intervened to disperse them. [size=no report]

On 2 July 2020, members the Mining Ministry union clashed with the security guards (assumed Police Forces) of the minister in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) as they attempted to force their way to see the minister over concerns about mining royalties. Several people were injured. [size=at least several]

On 12 July 2020, a group of taxi drivers demonstrated in Port Gentil town (Bendje, Ogooue-Maritime) against abuses by security forces during the enforcement of the anti-coronavirus measures. The security forces (assumed Police Forces) reportedly arrested some of the demonstrators. [size=no report]

Around 23 July 2020 (as reported), residents captured one suspected robber and severely beat him up before handing him to the police in Nzeng-Ayong neighbourhood of Libreville city (Komoh-Mondah, Estuaire). [size=no report]
On 27 July 2020, teachers demonstrated in Owendo town (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of salary arrears. They erected barricades in front of they high school. [size=no report]

On 10 August 2020, former employees of the Gabon Press Agency demonstrated in front of the Ministry of Finance in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their dismissal allocations. [size=no report]

column16: Gabon Actu; Gabon Media Times; Gabo News
column17: On 1 September 2020, about 50 forest guards demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their corporation allowances. The gendarmerie forces fired tear gas to disperse them, to which they replied with stones. Several were arrested, and 5 others injured. [size=about 50]

On 7 October 2020, members of the national forest guards union demonstrated in Libreville city (Komo-Mondah, Estuaire) to demand the payment of their bonuses. They erected barricades at the entrance of the Ministry of Water and Forests. [size=no report]

Gambia's Justice Minister, Edward Gomez has been quoted issuing threats to exiled journalists and rights defenders, saying that they would be prosecuted if they returned for painting a grim picture of the country.
On 17 June 2011, the police forces arrested and tortured an Islamic preacher in Gunjur town (Kombo South, Brikama). It 's unclear what he was accused of.
Gambia's special criminal court on Friday sentenced the country's former police chief to life in prison for armed robbery, corruption, and a host of other charges.
Gambias election campaign wrapped up Tuesday with rival presidential candidates staging rallies in the tiny capital Banjul ahead of the poll tipped to hand incumbent Yahya Jammeh a fourth term.

Staff and students of the President's International Award (PIA) staged a mass protest against the re-appointment of their former chief executive officer, Abdoulie Bah, by the Ministry of Youth and Sports.The angry students, who were chanting 'we don't want Abdoulie Bah' said they need the help of the authorities to address the problem at PIA.
On 18 May 2012, the police forces arrested and reportedly tortured an influent Imam in a mosque in Brikama town (Kombo Central, Brikama).

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: During the month of May 2012, the government of Yahya Jammeh arbitrarily arrested and tortured persons included the father of Omar Fufana who testified before the TRRC on 30 January 2020.
Four are killed in a landmine blast, believed to have been a remnant of a 2007 war with Senegal.
Four people are killed when their cart hits a landmine near the Casamance region.

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: Imam Baba Leigh, a human rights activist and religious leader, was arrested by the NIA after he criticized the government's use of the death penalty in one of his sermons. During his five month incommunicado detention, he was severely tortured

Thousands gathered in Banjul to protest against the 17-point demands by the European Union, which include infrastructure and health improvements, in exchange for the financing to do so. Many see this as an encroachment upon their national autonomy.

Arrests: Baboucarr Ceesay, journalist and vice president of the Gambia Press Union, was arrested by plain-clothes officers of the National Intelligence Agency shortly after he left his residence. No reason was given for his arrest, though the detention is likely political. Baboucarr Ceesay was detained for four days in September after seeking a permit for protest from police officials.
Arrests: Col. Solo Bojang, a senior officer with the Gambia National Army in charge of Kanilai Guard, was charged with multiple criminal charges (theft, conspiracy, abuse of office, etc.)
Armed men attacked businesses in Upper Saloum District village of Panchang, Central River Region
Gambia National Trade Union Congress held May Day protests for increased salaries and improved working conditions.
Bakers in the Gambia town of Brikama, West Coast Region, embarked on a sit-down strike after public health authorities at the Brikama Health Centre ordered them to improve on their hygiene

least 150 youths from around Brikama yesterday morning protested along the Brikama-Banjul Highway demanding an end to exploitative working conditions in the local timber business. The demonstration was broken up by police although there were no been reports of whether this was violent or not.
People gathered in Soma to celebrate the International Day of the Girl Child (Oct. 11).

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: At least five people were detained at NIA headquarters for several weeks, held incommunicado, and physically abused for sexual orientation.

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: A man suspected of homosexuality was detained by NIA agents, held for eight days at NIA headquerters and then detained at Mile 2 prison for nine months with another man, subject to regular abuse at the hands of NIA officials for ""unnatural acts"". They were relased in July 2015
Following an attempted coup in December 2014, security forces detained and tortured three suspected coup plotters in custody. One escaped to Germany.

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: Five people reportedly abducted by men believed to be members of the NIA.

Arrests: Dozens of military personnel and civilians were arrested and a large cache of weapons and explosive found in the aftermath of an attempted coup earlier in the week. There is a heavy security presence throughout Banjul, including checkpoints, roadblocks, and house-to-house searches.

column7: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017); Police Forces of Gambia (1996-2017)
column17: Hundreds of security force members held a rally in support of President Jammeh, four days after an attempted coup.

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: One man was reportedly abducted by men believed to be members of the NIA.
Thousands marched in favor of the government in light of the Dec 30 attack on the presidential palace.

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: One man was reportedly abducted by men believed to be members of the NIA.
Gambians in Brikama took to streets to denounce the December 30th attack on the presidential palace in Banjul
The people of the Lower River Region (LRR) last Thursday turned out in their numbers to line up the streets of Jarra Soma in strong condemnation of the December 30th militant attack on State House

The Mourid community in The Gambia Sunday joined the global condemnation of the December 30th attack on State House. The Khalifa general of the Mourid, Pap Demba Jobe, led the condemnation that came in the form of a protest march at the Kanifing Municipal Council
Malians living in The Gambia Friday marched in their numbers from the Arch 22nd to the City Council in Banjul, in denouncement of the December 30th militant attack of State House.
Ahlu Tivaouane Federation, a religious Tijaniyya sect representing all the Daras in The Gambia Thursday strongly condemned the 30th December militant attack on State House in Banjul.

column7: Federation of Jamiatul Ansar Ud Deen
column17: The Federation of Jamiyatul Ansarudeen, a Muslim group of the Nyassen sect, on Tuesday joined the global condemnation of December 30th attack on State House, by organising a march in Banjul.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.
A sit-down protest organized by the University of the Gambia was held by students from 26 to 31 March, to denounce the new grading system.

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: Brothers Muhammed Fadel Hydara and Hatabu Hydara were reportedly picked up from their homes in Serekunda by alleged NIA members. They have not been seen since

column6: Military Forces of Gambia (1996-2017) National Intelligence Agency
column17: Alagie Abdoulie Ceesay, manager of Taranga FM radio station, was picked up by NIA agents on July 2 and released July 13, without charge; he was reportedly severely tortured. Ceesay was seen forced into a car in Banjul four days later. He is on trial for sedition and has been refused bail
