column17: 16 December. Police officers were video-taped when assaulting a taxi driver and beating a passenger in Accra. The victim resisted his arrest for illegally overtaking. Police later confirmed the incident but clarified that Community Police Assistants were involved, not regular police forces.
18 December. Youth working for the Forestry Commission stormed the head office in Accra and protested over non-payment of their salaries.
24 December. Two days prior to the national referendum on the creation of new regions, police forces in the Hohoe municipality seized weapons in Alavanyo-Dzagbedze. The owners are on the run.
27 December (on or around). Angry NPP party members stormed a meeting of Fomena NPP regional executives amid internal dissensions, injuring an MP, destroying his car and vandalising the office.
On December 28, in Accra city (Accra, Greater Accra), policemen attacked a journalist who was covering the BHIM concert, leaving him hospitalized.

On December 30, in Tema town (Tema, Greater Accra), an unidentified armed actor killed the Senior Pastor of Tema Community Four Assemblies of God Church just before Sunday morning worship for unknown reasons.

On January 2, in Accra city (Accra, Greater Accra), Muslim youth attacked the Glorious Word Power Ministries International Church because its Reverend prophesied that some prominent personalities, including the National Chief Imam could die before 2019 ends. Vandalism was reported but there were no reported injuries.
06 January. A police patrol team in Accra fired gunshots at suspected robbers on a motorbike at Spintex road. One of the robbers died and one got injured.
08 January. Rioters, mainly former aggrieved customers of Menzgold, blocked roads and burned tyres in Kumasi to demand their money that is locked in the company
10 January. Police fired gunshots on youths that attacked chiefs who attended the funeral of Yaa-Naa Yakubu Andani in Yendi
10 January. Prior to a funeral, Abudus militias and Andanis militia clashed in Yendi. One person died and three sustained gunshot wounds.
11 January. At the day of a funeral of Yaa-Naa Yakubu Abudus militias and Andanis militia clashed again in Yendi. 17 people injured and a number of houses torched.
12 January. Police officers at Adenta Police station in Greater Accra were accused of having beaten a detainee to death. The victim died in police custody.

13 January. Military Forces of Ghana and unidentified youth fought in Alavanyo Dzogbefeme in Kpandu area. Military forces were dispatched to the village to retrieve a weapon that was stolen from a police patrol earlier that day. 3 people died in the battle.

On January 16, an investigative journalist was shot in the neck and chest by unknown assailants while he was driving in Accra. The attack is thought to be politically motivated as a member of the Ghaninan parliament recently criticised his work and pointed him as a target.

18 January. During the festivities around the new Yaa-Naa in Yendi, gunshots were fired from a building and police forces responded. One dead person found in the building and two people arrested with AK47. Authorities imposed a curfew in the town from 5pm to 7am.
24 January. Residents of the Kwesimintsim Zongo community in Takoradi marched to the local Police station asking questions on the death of a suspect in police custody

25 January. Two days after an accident in a mine, a crowd protested at the mortuary of the Upper East Regional Hospital in Bolgatanga. Protesters called for the withdrawal of the Shaanxi mining company responsible for the mine.
28 January. Traders protested in Accra against the plan of the city administration to sell a parcel of land to a private developer

On 31 January 2019, unknown gunmen, who may be part of Invisible Forces, attacked the residence of the NDC candidate Delali Berempong in Accra (Accra, Greater Accra) who competed in the Ayawaso West Wuogon by-election on that day. Six people sustained gunshot wounds.

On 31 January 2019, the NDC MP Sam George was attacked by unknown gunmen in Accra, believed to be members of the vigilante group Invisible Forces. He was beaten and chased by a about 50 people. The attack is related to the Ayawaso West Wuogon by-election on that day.
On 31 January 2019, unknown gunmen stormed the polling station for the Ayawaso West Wuogon by-election at La Bawalashie Presby in Accra and fired shots at NDC agents.
04 February. Unidentified gunmen approached three police officers in Tamale, opened gun fire and stole two AK47

05 February. Unidentified gunmen clashed with police and military forces along the Otorkpolu-Odumase highway. Security forces were overpowered, one soldier injured and reinforcement troops were sent to the location. Assaillants were arrested later that day
05 February. NDC members of Parliament marched to the Police HQ in Accra to demand justice for MP Samuel George who was assaulted during the Ayawao by-elections.

column7: PNC: Peoples National Convention; NDC: National Democratic Congress; CPP: Convention Peoples Party; PPP: Progressive Peoples Party
column17: 08 February. Organized by the PNC and supported by NDC, CPP and PPP protesters in Accra marched against increasing levels of political violence. The NPP government was blamed to be inactive against political vigilante groups such as the Invisible Forces militia.
08 February (or around). A Fulani and teacher were killed in Nangon, near Karaga, by unknown gunmen

08 February. Armed farmers attacked herdsman in Ahomahomaso near Begoro in the Fanteakwa District of the Eastern Region, in an attempt to chase them away from the area. The herders were accused of having killed cattle in the community

11 February. Two factions of Atulbabisi royal family who are in dispute over chieftaincy clashed in Bolgatanga. Police and Military forces were dispatched to calm the situation. Two officers and another person were shot and injured.

11 February. Members of the Pro-NDC ""The Hawks"" militia, armed with guns and other weapons, attacked the NDC Suame Consituency Chairman leaving him injured. The militia stormed a meeting in Kumasi and fired gun shots. The victim is accused of possessing a party vehicle which he is not entitled to.

11 February. Traders and workers clashed in Kumasi over the distribution of market space, after their relocation from the central market. Both parties fought with sticks and stones. One person left unconscious
12 February. Rioters in Salaga protested against the nomination of Damango as capital of the new Savannah region. They set ablaze the local NPP office and hindered fire fighters to control the fire
13 February. Youth protested at the Police HQ in Salaga and demanded the release of seven suspects who were arrested for the destruction of the NPP HQ on the previous day
16 February. Fulani militias attacked Abrewankaw community. They killed a resident, injured several others and set the village ablaze.
18 February. The Hawks Militia, that is informally affliated with a NDC wing, attacked a NDC meeting at the HQ in Kumasi and killed one person
19 February. Two rivaling factions of the Atulbabisi Clan engaged in a battle over chieftaincy in Bolgatanga. One person killed by gunshots, one injured
23 February. CPP members marched through Accra to remember the overthrow of President Nkrumah and call for CPP to rule the country.
05 March. Two rival groups of Fadama and Abeka neighborhoods clashed in Fadama/Accra. One person stabbed to death
05 March. A group of young men stormed Fadama area in Accra in reprisal for the earlier clash. They vandalized shops and scared residents
07 March (or around). Two journalists were kidnapped by workers of a gold mine while investigating at Apampatia village. Police forces rescued the journalists
07 March. Spare part dealers protested a tax hike on luxurious vehicles in Accra [size=no report]
12 March. Students of the University of Education, Winneba, protested the dismissal of lecturers [size=no report]

14 March. Three journalists filmed a police officer on an unregistered motorbike involved in a traffic accident. They got engaged in an argument and were later pounced and assaulted by a team of 10 police and military officers. The journalists were rushed to the hospital for treatment.

14 March. The peaceful student demonstration at the University campus in Winneba against the dismissal of lecturers turned violent when rioters started to destroy property and threw stones at police forces. Police responded with teargas and warning shots. 10 people were injured.
15 March. Fights Chekosi and Konkomba resumed in Nazawani in Cheperoni area, leading to one death. Military and Police forces were dispatched to the district.
15 March (or around). Gun battles between Chekosi and Konkomba spread from Nazawani to Nansoni. Military and Police forces were dispatched to the district.
16 March. Residents of Dansoman in Accra protested the high costs of living and lacking development in their area [size=no report]

17-19 March. Clashes between Chekosi and Konkomba militias continued in Chereponi district until March 19. Bullets fired and houses in 22 communities were torched and civilians were forced to flee. Police forces dispatched to region to restore calm

17-19 March. Clashes between Chekosi and Konkomba militias continued in Chereponi district until March 19. Bullets fired and houses in 22 communities were torched and civilians were forced to flee. Police forces dispatched to region to restore calm

17-19 March. Clashes between Chekosi and Konkomba militias continued in Chereponi district until March 19. Bullets fired and houses in 22 communities were torched and civilians were forced to flee. Police forces dispatched to region to restore calm
20 March. A mob of mechanics lynched a suspected robber in Sunyani and killed him [size=no report]
21 March (or around). Two farmer families clashed in Hwakpo over land. One person killed. Intervention of police forces prevented a full scale communal clash
25 March. Residents of Kumasi protested the inappropriate management of landfill site by the city administration [size=no report]
27 March (or around). Employees of a Chinese construction company staged a demonstration in Accra to protest their treatment [size=no report]
31 March-1 April. Rioters mounted roadblocks and carried cutlasses and ""offensive materials"" in Nanton for 2 days to protest the nomination of a chief [size=no report]
01 April (or around). Landguards attempted to assassinate a local chief but instead killed two civilians in Denkyira in Ga South municipality
31 March-1 April. Rioters mounted roadblocks and carried cutlasses and ""offensive materials"" in Nanton for 2 days to protest the nomination of a chief [size=no report]
02 April. Customers of Menzgold protested at the EOCO office in Accra and demanded access to the seized assets of the company [size=dozens]

02 April (or around). Two rivaling factions of the NPP engaged in a street-fight over internal disagreements at the party's office in Effiduase-Asokore. Police intervened and arrested four people [size=no report]
03 April (or around). Workers of a mining company staged a peaceful protest in Tongo and demanded the arrest of suspected murderer [size=no report]

03 April. Rioters burnt tyres, blocked roads and assaulted the fire patrol in Nuaso during a protest against power cuts in the area. Police attempted to disperse the crowd with warning shots and eventually shot two rioters. Both were injured [size=no report]
04 April (or around). Rioters burnt tyres and blocked roads in Kasoa to protest the bad state of roads in the community [size=no report]
04 May. Women groups protested the raids and harrassments of suspected sex workers in a police raid in Abuja. Protests took place in Lagos, Abuja and Accra. [size=no report]
23 April. Farmers from Aboatsam, close to Asesewa, attacked a group of Fulani pastoralists and gunshot wounded one.
24 April. Farmers from Aboatsam, close to Asesewa, attacked a group of Fulani pastoralists and gunshot wounded two.

column8: Police Forces of Ghana (2017-) Metropolitan City Guards
column17: 25 April. A demolition exercise by Tamale City Guards that hit NDC property sparked a street-fight between NDC supporters and City Guards. A body guard of the mayor fired a warning shot to end violence. [size=no report]

25 April. A group of about 20 members of a faction of the NDC Hawks militia stabbed a member of another faction of the militia at his home in Kenyasi-Abirem/Kumasi. The latter's group was involved in the February shooting incident in Kumasi.

27 April (or around). A group from Ntsin community staged a protest at a festival in Cape Coast accusing the local traditional ruler and the regional minister of ignoring the youth in the area. Police intervened. [size=200]

27 April. About 20 members of the Ghana Armed Forces intervened in an argument between Minibus drivers in Anwiankwanta as one of the buses belonged to them. They beat the drivers up, leaving some with injuries.
02 May. A women group staged a protest in Sekondi-Takoradi to demand the release of three girls kidnapped last year. [size=no report]

03 May. Residents of Dawhenya burned tyres and blocked a main road with containers to protest the bad state of the road. Police forces intervened and used teargas to disperse the crowd. [size=no report]

05 September. Members of NDC violently demonstrated at regional party HQ in Kumasi against the exclusion of candidates in the parliamentary primaries. Police forces were able to stop the crowd from burning the building. [size=no report]

13 May (or around). Residents of Nanakrom/Adenta protested the bad state of the road due to the recent flooding in the area. Protesters demand fixing of infrastructure in their community. [size=no report]
14 May. Rioters in Sunyani burnt tyres and blocked a street to protest the bad state of a road in their area. [size=no report]
15 May. Rioters in Sunyani threw stones at Police forces who cleared the road after the protest of May 14. Two police vehicles were damaged and rioters arrested. [size=no report]

16 May. Police forces executed a court warrant in Manso Tontokrom when they encountered a group of youth with guns and machetes. Youth erected road blocks and attacked police officers. Police responded with warning shots. One police officer and five youth sustained gunshot wounds.
19 May. A farmer was killed by Fulani militias in Asatoase.
20 May. The district coordinating director of Chereponi was attacked by Konkomba militias in Garinkuka and injured. Another civilian was killed.
20 May. Rioters in Manya Kpongunor attacked a team tasked with the power disconnection of the area due to unpaid bills. Three people injured.
20 May. Residents of Apowa protested the bad state of the highway in their community. [size=no report]
21 May. The closure of media houses due to expired licenses sparked protest in Accra. Protesters demanded free expression and media. [size=hundreds]

22 May. Rioters burnt tyres and blocked a road in Odumase-Krobo with stones and wood to protest the disconnection from the electricity grid due to unpaid bills. The team and their police escort were pelted with stones. Police responded with gunshot and straybullets killed at least one rioter. [size=no report]
28 May. NPP youth assaulted the District Chief Executive Officer of Krachi West and dragged him out of his office. The assailants claim that the the DCE was working against NPP interests.
31 May (or around). A youth mob burnt a suspected robber in Huhunya. The robbers previously shot two of the youth who were chasing them. [size=no report]
03 June. Police forces rescued a civilian in Agogo who was arrested by a mob and accused of being part of the Huhunya robbery happened in the previous week. [size=no report]

06 June. Militias of the rivaling chiefs Bukari and Kant shot at each others palaces in Bole. Chief Bukaris house and car were later set ablaze by Kant militias. Bukari was rescued by Police forces who took over both palaces and ended violence.

08 June (or around). Youth stormed the Police station in Breman Asikuma and pelted it with stones to protest the death of a suspected drug dealer in police custody. Police reinforcements dispersed the crowd. [size=no report]
10 June (or around). Residents of New Esaase, close to Nkawkaw, protested against the a gold mining company operating in their village and the lack of development in their area. [size=no report]
12 June. A suspected robber was lynched to death by a mob in Tema. The victim died despite the intervention of police forces. [size=no report]
14 June. Ayomso and Akrodie communal groups clashed in Akrodie over concessions for woodworkers. The clash resulted in two deaths and 13 injured.

The residence of Guineas recently installed president was hit by rocket fire as sustained heavy weapons fire by an unknown individual or group. One staff member dead. Guineas former army chief Nouhou Thiam was arrested Tuesday after the attack, though his involvement is unknown.

column17: Clashes between supporters of the ruling party and the opposition have resulted in 24 people injured. The clashes were instigated by an RPG attack of a procession staged of the wife of leading opposition politician Cellou Dalein Diallo.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: The RPG planned a rally in Kindia town, which lead to at least 10 people being injured in a clash between supporters of the opposition and the ruling party. Looting also reported.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: UFDG protesters erected barricades. When the police broke through these barricades, some members of the protest began shooting, killing a trainee policeman and injuring 51 in total.

column8: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Clashes between RPG and UFDG supporters continue on Monday in Hamdallaye, Bambeto, Cosa, Cite de lAir and Wanindara. Gunfire heard.

column8: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Clashes between RPG and UFDG supporters continue on Monday in Hamdallaye, Bambeto, Cosa, Cite de lAir and Wanindara. Gunfire heard.

column8: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Clashes between RPG and UFDG supporters continue on Monday in Hamdallaye, Bambeto, Cosa, Cite de lAir and Wanindara. Gunfire heard.

column8: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Clashes between RPG and UFDG supporters continue on Monday in Hamdallaye, Bambeto, Cosa, Cite de lAir and Wanindara. Gunfire heard.
Clashes between young people from different communities have led to arson in Mollahtoureya, Ratoma.

column6: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column8: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Clashes between RPG and UFDG supporters continue on Monday in Hamdallaye, Bambeto, Cosa, Cite de lAir and Wanindara. Gunfire heard.
Guinea riot police fired tear gas to disperse opposition activists protesting the supreme Courts confirmation that the ruling party won the country's divisive elections.
Demonstrations continued on Saturday with rioters building barricades on the roads of Conakry and in the suburbs.
Police in Guinea shot and wounded two people during a violent protest over an alleged attempt to kidnap a radio journalist on Sunday.
1 teenage girl was shot dead by police during a riot in Conakry.
Protests against living conditions in Fria, clashes occurred between angry youths and security agents
Divisional Commissioner gunned down about a month ago on the outskirts of the Guinean capital by unknown assailants
Rioters killed a suspected murderer, attempted to kill the accomplices, but the police turned the rioters back
Rioters attacked police after the presumed beating leading to death of a Kankan footballer; 15 people were wounded, including 8 shot; at least 3 fatalities reported
19 injured in 2 days of clashes over disputed gold mine claimed by both the residents of Kignekoura and Sidikila
19 injured in 2 days of clashes over disputed gold mine claimed by both the residents of Kignekoura and Sidikila

Rioters blocked the highway where three people were killed in a road accident, tried to attack the truck driver responsible, then surrounded the police station where he was being held; police from Kankan were called it to assist their counterparts in Sanguiana; no violence reported

Disappearance of a Boke citizen and perceived indifference by security services caused clashes between youth in Boke and the security services after the youth start burning shops and stoning vehicles in the central market
At least 21 hurt in riots over power outages in Conakry; police used tear gas, rubber bullets and batons to disperse demonstrators who threw stones, burned tires and erected barricades

Two killed and 33 wounded as residents angry at power shortages rioted; police used batons and tear gas, rioters used stone; one rioter killed by police car, one police trainee hit with a stone and beaten to death

Protests against lack of water and electricity in the suburbs of Conakry undertaken; women marched, blocking traffic to the red-light districts, including Bambeto and Cosa; police intervention led to the death of one young tailor

Security measures: Guinea and Mali have agreed to establish joint patrols on their borders to curb cross-border crime (e.g. Drug trafficking, weapon smuggling) and avert conflicts between herders and farmers in the border regions
New protests against lack of water and electricity in the suburbs of Conakry undertaken; women protested by setting up road blocks and ""looting"" private vehicles
Students at some public schools in the capital began a protest, leading to teaching being blocked out of the schools; these protests were dispersed by police using tear gas

Non-violent activity: The governor of Conakry has been replaced following his handling of the riots in February and implying deadly forced would be used if people made trouble while the Moroccan king visited Conakry
Police moved to break up student protests in Ratoma, using tear gas
A demonstration was held in Kankan against insecurity following the murder of a soldier near a bank the previous night
Security agents broke up a protest against the Guinean Aboriginal Corporation Palm Oil and Rubber (sic), killing one person and injuring others

column9: MSF: Doctors Without Borders; Health Workers (International)
column17: On 5 April 2014, a mob of locals attacked an isolation centre for people suffering from the Ebola outbreak at Macenta. People pelted stones at MSF aid workers at the centre. The attack was likely motivated by misinformation about the treatment process and a rumour that Ebola was brought over on purpose.
Thousands of Guinean officials participated in a sit-in outside the PMO to demand their pecuniary charges
Nineteen people were seriously injured in violent clashes between two communities in the village of NDiarre (sic); it appears to have been a dispute over land; the alleged leaders have been detained
Dozens of women, joined by ministers, former ministers and MPs, walked to the Nigerian embassy to protest the kidnapping of girls in Nigeria by Boko Haram
A group of Muslim youths looted and torches bars and eateries in the urban area of Kankan, including the ""Rio"" bar, ""Sinkefara"", ""Djicorony"" and ""Le Destin"" public house

Muslim youths who had been looting and torching bars in Kankan were opposed when they arrived at ""Le Bon"" by youth of the neighbourhood; the two groups of youth clashed and afterwards the looters stopped

column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross; Aid Workers (International); Health Workers (International)
column17: The Red Cross has suspended operations in southeast Guinea after a group of naked men wielding knives surrounded a marked Red Cross vehicle and threatened the passengers.
Residents of villages in Guineas southeast region have shut out medical workers by blocking roads and bridges in some cases due to fears over Ebola.

A mob formed over anger at the police due to the escape of several criminals from jail. The rioters proceeded to loot and ransack several public buildings, and later went to the civil prison and released all prisoners. Local authorities took shelter in a nearby military camp.

A crowd of young men, some armed with clubs and pistols, set up barricades and threatened to attack the hospital following rumours that Ebola had been purposefully spread in the city. Security forces intervened, gunshots were fired by the rioters, and at least 55 people were injured.

Youth protesters hold series of demonstrations over the past month in Labe, calling for dismissal of Samba Diouma Camara as head of the youth association in Labe, due to his support of President Alpha Conde in upcoming elections.

column9: Aid Workers (Guinea); Journalists (Guinea); Government of Guinea-Bissau (2012-2014)
column17: ""One INGO staff member, along with seven other individuals (government officials and journalists), was killed in a mob attack. The group was part of an Ebola education team. It appears that the community members attacked because they believed that health workers were spreading the disease.""
Youth riot against local authorities support of President Conde. Reports of stone throwing between protesters and police in streets of Labe, and rioters burning tires in the street.

At least 21 members of a government outreach team were injured when residents of Women near Nzerekore attacked them with sticks and stones, thinking they were coming to bring Ebola to the village. 6 of the officials and 3 journalists were believed to be captured but 8 bodies have been recovered. Among them were the regional director of health and assistant director of Nzerekore hospital. It is also reported that they have erected barricades and destroyed a bridge to block access to the town.

""A team of five aid workers was attacked in Guinea by a crowd that grew hostile when the team started collecting bodies believed to be infected with Ebola. One the aid workers sustained a neck wound.""

column9: ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent
column17: A Red Cross team was attacked while collecting bodies believed to be infected with Ebola, one worker wounded in the neck. Family members of the dead attacked 6 volunteers and vandalized their cars, then threw rocks at the regional health office.
Arrests: Police arrested 27 suspects over the murders of 8 Ebola education team members, who were attacked by locals in Women last week.
Reports of police throwing stones at protesters on Oct. 2 in Labe. No injuries or arrests reported.

column9: Aid Workers (Guinea); Women (Guinea); ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent
column17: ""A team of Red Cross volunteers was attacked by a group of people that pelted the team with bricks and stones. One Red Cross volunteer that managed to return to their vehicle was wounded by shards of glass in her eye when the car window was hit by the a stone and shattered. She was taken to the hospital and had the glass removed from her eye.""

Protesters gather at parliament in Conakry and go on a hunger strike on Nov. 11 to demand the demilitarization of the village of Womey where 8 members of an Ebola education team were killed in September.
A group of homosexual youth clashed with another group of youth at a public celebration.
Five homosexual youth were arrested after clashing with another group of youth at a public celebration.

column9: Civilians (International); Health Workers (International); Aid Workers (International); ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross
column17: An angry crowd confronted Red Cross workers regarding the burial of an Ebola victim. The police tried unsuccessfully to calm the situation as the rioters burned a Red Cross vehicle.
Property destruction: A pickup full of gendarmes reportedly raided the Orange offices and dismantled their billboards.

Dozens of youth staged an angry protest against a new Ebola treatment centre, halting the construction. They damaged a gazebo and equipment being used for the opening as Doctors Without Borders staff and local officials were evacuated.
Hundreds of youth violently prevented the installation of an Ebola treatment centre, setting fires and breaking furniture.
Youth in the Bambeto-Cosa interchange area blocked roads as part of a general strike and security forces dispersed them.

column7: CNTG: National Confederation of Guinean Workers
column17: Strikes: Trade unions led day two of a general strike calling primarily for salary increases for civil servants.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; UFR: Union of Republican Forces
column17: At least a dozen were injured in clashes between opposition political protesters who threw stones and burned tires, and police who used tear gas and possibly live ammunition.
Clashes reported between opposition supporters and security forces.
Youth in the Bambeto-Cosa interchange area clashed with police after blocking streets and burning tires in support of the general strike.

Residents attacked a group of three police officers and their driver who stopped on their way to a funeral, claiming the victims were spreading Ebola and had killed a local resident whom one of the victims had given a sedative. The mob used machetes and clubs to beat the victims, killing two and setting their bodies on fire.
President Conde joined a demonstration of several hundred people to a sign a condolence book at the French embassy in light of the Charlie Hebdo attacks in France.

Authorities in Guinea say one person died and three others were seriously wounded after someone threw a grenade into a crowd of people watching a televised soccer match. Some media houses reported the number of fatalities as 3, though the police chief only confirmed 1 death.

column7: UFC: Union of Forces for Change
column17: Thousands of opposition activists rallied in the Guinean capital on Thursday demanding ""anyone but Alpha"" Conde be returned in presidential polls expected before the end of the year
Around 50 people were injured in riots in the town of Labe in northern Guinea when people protesting a shake-up in the civil service clashed with security forces, the government said on Wednesday

column9: Aid Workers (Guinea); Women (Guinea); ICRC: International Committee of the Red Cross and Red Crescent
column17: ""An Guinea Red Cross volunteer was wounded in an attack by a mob in Forecariah when she tried to provide a burial for a woman suspected to have died from Ebola. Another volunteer was attacked during the incident as but sustained no serious injuries.""

Around a dozen Guineans were wounded Monday in clashes with police after the arrest of an imam who led funeral prayers for a suspected victim of Ebola. Demonstrators put up barricades, burned tyres and overturned rubbish bins in the capital Conakry, before using sticks and stones to attack officers who responded with tear gas and baton charges.
Local media journalist Abdoulaye Oumou was assaulted by police forces while covering a civil society protest against insecurity

One protester was killed and several others shot and wounded Monday as Guinean police battled to control violent demonstrations in the capital Conakry against the regime of President Alpha Conde. The opposition had called for demonstrations across the capital against a lack of stability, which it blames on Condes government.

Fresh violence erupted in the Guinean capital Tuesday after a day of clashes between police and anti-government protesters that left one dead and several with gunshot wounds, AFP correspondents witnessed. A small girl who, according to the government, fell into a culvert when she was fleeing the violence, died during the protests.

At least five people were wounded by gunfire in Guinea's capital, Conakry, on Monday during violent opposition protests against the timing of elections, an opposition leader and a witness said. Some opposition supporters erected barricades and burned tyres on the streets of the seaside capital while youths fought street battles with the police and gendarmes.
Clashes broke out at midday between demonstrators and police in the suburbs of Conakry, with at least five civilians sustaining minor injuries, witnesses told AFP.
Security forces in Labe killed a protester and wounded four others, witnesses said Thursday, as opposition supporters clashed with police at anti-government rallies in its largest towns and cities.

More than 20 people were wounded Monday in clashes between anti-government protesters and police in Guinea, the opposition said, as the regime of President Alpha Conde clamped down on nationwide demonstrations. Clashes broke out between youths and security forces in the capital Conakry as demonstrators burned tyres and threw stones at police, who responded with tear gas, witnesses said. Further reports claim one person died from injuries sustained during the protest
Local media journalist Ibrahima Sory Diallo was seriously assaulted by police forces while covering a protest in Cosa

Guinean security forces on Thursday clashed with protesters in the capital Conakry who demanded a revision of an election timetable that they say stacks the odds in the regimes favour, an AFP journalist and witnesses said. Young men threw stones at the security forces, who responded with teargas in some areas.

column16: Media Foundation for West Africa; Aminata
column17: Anti-riot police in Guinea beat up Thierno Amadou Camara, the managing editor of the guineematin website on July 31 during a congress organised by the opposition Unity and Progress Party (Parti de lUnite et du progress-PUP)
Riot police in Guinea used tear gas to break up a rally on Saturday demanding the return of a former military ruler who wants to run for president despite facing charges related to a 2009 killing.

Split of 100 million GNF offered by Conde to Labe region for women and youth led to clashes in Dalein, Tountouroun and Mali communes. In Tountouroun, young people held local officials captive to get their right share of the money.

column7: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: In Kankan -- a town in Condes eastern support base -- government supporters threw stones to prevent a meeting arranged by Sidya Toure, another candidate and former premier

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Rival political factions clashed in northern Guinea, in the first violence ahead of the October elections. Rivals threw stones at each other in Koundara. Public and private property was ransacked. At least 17 were injured and 37 opposition members arrested, including some leaders who did not take part in the violence and called militants for calm instead.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Clashes between rival political factions took place in Enta in Matoto commune in Conakry; two people were injured and several arrested and freed a little later

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Opposition supporters clashed with activists from the ruling party in Nzerekore on 2 and 3 October leaving one person dead, at least 80 injured and significant material damage; the death toll was denied by Guinean officials. A curfew was imposed on the city

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Opposition supporters clashed with activists from the ruling party in Nzerekore on 2 and 3 October leaving one person dead, at least 80 injured and significant material damage; the death toll was denied by Guinean officials. A curfew was imposed on the city

column17: Arrests: Deputy Secretary General of Association of retired Servicemen and widows of Guinea arrested over planned protest to free the Secretary General arrested

column7: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party

column7: SNMRVG: National Union of Ex-Servicemen and Widows of Guinea
column17: Police forces dispersed protesters of Association of retired Servicemen and widows of Guinea with tear gas in Kaloum on 6 October

column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Clashes between opposition and ruling party supporters at a UFR rally in Kaloum. Some injuries reported

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: UFDG militants reportedly burnt several stores owned by RPG militants.

column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party; Police Forces of Guinea (2010-)
column17: Violent clashes between opposition and ruling party supporters killed two people in Conakry on Thursday. Police fired tear gas after people were wounded in the violence.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; Police Forces of Guinea (2010-)
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party; Police Forces of Guinea (2010-)
column17: Violent clashes between opposition and ruling party supporters killed five people in Banankoro on Thursday. Police fired tear gas after people were wounded in the violence.

column6: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column8: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Violent clashes between opposition and ruling party supporters lead to the fatal stabbing of a man.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Seven people were killed on 9 October in Banankoro district in clashes between opposition members and supporters of President Condes party

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Sonfonia was the scene of violent clashes between rival supporters which resulted in the death of one person

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Police allegedly fired on demonstrators of opposition and ruling party supporters who had been clashing since 8 October, killing one person

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Stores and cars belonging to UFDG supporters have been attacked by RPG militants in Tanene in Dubreka prefecture, causing some injuries.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Youth groups from rival political parties threw stones at each other around the private residence of UFDG candidate Diallo; riot police used tear gas to disperse them

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Violent clashes between police forces and youth in area known for UFDG support; part of the road between Bambeto and Cosa was closed by rioters. One UFDG militant was killed

Clashes between police forces and civilians as they were on their way to contest and negotiate with authorities over expanded gold mining in the area. At least 10 people were arrested, several people injured, and two police vehicles burnt down.
Women from the UFDG protested in Conakry against the detention of UFDG militants following election-related violence in Conakry earlier in October.

Over 150 women took to the streets over a video shared on social media which appeared to show a rape filmed by the attacker. They waved placards and chanted slogans such as ""Hands off my sister"" or ""halt to rape""
Riots following a motorbike accident that killed a young man. Angered youth burned down minibuses. Police forces used tear gas to disperse crowds. Many people were injured

column8: Police Forces of Guinea (2010-) Prison Guards
column17: At least a dozen inmates and guards were wounded during a riot at an overcrowded prison in Guinea's capital. Hundreds of police were deployed around and inside Conakry Civil Prison, from where gunshots were heard for at least two hours

column8: Police Forces of Guinea (2010-) Prison Guards
column17: Prisoners attempted to evade Siguiri prison; one of them died in fire exchanges with prison guards, and several others were injured

Two people were killed, many wounded and vehicles and buildings torched when rival groups clashed over the construction of a large mosque in Touba. 13 people have been arrested and two interior Ministers sacked for their bad handling of the deadly violence
Guinea has deployed dozens of security personnel to a northeastern gold hub after residents refused to leave to make way for a multinational mining operation.

column9: Prisoners (Guinea); Police Forces of Guinea (2010-) Prison Guards
column17: A mob lynched four men accused of the murder of a gold seller, after dragging them out of the prison where they were being held. One was burnt alive.

At least 17 people have been arrested and jailed in Kankan following tensions between civilians and a gold mining company. The police has been accused of brutality and of having fired live ammunition and wounded seven people.
Angry youth attacked an alleged robber who died of his wounds on 31 December in Koumbia in Gaoual prefecture.

column6: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column8: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Clashes between security guards of Cellou Dalein Diallo and Bah Oury at the Union des Forces Democratiques de Guinee (UFDG) headquarters.
Riot students burnt down two schools in Kankan. Police intervened to chase them.

column6: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column8: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Violent clashes erupted at the UFDG headquarters in Conakry between supporters of Bah Oury and those of Cellou Dalein Diallo as Bah was denied access to a political meeting. A journalist was shot in the clash.

column6: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Violent clashes erupted at the UFDG headquarters in Conakry between supporters of Bah Oury and those of Cellou Dalein Diallo as Bah was denied access to a political meeting. A journalist was shot in the clash; Cellou Daleins body guard succumbed of his wounds three months later.
Hundreds of people joined a march in Conakry Monday in memory of journalist El Hadj Mohamed Diallo who was shot dead last week in clashes outside the offices of an opposition party.
Youth blocked traffic and threw stones at police officers in Ratoma area of Conakry, in the context of a general strike called by trade unions. Police replied with teargas.

column7: USTG: United Trade Union of Guinean Workers; CNTG: National Confederation of Guinean Workers
column17: Youth blocked access to one main road in Conakry, in the context of a general strike called by the two main trade unions, USTG and CNTG. they clashed with taxi drivers and other public transport operators who forced their way through the erected barricades. Police intervened to disperse the youth. They arrested at least 16 trade unionists in the capital after the clashes.
Police arrested a man and severely beat him over three days at the Anti-Crime Brigade in Kipe, a neighbourhood of Conakry. He remained in detention at the end of 2016.

Police arrested eight suspected UFDG supporters in two neighbourhoods of Conakry for allegedly being involved in destabilising activities, including erecting barricades to block traffic, in the context of the two day strike launched by the party.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Supporters of former UFDG vice president Bah Oury beat and robbed UFDG leader Diallo in Bambeto.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Clashes between supporters of Bah Oury and Cellou Diallo following a meeting on national reconciliation in Bambeto seriously injured several people.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; Women (Guinea)
column17: Women from opposition party UFDG clashed with police forces when they were prevented from staging a peaceful protest in Conakry to denounce government injustice. The women reacted by preventing traffic on a nearby road.
Police fired tear gas in response to students throwing stones on school and police buildings in Kouroussa to protest against the arrest of an alleged student robber. Several students were arrested.

column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Several people were injured and some property damaged in Kerouane following clashes between protesters demanding the departure of the communes Mayor and supporters of president Alpha Condes Rally for the Guinean People Party.
Fishermen protested against the planned government privatisation of Boulbinet port in Kaloum commune.

column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: At least one person was injured in clashes in Kerouane between protesters demanding the departure of the communes Mayor and supporters of president Alpha Condes Rally for the Guinean People Party.
Sanitation workers protested in Labe against lack of income payment by their employer in a 10-days project.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: Opposition UFDG party supporters set fire to the motorcycle of an RPG supporter accused of spying during the burial of UFDG leader Cellou Daleins body guard in Bambeto.

column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: One person was shot and severely injured in clashes between opposition UFDG party supporters and police forces in Hamdallaye following the burial of UFDG leader Cellou Daleins body guard.

Siguiri commune Mayor Dr Traore was assaulted by supporters of his rival presiding the special delegation, leading to severe injuries, while his property was vandalized. This came amid tensions over management of the town council. Four of the suspected attackers were later arrested by the police.

Hundreds of people from the Djuwa pan-African organisation staged a peaceful demonstration between Taouyah in Ratoma commune and Dixinn in Conakry, to call for the creation of United States of Africa.

column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; Party for Renewal and Progress
column17: On May 27, at least 59 people were injured, including members of UFDG and the Party for Renewal, in Guinea when youths clashed with police. Security officials stopped ordinary people from entering a new mosque in Timbo to allow local dignitaries to pass but youths became angry and threw stones and attempted to rush in, witnesses said. Police responded with teargas and beat back the youths. [size=no report]
Youth went on rampage in Conakrys Simbaya neighbourhood after discovering the body of one of theirs.

22 people were injured, including five with bullet wounds, during clashes on 17 and 18 June between security forces and people demonstrating over the beating of a truck driver by soldiers in the northern city of Mali. Soldiers reportedly threw tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, while rioters vandalized 56 shops and cars, burnt down 37 motorcycles and killed livestock, leaving damages amounting nearly CFA 1 billion.

22 people were injured, including five with bullet wounds, during clashes on 17 and 18 June between security forces and people demonstrating over the beating of a truck driver by soldiers in the northern city of Mali. Soldiers reportedly threw tear gas to disperse the demonstrators, while rioters vandalized 56 shops and cars, burnt down 37 motorcycles and killed livestock, leaving damages amounting nearly CFA 1 billion.

column6: Military Forces of Guinea (2010-) Presidential Security Unit
column17: Presidential guards arrested, beat and threatened a journalist covering a meeting of the ruling party attended by President Conde in Conakry as he refused to hand over his camera. The police refused to record his complaint.
Military police officers arrested and severely beat a man in detention in Conakry, asking him to confess for a robbery he allegedly did not commit.

Residents of Magana and Linbana villages in Kinieran sub-prefecture, Mandiana prefecture, clashed over management of a mining site. Several people were shot and injured and two houses were burnt down. Kinieran sub-prefect was kidnapped and beaten by a group of rioters as they accused him of taking sides in the conflict. Police arrested and detained 28 suspects in relations to the event.

Residents of Magana and Linbana villages in Kinieran sub-prefecture, Mandiana prefecture, clashed over management of a mining site. Several people were shot and injured and two houses were burnt down. Kinieran sub-prefect was kidnapped and beaten by a group of rioters as they accused him of taking sides in the conflict. Police arrested and detained 28 suspects in relations to the event.

column7: F2DHG: Womens Development and Human Rights; Women (Guinea)
column17: Pita residents staged a peaceful march to protest against recurring rape cases and impunity for such crimes in the country. The march was organized by the Femmes, Developement et Droits Humains en Guinee NGO.

column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Arrests: Police arrested and briefly detained UFDG leaders Deputy political advisor in Matam for formulating threats against the president and national institutions during a speech at the UFDG headquarters a few days prior. He was provisionally freed on 5 August, upon the start of his trial.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: At least half a million Guineans from various opposition Guinean parties but led by the UFDG party, protested in Conakry from the suburbs to the 28 September stadium against economic mismanagement and corruption by the government of President Alpha Conde. Police allegedly fired tear gas and live ammunition to disperse the protesters, killing at least one person and injuring at least two others.
Boda boda riders protested in Conakry against the governments decision to forbid them from operating in the capital, riding from Ratoma commune to Dixinn.
Workers at the Rio Tinto mining industry demonstrated in Matam commune of Conakry against lack of indemnity over planned lay offs.
Workers at the Rio Tinto mining industry demonstrated for the second time in Matam commune of Conakry against lack of indemnity over planned lay offs.

column8: Police Forces of Guinea (2010-) Prison Guards
column17: 13 prisoners escaped from Pita prison after beating prison guards.

Residents of Coleyah Lanseboundji in Conakry staged a protest against electricity shortages for more than a week in the neighbourhood, setting up road blocks on Le Niger road. They threatened to rampage the offices of the national electricity company if no action had been taken in the next three days. Police intervened to disperse the protesters.
Residents of Tombo neighbourhood in Kaloum commune, protested against authorities bad waste water treatment, setting up road blocks on roads leading to the centre.

column7: FESABAG: Autonomous Trade Union Federation of Banks, Insurance and Micro-finance of Guinea
column17: Strikes: Workers in the banking, insurance and micro-finance sectors, led by the Federation Syndicale Autonome des Banques, Assurance et Micro-finances de Guinee (FESABAG), partially followed a nation-wide call for strike over working conditions.

Rioters in Gueckedou burnt and damaged several vehicles in protest against high levels of robberies in the town over the previous six months, asking to be brought three suspected robbers held at the police station at the time. Police reportedly intervened and used teargas to disperse the rioters.
Pilgrims protested against inability to access their packages back from their pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia by setting up road blocks on the highway to the international airport Conakry-Gbessia.

column7: USTG: United Trade Union of Guinean Workers
column9: CNTG: National Confederation of Guinean Workers
column17: USTG and CNTG supporters clashed in Paraya area of Labe over authorities approval of the building of a travel route by USTG to Dinguiraye, leaving several injured. Journalists from Espace FM who had gone to report on the clashes were reportedly physically and verbally assaulted by members of the CNTG.

column7: CNTG: National Confederation of Guinean Workers
column17: USTG and CNTG supporters clashed in Paraya area of Labe over authorities approval of the building of a travel route by USTG to Dinguiraye, leaving several injured. Journalists from Espace FM who had gone to report on the clashes were reportedly physically and verbally assaulted by members of the CNTG.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Clashes between UFDG and NFD supporters on the Hamdallaye-Bambeto axis in Ratoma commune, burning tyres on the road and disrupting traffic.
Dozens of gunmen, some in military uniforms, raided the residence Coyah prefect in the early hours of 24 November, leaving the prefect injured and his house looted.
Dozens of women protested at Bonfi neighbourhood in Matam commune to protest space distribution within the newly inaugurated Briqui Momo market. Authorities intervened to discuss with the women.
In strike action, miners have blocked the entrance to the Siguiri, 800 km from the capital

column9: Prisoners (Guinea); IMC: International Medical Corps; Aid Workers (Guinea); Health Workers (Guinea)
column17: A vigilante group storms the Sangardo gendarmerie in Kissidougou and lynches a group of three people earlier detained over the alleged kidnapping of a boy, including two workers from the International Medical Corps organisation, whom died during the attack.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Guinea (2010-)
column17: Several soldiers fired shots in the air in a military camp in Conakry in the night of 19-20 January, calling for better working and living conditions. Police arrested four end January, while authorities charged them with incitement to violence mid- March.

Angry secondary and high school students from three public schools in Kaloum ransacked the local education administration's offices, threw rocks at windows, burnt tyres, and confronted policemen at the local police station, protesting lack of teachers in their schools who have been boycotting classes in recent weeks.

Clashes between rioters and police forces on the Hamdallaye-Bambeto Cosa axis in Ratoma commune of Conakry. The youth erected barricades on the road, burnt tyres and threw rocks at police forces, while police fired tear gas to disperse them. The reasons for the riot are unclear.

column7: FPSE: Professional Union Federation of the Education Sector; SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: Strikes: Teachers led by the FPSE and SLECG syndicates renewed a strike action across the country calling for increased salaries and status changes. The strike was followed in many parts of the country, including Conakry, Siguiri, Kindia, Lab, Gaoual and Bok, where schools remained closed during the day.

Clashes between rioting high school/university students and army police in several parts of the capital, including along the Hamdallaye-Cosa axis over two days. The students were protesting teachers' absence in classrooms, setting up barricades, burning tyres on roads and throwing rocks at security officers. Security officers fired teargas in response. Authorities ordered the closure of all primary and secondary schools and universities in the country until negotiations with the teachers end.

Clashes between rioting high school/university students and army police in several parts of the capital, including along the Hamdallaye-Cosa axis over two days. The students were protesting teachers' absence in classrooms, setting up barricades, burning tyres on roads and throwing rocks at security officers. Security officers fired teargas in response. Authorities ordered the closure of all primary and secondary schools and universities in the country until negotiations with the teachers end.

Clashes between police/military police and rioting students across four of five communes of Conakry (including in Gbessia, Dabondi, Bonfi, and Kaloum) left five people shot dead, including one in Dabondi (Matam commune), one hit by a bus as he tried to flee the violence, more than 30 injured, and caused heavy material damage, including to health infrastructure. 32 people were arrested after riots over 20-21 February. Students were protesting school closure as a result of nationwide teacher strikes.

column7: FPSE: Professional Union Federation of the Education Sector; SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: Renewed protests by teachers led by their syndicates (FPSE and SLECG) in Labe calling for increased salaries and status changes.

Clashes between police/military police and rioting students across four of five communes of Conakry (including in Gbessia, Dabondi, Bonfi, and Kaloum) left five people shot dead, including one in Dabondi (Matam commune), one hit by a bus as he tried to flee the violence, more than 30 injured, and caused heavy material damage, including to health infrastructure. 32 people were arrested after riots over 20-21 February. Students were protesting school closure as a result of nationwide teacher strikes.

Clashes between police/gendarme forces and rioting students who had burnt tyres and erected barricades preventing circulation on roads in Conakry left two people killed. 32 people were arrested after riots over 20-21 February. The students were protesting the signing of an agreement between teachers' syndicates and authorities during riots the previous day.
Students from a private school in the capital marched to protest high school fees and teachers' absence in class.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Clashes between UFR and UDFG supporters as both parties were holding general assemblies in Conakry's Matam commune. Rioters threw stones, leaving at least 17 injured on UFR's side, and vandalized vehicles.

Clashes between police and angry protesters in Gueckedou following the condemnation of a former mayor in the area to three years' imprisonment over corruptions charges. The protesters set up barricades on roads and burnt tyres while police used tear gas to disperse them. At least one person was killed and another severely injured in the clashes.
Angry residents chased police to protest their late arrival at the scene of an armed robbery that left a person with a gunshot wound. Police fired shots in the air to disperse them.

The death of a boda rider in a road accident in Boke led to four days of riots by the town's residents, who set up barricades, burned tyres on the road and ransacked public and private properties in the town, including a major mining company. One person was killed and another 28 were injured in the violence when police intervened from the second day to disperse them. 20 were arrested by police. Other grievances were expressed by the rioters, such as high pollution levels and electric cuts, and lack of water and employment in the town.

The death of a boda rider in a road accident in Boke led to four days of riots by the town's residents, who set up barricades, burned tyres on the road and ransacked public and private properties in the town, including a major mining company. One person was killed and another 28 were injured in the violence when police intervened from the second day to disperse them. 20 were arrested by police. Other grievances were expressed by the rioters, such as high pollution levels and electric cuts, and lack of water and employment in the town.

The death of a boda rider in a road accident in Boke led to four days of riots by the town's residents, who set up barricades, burned tyres on the road and ransacked public and private properties in the town, including a major mining company. One person was killed and another 28 were injured in the violence when police intervened from the second day to disperse them. 20 were arrested by police. Other grievances were expressed by the rioters, such as high pollution levels and electric cuts, and lack of water and employment in the town.

The death of a boda rider in a road accident in Boke led to four days of riots by the town's residents, who set up barricades, burned tyres on the road and ransacked public and private properties in the town, including a major mining company. One person was killed and another 28 were injured in the violence when police intervened from the second day to disperse them. 20 were arrested by police. Other grievances were expressed by the rioters, such as high pollution levels and electric cuts, and lack of water and employment in the town.
Riots have spread in Boke on 1 May night: 3 dead, 10 wounded and many material damages. The accidental death of an individual pushed local youth to go to the street.

column7: FESABAG: Autonomous Trade Union Federation of Banks, Insurance and Micro-finance of Guinea
column17: Workers in the banking, insurance and micro-finance sectors, led by the Federation Syndicale Autonome des Banques, Assurance et Micro-finances de Guinee (FESABAG), went on unlimited strike to protest bank association refusal to negotiate on economic conditions. A short clash took place between labour union representatives and two representatives of BCIG trying to open the bank.

On 30 May 2017, a group attempted to revenge the death of a civilian by attacking taxi drivers and stoning their vehicles in Conakry (Conakry, Conakry), but police intervened to prevent further violence. [size=no report]
Clashes between two families of Bankoumana in Kondianakoro commune over a suspected land issue left 2 injured.
Clashes between populations of Djilengbe 2 in Kandianakoro commune and populations of Faragbekoro in Balandougouba commune over a suspected land issue.
Unidentified assailants murdered a man over a suspected land issue in Kondianakoura district, 3km from the centre
People demonstrated against the lack of electricity in the neighbourhood of Dar es-Salam.
Youngsters were demonstrating in front of the parliament claiming the dismissal of the new civil code prohibiting polygamy.
Workers demonstrated against mining companies .
Women blocked off the Bambeto-Kipe route to protest against the lack of electricity in the neighbourhood of Koloma.
Riots erupted to denounce the lack of electricity. Rioters attacked the police station and sacked, while one person was killed in the clashes against police.
Faranah's youth demonstrated against the EDG (Electricite de Guinee) protesting the long delay in providing the new transformer.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Clashes are reported between presidential and opposition supporters.
An unauthorised demonstration ended up with the arrest of a reggae artist (Elie Kamano) and other three people. Teargas were used to break up the crowd.
Opposition demonstration in Sangoyah, Matoto area of Conakry.
Opposition demonstration in Nango area of Conakry.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: UFDG supporters protested against Alpha Conde's regime ahead of a meeting to be held by the party at its HQ, calling for new local elections.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Thousands of opposition party supporters led by UFDG's Cellou Dalein Diallo held a republican march through Ratoma and Dixinn communes up to a stadium in Conakry against Alpha Conde's regime. They denounced attempts to review the Constitution to allow the president to prolong its mandate and called for the planning of new local elections.
Youngsters attacked the Foumbadou police station: local inspector was heavily wounded, and several motorcycles were seized.

On Tuesday and Wednesday, people went to the street to protest the lack of water and electricity. The clashes between rioters and police forces resulted in several material damages to property, a police station plundered, ammunitions and weapons seized. 2 civilians and one soldier dead and 41 wounded.

On Tuesday and Wednesday, people went to the street to protest the lack of water and electricity. The clashes between rioters and police forces resulted in several material damages to property, a police station plundered, ammunitions and weapons seized. 2 civilians and one soldier dead and 41 wounded.

Armed youths in Guinea destroyed the offices of the ruling party and occupied parts of the restive mining town of Boke on Friday, witnesses told AFP, following the deaths of two protesters this week. The youths controlled entire sections of the northeastern city by early evening after erecting barricades, with local officials and soldiers alike sheltering in military barracks, the witnesses and a local official said.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Tens of thousands of people demonstrated in Conakry, on the appeal of the opposition, to demand the organization of local elections which have not held place for 12 years. Two people were wounded by bullets and a young protester was shot dead by police on his way back home after a UFDG demonstration.

Following ten days of violent demonstrations against the lack of electricity in the mining region of Boke, people burnt down public buildings in the near city of Kolaboui and blocked the terrestrial and rail communication routes. Police used teargas to disperse the crowd.
Following this week events, youngsters blocked ""Le Prince"" highway .
People took the street and erected barricades on the main road to protest the lack of electricity.
The funeral march of the two victims of police violence was the occasion for opposition leaders to protest police violence during demonstrations.
Youth erected barricades on the streets of Sangoya to protest authorities' refusal to collect trash in the city.
People went to the streets protesting the lack of water supply. Some youngsters burned tires and blocked the access to Fidel Castro highway. Police intervened to disperse the crowd.
Regime opposition members went to the streets.
Opposition supporters went to the street to demonstrate against the government.
Youngsters blocked the access to the Le Prince highway and burned some tires within the framework of demonstration against the government.
Youngsters took the street to protest the infrastructural shortcomings on the Kankan - Kerouane axis.
Three police agents were wounded by protester denouncing the non-respect of government's agents. Several demonstrators were wounded and other were arrested.
A religious chief was killed by an individual of Telemele province.
A rumour about the death of President Alpha Conde has resulted in a violent clash between gendarmes and journalists. 12 journalists were injured, their equipment and objects damaged.

Several hundred journalists demonstrated against violence against a dozen of their colleagues last week by gendarmes and denounce the lack of support from their supervisory authority, said an AFP correspondent.

People protesting against power and water cuts ransacked the gendarmerie, the police premises and looted the residences of the director of the mine, Sekou Berete, as well as the head of the laboratory of the hospital of the Company of the Bauxites of Guinea (CBG), according to the same sources

Two young people, who were protesting against power and water cuts, were wounded by gunfire Saturday in Guinea in the mining town of Sangaredi (north-west) during clashes with police, it was reported, during violent clashes that broke out between hundreds of excited young people and police, also making about 20 minor injuries since Friday. A gendarme on the phone also reported two of his comrades ""injured by young people who use slingshots"".

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: Two days of clashes between young protesters and police in Conakry over the state of education, which claimed the lives of two teenagers on Monday and Tuesday. At least 15 people were injured. Young people burned tires, dumped garbage cans and clashed with police with stones and slingshots.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: Two days of clashes between young protesters and police in Conakry over the state of education, which claimed the lives of two teenagers on Monday and Tuesday. At least 15 people were injured. Young people burned tires, dumped garbage cans and clashed with police with stones and slingshots.
Thousands of people including Guinean civil society actors and deputies of the National Assembly protested Tuesday in Conakry against the inhuman trafficking and slavery of blacks in Libya.

Amid suspension of classes by teachers demanding salary increases, clashes erupted in several neighbourhoods of the capital Conakry. Young people threw stones at the home of the Minister of National Education, Ibrahima Kalil Konate, and were repulsed by gendarmes.

22 people were killed and several others injured in clashes between gold miners on the Mali-Guinea border. Malian gold miners, assisted by Malian gendarmes, who attacked the Guinean gold miners at a mine in the village of Faranokho.
An Ivorian student was shot dead following a possible police blunder in Conakry during student protests against teachers' strike.
Guinean women trade unionists organized a peaceful march to mark the international day of the fight against gender-based violence instituted by the United Nations

The NGO ACIC action against illegal immigration held a peaceful march in Labe. Objective: To denounce the slavery of Guinean nationals in Libya and to demand employment for young people so that they can settle down.
Local sources tell us that angry students demonstrated peacefully this Saturday to denounce a screaming lack of teachers at Filira de Boke High School in Lower Guinea.

Angry young people denouncing false promises of the Guinean government were dispersed by police a few meters from the presidency of the Republic of Guinea. According to our informants, protesters denounced the non-compliance with the commitment of rejuvenate and feminize the administration.

A dozen youngsters barricaded the secondary road that connects the Fidel Castro Highway to Carriere neighbourhood, in the commune of Matam. They protested against the electric shedding and the lack of water in their locality.
Youngsters blocked the Bambeto-Cosa axis to protest against the lack of electricity.
A Saudi preacher was shot dead. The murderers have not been identified, but a security source suggests he had conducted a ""preach that was not in the taste"" of a part of the local population.

Several Islamist clerics dressed in white demonstrated in the street shouting the slogan ""Allahou akbarou"". They gathered in Sekou Commissioner Mosque to take a decision against the assassination of the Saudi in a village of Mandiana back from a sermon.

Hundreds of people attended a commemoration of the mass murder in 1971 under the regime of Guinea's first president Sekou Toure. The demonstrators, dressed in red in mourning, then visited the ex-camp Boiro, prison symbol of repression under Sekou Toure, where a reading ceremony of the Koran was organized for ""the rest of the soul of the disappeared "".

column7: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: The RPG seat was surrounded by a group of young people protesting the missing payment of bonus activities against some party officials.
A moto thief was lynched by the crowd.
Following the election day, dozens of shops and houses were looted and burned by alleged opposition supporters.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Following election-related violence, opposition party supporters clashed with security forces, one dead.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Following election-related violence, huts and houses were set on fire in the central town of Kalinko. Five infants died in an incident that was apparently deliberate.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; Students (Guinea)
column17: Following election-related violence, a 23-year-old student named as Mamadou Diakouane Diallo also died from wounds sustained in gunfire in a Conakry suburb.
Following the election day, dozens of shops and houses were looted and burned by alleged opposition supporters.

column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: Clashes were reported between UFDG supporters and a group of people targeting the residence of the former prime minister Cellou Dalein Diallo. Several people wounded.
At least two men died in clashes between demonstrators and riot police, following protests over local election results and the resumption of a teachers' strike.
Following teachers' strike, youngsters protested the absence of teachers' from schools: several people were arrested after they clashed with security forces.
Following teachers' strike, youngsters protested the absence of teachers' from schools: gunfire shots were heard.

A policeman died from a head wound on Monday sustained as people protested over delayed local election results in Guinea and teachers went on strike over pay. Thousands of young people have been demonstrating in the Guinean capital, Conakry, over the failure to announce results to the February 4 election, while a teachers' strike has also entered its second week.
Youngsters demonstrated as the prefect closed the route that passed through the airport's track. Police intervened to allow the closure of the track.

Teachers are on strike while the opposition is still challenging the results of the 4 February communal elections with a call for a 'dead city'. At least one person was shot dead and several others injured during clashes between law enforcement agencies and young demonstrators in Conakry, in the Hamdallaye suburb, traditionally an opposition stronghold.
Following the closure of the track, a hundred women marched towards the prefecture. Policemen blocked the demonstration and dispersed it.
The funeral of a young demonstrator (killed on 26/02) became a march (though peaceful) against the government.

5,000 women, clad in white, marched in protest at a violent crackdown on political demonstrations following elections last month. Dressed in the local colour of mourning, they took part in the three-kilometre (two-mile) march.
On 12 March 5, Dozes were beaten up by rioters, 3 of them were arrested, 2 could run away.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; Students (Guinea)
column17: On 12 March, in the framework of a dead city day, students gathered outside the presidential palace, chanting anti-Conde slogans and demanding an end to a separate school strike and the publication of local elections' true results.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; Journalists (Guinea)
column17: On 12 March, groups of youths destroyed the windows of the vehicles parked in the Espace FM radio property.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On 13 March, clashes between protesters and policemen in Conkary. People were protesting against the crisis in education. Young people erected barricades in the city, burned tyres and threw stones at police, who replied with teargas.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On 14 March, three young men were killed by police forces in less than 24 hours in Ratoma commune, during a dead city day to protest the crisis in the educational sector and election's forgery. 3 policemen were wounded. Shots fired by police were heard overnight.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; Women (Guinea)
column17: On 15 March, women supporting opposition went to the street to protest the killing of young opposition members by police forces.

column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On 19 March, a UFDG politician was killed by unknown armed men in Sinta.
On 20 March, a woman received a gunshot wound from a policeman in Ratoma while preparing food in her home. Circumstances unclear. Dead city initiatives were ongoing.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On 20 March, following the ""dead city"" initiative, youth set up barricades and threw rocks at the police in Sonfonia. Police fired teargas.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; Women (Guinea)
column17: On 21 March, a demonstration organised by opposition women against the post-electoral violence was dispersed by policemen in Conakry, preventing them to do the planned sit-in.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On 22 March, policemen dispersed oppositions protesters who burned up objects on their way in Conakry. 4 policemen wounded, a police station burned, some weapons were seized by protesters
On 28 March, opposition women went to the streets in Conakry to protest police violence and killings of opposition supporters.
On 16 April, clashes on property issues between villagers of Kinienkoura and Koundianakoro, Mandiana, resulted in several wounded.
On 16 April, moto-taxi men clashed in Siguiri, as some of them wanted to open a new moto-taxi office. 15 wounded (10 severely).
On 18 April, moto-taxi men and police forces clashed in Siguiri, as a moto-taxi office was ordered to close by authorities.

""Recently"" (report dated 22 April), a number of demonstrations against power cut in Conakry took place, with people often blocking routes and burning tyres. The Minister of Energy denounced these practices as politically motivated.
On 25 April, two killers were lynched by local crowd in Tonson, Doko.
On 28 April, an alleged moto thief was lynched by an irate crowd in Gueckedou, Forest Guinea.
On 29 April, the attempt of evicting a family from its residence triggered clashes between locals and police. One civilian dead and several wounded.

column9: UGTG: General Union of Guinean Workers
column17: Arrests: On 8 May, the secretary-general of the UGTG was arrested and taken to the Conakry Central Prison. He is accused of organising an illegal public rally.
On 10 May, clashes erupted in Sackodou, Maleyah between Foulata and Saraya people over the possession of an acajou plantation. Gendarmes were deployed to stop the clashes.
On 14 May, opposition supporters set up barricades in Matoto and Ratoma, Conakry, as talks with the government failed.
On 14 May, opposition supporters set up barricades in Matoto and Ratoma, Conakry, as talks with the government failed.

On 14 May, clashes broke out between communities of Kigneba and Nafadji districts in Bankon sub-prefecture, Siguiri. The gold mine of Sanan is at the centre of these acts of violence. One person was killed and many injured.
On 31 May, women of the Matoto market took the street to protest the arrest of one of them, following a situation with a Minister's wife, preventing access to the Fidel Castro highway.
On 5 June, demonstrators went to the streets to protest waste in their neighbourhood.
On 10 June, angry people set fire to a police vehicle in Yimbaya, Matoto, following an accident between policemen and a bike rider
On 11 June, people from Kokoun and Sanafara clashed in Kegnebakoura commune: several people were wounded by gunshots.
Month of June. Security forces attack civilians by firing live rounds at civilians, killing 2 and injuring 10 others.

column7: Serifoula Communal Militia (Guinea); Lamia Communal Militia (Guinea)
