column17: On 17 June, clashes between villagers from Fissaya vs Heremakono, Serifoula and Lamia erupted around some land issues in the Dabola prefecture. 3 dead and several wounded.
Around 25 July, people in Ratoma, Conakry demonstrated to get their neighbourhood connected to power.
""One male national UN contracted driver was ambushed near Yende in Kissidougou, and seriously injured by the unknown armed perpetrators.""
On 1 July, people in Sonfonia, Conakry demonstrated to get their neighbourhood connected to power. They erected barricades to block traffic on the roads.
On 4 July, demonstrators and police forces clashed in Bambeto, Ratoma, during the dead city day.
On 4 July, demonstrators against the fuel price hikes set up roadblocks to block the route in Labe.

On 9 July, protesters against fuel price hikes threw rocks at police in Kissosso, a southern suburb and blocked some of the main roads; riot police responded with teargas. A three-day strike was organised to protest the fuel price hike.
On 10 July, people took the street in Conakry to protest against fuel price increase. Some burned tires and barricaded some streets.
In the week of 9 July, unidentified men killed a merchant in his boutique in Siguiri. Circumstances unclear.
On 13 July, a crowd of angry residents attacked and looted the house of an army officer. The army officer killed one of the rioters and was subsequently detained by security forces.
On 14 July, armed clashes took place between inhabitants of Niandakoura and Kissakolen in Siguiri over a gold-mine, leading to one death. Another body was found several days later in the same area.

On 16 July, civil society activists blocked the roads to enter Mamou city after a protest march due to take place had been postponed. The protest march should have taken place to enter a 3-day phase of strikes in the whole city.
On 15 August, people from Koromadou and Loylakoro villages clashed in Mandiana, Kankan, over the property of some gold mines. 8 people wounded.
On August 24, citizens of Mbonet district, Banora sub-prefecture, demonstrated against the alleged appropriation of 10% of local revenues from gold extraction by local authorities.
On September 20th, a police station was set on fire by an unknown armed group.

On September 14th, young people protested in Mandiana in Kankan against empty presidential promises and the isolation of their prefecture following the deterioration of infrastructure. The police fired live ammunition at the demonstrators. At least one protester was shot dead and a dozen wounded.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On September 19, around 200 people led by the UFDG demonstrated in Conakry to show their support the president of the Guinean Constitutional Court, Kelefa Sall, disavowed by other magistrates of this body.

On Sept 27, protesters demonstrated in Conakry in support to the president of the Guinean Constitutional Court. Police forces responded with violence, firing tear gas and beating people with their guns, fists and boots. At least five people were injured, including a member of the liberal bloc.
On Oct 16 a 22-year-old man was killed during a demonstration in the capital city Conakry. He was shot dead by the police.
On 21 October 2018, residents demonstrated in Conakry city (Kaloum, Conakry) to demand fair elections. The police forces fired tear gas to disperse them. [size=no report]

column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On Oct 23, as UFDG leader Cellou Dalein Diallo left his home in Conakry to join his supporters to protest the municipal elections, Diallo claimed that police fired tear gas and gunshot to prevent him from leaving, claiming an assassination attempt. Diallo's driver was injured. The police denied that they were the ones who fired the gunshot.

On Oct 23, UFDG supporters rioted in Conakry to protest the municipal election results. They set up barricades in the streets, set tires on fire and clashed with the police. One person was killed and another 30 were injured.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On Oct 24, UFDG supporters rioted in Labe after UFDG leader Cellou Dalein Diallo said his car was hit by gunfire a day earlier in Conakry. They set up barricades and burned tires on several main routes in Labe and clashed with police. 30 injured.
On Oct 29, in Lansanaya dam and Dabompa in Matoto commune, students protested against a teacher strike.
On Oct 29, students protested against a teacher strike along the Bambeto-Cosa axis.
On Oct 29, students protests in Kaloum to demand that teachers end their strike. Police fired gunshots and teargas and engaged in running battles with the students to disperse them.
On Oct 29, students protested against a teacher strike in Conakry.
On Oct 29, students protested against a teacher strike in Kipe, Ratoma. They were dispersed by police.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On Oct 30, youth in Sonfonia rioted in response to a call by the UFDG leader to protest, burning tires and setting barricades on the roads. They threw stones at the police officers deployed to disperse them.
On Oct 30, students demonstrated against a teacher strike in Tougue.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On Oct 30, police opened fire to prevent a march near the home of Cellou Diallo in Conakry. A protester was killed and several others injured.
On Oct 31, students demonstrated in the city of Kankan after the arrests of ten unionists. They were then dispersed by the police.
On Nov 1, women protested in the city of Commune against a teacher strike. The police used teargas to dispersed the protests.
On Nov 1, a women protest was prevented by the police in Conakry.
On Nov 4, an unknown armed man entered a nightclub in Labe and started shooting. There were some injuries.
On Nov 5, Kankan inhabitants barricaded the road to protest against the prohibition for heavy vehicles to circulate in their district.
On Nov 5, teachers went on a peaceful march to express their dissatisfaction with the salary freeze in Lelouma.
On Nov 5, teachers demonstrated in front of the premises of the Prefectural Directorate of Education (DPE) to claim their salaries in Forecariah

column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On Nov 7, reports of clashes between police and UFDG supporters on the margins of a call for a dead city day in Conakry.

column9: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On Nov 7, soldiers killed two young men suspected of being part of the opposition in Conakry. The attack occurred on the margins of clashes between UFDG rioters and police in the context of a dead city day call in the capital.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On Nov 8, opposition activists marched in Koya against the assassination attempt of the opposition leader, the killings of opposition activists and the violation of political agreements.
On Nov 8, youth protesters set barricades in Bambeto-Cosa axis.

On Nov 8 and 9, mass police deployment in Wanindara in Conakry and retaliatory attacks against civilians. Several people were injured with gunshot wounds, some men and women were abused, and goods looted.

column7: Vigilante Group (Guinea); UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: On Nov 8, a policeman was killed from mob beatings after the death of two young men the day before in Wanidara district in Conakry.

On Nov 8 and 9, mass police deployment in Wanindara in Conakry and retaliatory attacks against civilians. Several people were injured with gunshot wounds, some men and women were abused, and goods looted.
On Nov 13, women protested in the city of Conakry against Police violence that killed two men the previous week. Protests were dispersed by the police.
On Nov 13, Guinean police arrested 25 people in the Wanindara suburb of the capital, Conakry. Wanindara was the scene of violence and police crackdowns last week.
On Nov 15, two bullet wounds were reported during opposition protests. The rioters clashed with the police in Hamdallaye.
On Nov 15, opposition groups marched in Bambeto. The protest was dispersed by the police that used tear-gas.
On Nov 16, some youth clashes with the Police in Bambeto.
On Nov 19, students erected barricades at Tombola Cite on the Fidel Castro Highway, Matoto Commune (Conakry), to denounce the recent insecurity in the country.
On Nov 19, youths erected barricades on the road for 6 hours to challenge the state on insecurity in the country, especially in the capital. Police used tear gas to disperse the protesters.
On Nov 22, police dispersed a movement of protesters against insecurity in the country on the Hamdallaye-Cosa axis.
On Nov 22, dozens of teachers staged a sit-in in front of the Ministry of Education and Literacy and walked to the Primature. Police dispersed them with teargas.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: On 25 Nov 2018, teachers from SLECG union started a two-day sit-in in front of the Primature in Kaloum Commune. They demanded the un-freezing of their wages and opening of negotiations for higher salaries.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea; Students (Guinea)
column17: On 26 Nov 2018, teachers, parents and students have joined in a sit-in organised by the union SLECG in Lelouma. The protesters demanded the un-freezing of teachers' wages and resumption of classes.

On 26 Nov 2018, armed men burst into the home of the publishing director of Guinea Times and Africa Times in Taouyah area of Ratoma Commune, Conakry. Several members of the journalists' family were wounded.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: On 26 November, teachers from SLECG union staged the second day of their sit-in in front of the Primature of Kaloum Commune. They demanded the un-freezing of their wages and opening of negotiations for higher salaries. The police dispersed the protest with teargas near Kaloum court. Six people were arrested.

On 26 November, students from Kaloum Commune/Conakry resumed their protests, demanding the return of teachers into classrooms. Classes have been suspended due to the teachers' strike since 3 Oct 2018. The police dispersed protesters by tear gas.

On 27 Nov 2018, students aged 7 to 12 went to Dubreka prefecture to demand the return of teachers to classrooms. The protest was peaceful. Many classes have been suspended since the teachers' strike was launched on 3 Oct 2018.

column7: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: On 27 Nov 2018,, two rival groups of RPG youth clashed in Siguirini. A total of eight people were wounded, four from each group.

On 27 Nov 2018, students from Kountia high school of Maneah rural commune in Coyah prefecture staged a protest demanding the return of teachers into classrooms also denouncing the arrest and conviction of protesters, particularly in Conakry and Labe.
On 27 Nov 2018, women of the Republican opposition staged a protest in Ratoma Commune against the killings of members of the opposition in Conakry.
On 28 Nov 2018, residents of Sonala and Sananfra villages of Kignebakoura sub-prefecture, Siguiri clashed over disputed land. Eight men of Sonala were allegedly wounded by bullets.
On 29 Nov 2018, Around 500 opposition supporters staged an anti-government protest in Conakry city centre. The police used batons and fired teargas to disperse the protest. Four people were wounded.
On 29 Nov 2018, students blocked off several city roads of Nzerekore town, protesting against teachers' strike launched on 3 Oct.

On 3 Dec 2018, unknown perpetrators threw stones at the Hoggo Mbouro school complex in Labe, disrupting classes. The disturbance happened a day after the meeting of teachers affiliated with the SLECG trade union, which launched teachers' strikes on 3 Oct.
On 3 Dec 2018, students took to the streets in Kaloum Commune in protest against teachers' strikes launched on 3 Oct, demanding the return of qualified teachers. Police dispersed them with teargas.

On 3 Dec 2018, students from Africof de la Carriere college in Bonfi, Matam Commune took to the streets in protest against teachers' strike launched on 3 Oct, demanding the return of qualified teachers.

On 4 Dec 2018, students barricaded Fidel Castro Highway at Bonfi (Bonfira), Conakry in protest against teachers' strikes launched on 3 Oct. The students also burned tyres and launched projectiles. They were dispersed by the police who used teargas.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea; Labour Group (Guinea)
column17: On 4 Dec 2018, members of the SLECG teachers' union and supporters staged a sit-in at Pita town in protest against the freeze of their salaries and suspension of several teachers affiliated with SLECG.

During the week of 3-9 Dec 2018, an armed man opened fire in a night club in Fello Kahi locality of Dara Kethioun, Dara-Labe, Labe as he allegedly wanted to discourage the operation of the club. The assailant was arrested by the police.
On 5 Dec 2018, supporters of the Bloc liberal staged a hunger strike along the Leprince highway in Ratoma, Conakry against the crisis in the education sector and closure of classes.

On 5 Dec 2018, a young mechanic was beaten and kidnapped by men who could have been the police at Madina market in Conakry. The victim's brother was allegedly complicit in the kidnapping as the latter owed the victim money.

On 10 Dec 2018, female teachers supported by mothers demonstrated in Kaloum against the freezing of teachers' salaries, threats of dismissals and absence of teachers from schools. The protesters were dispersed by the police with teargas.
On 10 Dec 2018, parents of students marched on Fidel Castro highway in Bonfi, Matam commune in support of striking teachers.

On 13 Dec 2018, a peaceful march of the Republican opposition escalated when government forces [assumed police] dispersed them with teargas in Conakry. Clashes erupted between demonstrators and government forces near the residence of the former prime minister. Several people fainted due to the excessive use of teargas.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: December 15. SLECG teachers protest in Boke to demand government negotiations, with young people associated with the march near the central Boke market throwing stones at police. Police end the march by using tear gas.
December 17. Around 50 women from Fanafanako protest in front of Siguiri administrative office over the government response to a land dispute resulting in 11 people being wounded.
17 December. A woman is abducted by an unidentified armed group and found dead two weeks later, on 2 January, at Bantighel near Pita.
December 18. Secondary school students from Kipe riot, blocking roads in Ratoma commune by burning tires, demanding the return of striking teachers. Police intervene to end the riot.

column7: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: December 19. RPG-Rainbow supporters rallied in the streets of Matoto to install their candidate for mayor, despite his loss to UFDG opponent, Kalemodou Yansane. Police intervened to clear the RPG supporters.

December 20. Young protesters assembled in front of the USA embassy in Conakry denouncing the arrest in the USA of the son of former Guinean President Sekou Toure, Mohamed Toure, accused of enslaving a girl in Texas.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea; Labour Group (Guinea)
column17: December 24. Around a hundred teachers burn tires in the streets in protest against their low salaries and are then dispersed with tear gas by police.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: December 24. Supporters of Kalemodou Yansane clash with police in Matoto near the main town hall in Yimbaya, Conakry in an attempt to install Yansane as mayor. Rioters are dispersed by tear gas.
December 26. A journalist accused of criticising Guinean executives is assaulted by an unidentified armed group in Bambeto.
December 26. Young people riot in Kintinian by barricading doors to several government offices, demanding the removal of the youth sub-prefectural director. Police intervene and make several arrests.
December 27. Women protest in Kagbelen area of Conakry against the insufficient supply of power and water to the neighbourhood.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: 31 December. SLECG members protest in Boffra, with clashes reported after police attempted to disperse the demonstration in the streets. Some police reportedly injured.
31 December. Young people riot in Doko of Kankan against the installation of Sekou Keita, burning tires, destroying property, and setting fires. Several arrests and injuries were reported.
31 December. Young people riot in Siguirini of Kankan against the installation of Sekou Keita, burning tires, destroying property, and setting fires. Several arrests and injuries were reported.
31 December. Young people riot in Norassoba of Kankan against the installation of Sekou Keita, burning tires, destroying property, and setting fires. Several arrests and injuries were reported.
02 January. Female supporters of mayor candidate Kalemodou Yansane protest the election, demanding Yansane hold office.
03 January. Moto drivers protest in the streets of Labe demanding they are able to hold an elective congress.

04 January. Dozens demonstrate in Conakry outside the American embassy demanding the release of Mohamed Toure, son of former Guinean President Sekou Toure and his wife, who are in jail in the USA for forced labour and illegal accommodation charges.
04 January. Unidentified armed group attack the Kassonyah and Maneah communes of Coyah, killing one person and raping another. Fatality recorded in Maneah.
04 January. Unidentified armed group attack the Kassonyah and Maneah communes of Coyah, killing one person and raping another. Fatality recorded in Maneah.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea; Labour Group (Guinea)
column17: 07 January. SLECG protesters organized a demonstration in front of the director's office of prefectural education in Lola against frozen wage salaries in an ongoing strike across the country.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea; Labour Group (Guinea)
column17: 07 January. Police fired teargas as SLECG protest in Bonfi on the Fidel Castro motorway

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: 07 January. Protesters, ""militants"" of the UFDG, led by MP Bakary Keita demonstrate in front of the Ministry of Territorial Administration and Decentralization in favour of their candidate for mayor. Protesters were dispersed with tear gas and 8 were arrested by police.
10 January. Students demonstrate in Telimele of Kindia over the lack of teachers and breakdown of SLECG and government negotiations. Rioters threw stones at buildings and clashed with police.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea; Labour Group (Guinea)
column17: 10 January. SLECG and government negotiations fail over salary discussions, leading to riots in Labe with stones thrown at schools and other students. Police intervene to disperse the rioters.
12 January. Unidentified armed group attacks two young men, shooting one in the leg and stealing their possessions in Daka neighbourhood of Labe.

14 January. Protesters gather outside the Russian embassy in Matam following the statement of Russian ambassador to Guinea in favour of a constitutional amendment. They are quickly dispersed by police.
15 January. Unknown gunmen fired shots at a taxi on the RN3 road from Conakry to Boke at Tanene, injuring a passenger.
19 January. Guinean mathematics researcher, Sambegou Diallo, is attacked by three men in police uniform near his home in Sangoya. The police handcuff, beat and take the possessions of the researcher.
Weekend of January 19-20. Military forces and police forces of Guinea clash with one another in Dubreka over territorial authority on the edge of the city.

21 January. Students riot in several areas of Mamou city over planned examinations, destroying property at a private school and clashing with police by throwing stones. Police disperse the students with tear gas and some injuries were reported after police beat students on school property.
23 January. Dubreka community members riot over the negative effects of granite mining, blocking roads and burning the government offices. The rioters were eventually dispersed by police.
Night of 24 January to 25 January. Some soldiers and a civilian attempting to steal weapons from a military base in the suburbs of Conakry are caught and arrested.
28 January. Contract and substitute teachers protest in Conakry over the proposed examinations for their teaching positions.

column7: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea; Teachers (Guinea); Labour Group (Guinea); Students (Guinea)
column17: 28 January. SLECG teachers, students and parents protest in Tougue, beginning at the SLECG headquarters, over abuse of power by Prefectural Director of Education, Mamadou Traore.
28 January. Young people protest in Kankan over government delays following votes for the communal council. Police briefly intervenes in the protest.
29 January. Young people in Nongo area of Conakry protest over electrical load shedding, blocking streets before being dispersed by police.
02 February. Sidikila and Kignenkoura village members clash in Mandiana over a gold mine, killing 6 people and injuring others as a part of an ongoing conflict between the two villages.
08 February. Students of Lansana Conte in Labe protest for the return of their director of studies.

column7: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: 13 February. Rainbow RPG youth riot near the town hall in Norassoba of Siguiri, resulting in infighting amongst members of the Rainbow RPG, the burning of a home and arrests by police. Several injuries reported.

Month of February. Police forces evict civilians from a settlement in Kaporo area of Conakry, with reports of officers beating, wounding and attempting to rape civilians during the process. Date unknown.
Month of February. A government minister is assassinated in Conakry by an armed group comprised of a Sierra Leonean, Liberian, Nigerian and Guinean.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: 16 February. UFDG supporters of Dalein Diallo demonstrate in the streets around Bambeto, with police intervening near the crossroads of Casseur. Police intervene with tear gas and batons to disperse the UFDG supporters.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: 17 February. UFDG supporters of former PM Cellou Diallo riot in Conakry following police and gendarmerie disrupting a support rally. UFDG supporters threw rocks at security forces, who used tear gas and batons, injuring 27 of the UFDG members. [size=Over 30]
18 February. Young people in Dabola of Faranah protest in the streets against the lack of water and electricity. Police intervene to disperse the protest and make arrests.
19 February. Young people in Dabola of Faranah protest for a second day in the streets against the lack of water and electricity. Police intervene to disperse the protest and make arrests.
23 February. Young people in the UFR party protest in Conakry against the replacement of Baidy Aribot as Executive Secretary of Political Formation.

25 February. Young people riot by damaging vehicles and buildings at the Prima Centre in Ratoma following an eviction operation at the Koloma Directional Center. Police and gendarme intervene to end the riot. [size=no report]
08 March. A women's group protest for a new constitution during International Women's Day marches in Conakry at the People's Palace. [size=no report]

12 March. Residents of the Transversale 2 area of Conakry riot due to the government destruction of homes, raising barricades and burning tires on the roads, disrupting traffic on the Bambeto-Kipe road. Clashes with police and gendarmes reported [size=no report]

12 March. Students and supervisors of El Hadj Djiba Konate institute protest against working conditions at the facilities in Dabadou of Kankan. Police arrest the principal of the school after demonstrators surrounded a vehicle. [size=around one hundred]

column9: COPAM: Coordination of the Parties Allied to the Movement
column17: 14 March. Supporters of constitutional changes to allow President Conde to continue for a third term face protesters against these changes at the Palace of the People in Conakry. [size=around one hundred]

15 March. Riots continue over evictions in Kaporo Rails area of Conakry. Young people erected barricades, threw stones at police and burned tires. Police intervened and dispersed the demonstration. [size=no report]

column7: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party; Womens Group (Guinea)
column17: 16 March. Protesters with the RPG and other women's groups, as well as counter-protesters from UFR, demonstrate in Kankan concerning a third presidential term. [size=no report]

20 March. Moto taxi drivers riot outside the gendarmerie building in Dubreka of Coyah-Centre after a youth is found with the motorcycle of a recently killed moto taxi driver. Gendarmerie disperse the crowds with live rounds, killing a young student. [size=no report]
21 March. Young people from Ratoma neighbourhood protest in Conakry to demand the removal of their neighbourhood chief. [size=no report]
22 March. A military vehicle hits and kills 2 civilians, causing a riot by local residents who burn the vehicle in Lansanaya Barrage neighbourhood of Conakry.

25 March. Kolomo 1 residents protest and disrupt traffic due to ongoing evictions and demolition of the neighbourhood in Ratoma area of Conakry, with gendarmerie intervening to stop the protest. [size=no report]

On March 29, youths in the village of Kouyeya pillaged and ransacked the home of a Fulani family , the incident came against the background of accusations targeting the Fulani alleging that they are not rightful landowners.

column7: URTELGUI: Union of Free Radio and Television of Guinea; Journalists (Guinea)
column17: 02 April. Protesters demonstrate in Conakry of Kaloum against the imprisonment of the director of Conakrylive.info, Lansana Camara. After the demonstration, the journalist was released. [size=no report]

column6: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column8: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: 06 April. Two rival divisions of Rainbow RPG members clash in Tokounou outside Kankan, using firearms against one another. One person was killed and others wounded in the fighting.

06 April. Protesters demonstrate in Dubreka of Coyah-Centre against supporters of a third term by the incumbent Alpha Conde, police intervened with tear gas to disrupt the protesters. [size=no report]

07 April. Local officials, women and youths riot in Kouremale of Siguiri over a land dispute between Kouremale and Kolenda, killing a policewoman during the intervention. Gendarmerie make arrests and disperse the demonstration. [Size=several]
08 April. Young people riot at the Gbessia bridge in Matoto of Conakry over poor service of garbage collection, blocking traffic and erecting barricades on the road. [size=no report]
08 April. Residents in Kamsar riot by barricading streets and the train line over lack of public water and electricity services. Police intervene to disperse the demonstration. [size=no report]

column9: SLECG: Free Union of Teachers and Researchers of Guinea
column17: 10 April. Students riot over the SLECG strike, by throwing stones at police and blockading the streets in Conakry. Police fire tear gas at protesters to disperse the demonstration. [size=no report]
11 April. Young people protest against a third term for Alpha Conde in Tanene of Dubreke, carrying banners on motorcycles and cars in the streets. [size=no report]
11 April. Residents of Kankan of Kankan-Central protest to demand the installation of N'ko script in the formal education system. [size=nearly a thousand]
11 April. Citizens of Kolaboui of Boke demonstrate over poor provision of public distribution of water and electricity. Rioters burn buildings as part of the demonstration. [size=no report]
15 April. A civilian is attacked by suspected military forces in Mangata of Wonkifong, tying him and dragging him on the ground. Reasons unclear.

16 April. Riots break out between farmers and pastoralists in Lola of Nzerekore after a farmer was found dead following a dispute with a pastoralist grazing oxen on his field. One person is killed in the riot before gendarmes disperse them. [size=no report]
24 April. A soldier raped a woman in Popodara, Labe.

column8: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: 26 April. Armed independent political party members clash with RPG supporters due to divided support of the mayor in Koumana. Four people were killed and others seriously injured during the fighting.

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: 03 May. RPG and FNDC members violently demonstrated against one another in Kouroussa, Kankan. [size=no report]

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: 04 May. FNDC protesters against the third term of Alpha Conde demonstrate in Kindia city, with police making several arrests. [size=no report]
06 May. Contract teachers protest at the Ministry of National Education in Conakry against the conditions of their employment with the government. [size=several]
06 May. Contract teachers protest against their conditions of employment with the government in Labe. [size=480]

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea
column17: 06 May. Residents of Lombonna district of Labe protest to demand changes to UFDG head of district position, as the current head of district is out of the country for medical treatment. [size=no report]

07 May. Residents of Matam of Conakry riot by erecting barricades and lighting fires in the streets due to poor service provision of electricity. Police intervene to disrupt the demonstration. [size=no report]
Week of 08 May. Residents of Kolaboui of Boke riot due to poor service provision of electricity. Police intervene to disrupt the demonstration. [size=no report]
Week of 08 May. Residents of Kamsar of Boke riot due to poor service provision of electricity. Police intervene to disrupt the demonstration. [size=no report]
Week of 08 May. Residents of Boke of Boke-Centre riot due to poor service provision of electricity. Police intervene to disrupt the demonstration. [size=no report]
08 May. Residents of Bonfi in Matam riot against public provision of electricity and water, with reports of rioters fighting with police. [size=no report]

09 May. Residents in Heremakonon and Sankoumbaya areas of Conakry riot by constructing barricades and burning tires on the Fidel Castro highway against public provision of water and electricity. Police forces intervene to disperse the demonstration. [size=no report]

12 May. Residents of Kindia riot over lack of electricity, with gendarme soldiers dispersing the rioters with tear gas. Several soldiers were wounded by rioters during the demonstration. [size=several]

13 May. Women protest in Fria of Baguinet demanding the prefect steps down, with military forces intervening to disperse the protesters with tear gas and stones. Several protesters wounded following the intervention. [size=no report]

14 May. Women protest in Fria of Baguinet demanding the prefect steps down, with military forces intervening to disperse the protesters with tear gas and stones, with increased violence occurring on this day. Several protesters and a journalist wounded following the intervention. [size=no report]

15 May. Women and youth riot in Fria of Baguinet demanding the prefect steps down, with military forces intervening to disperse the demonstration with tear gas. Rioters throw stones at security forces and erect barricades on the roads. Several protesters wounded following the intervention. [size=no report]

19 May. Rioters block roads, dump garbage, throw stones and burn tires in Bonfi area of Matam commune of Conakry against cuts to electricity. Police forces disperse the rioters with tear gas. [size=no report]

20 May. Rioters block roads and burn tires against electricity shedding in Dabondy rails area of Matoto commune of Conakry. Police intervene by firing live rounds as warning shots to disperse the demonstration. [size=no report]
23 May. Rioters burn tires and clash with gendarme forces in an effort to stop demolition of homes in a landfill of Dar as Salam in Madina-Oula. [size=no report]
30 May. Students protest against a university decision at Labe University. [size=no report]

31 May. Students riot against a university decision at Labe University, throwing stones at security forces and school administration, as well as barricading roads. One student is killed by gendarme forces, school property is destroyed and both students and gendarme soldiers are injured in the riot. [size=no report]
06 June. Gendarme forces beat and kill a civilian during drug patrols in Kankan.
06 June. Protesters demonstrate against gendarme forces after the killing of a civilian in Kankan. [size=no report]
10 June. A soldier and a gendarmerie raped a young girl in Labe.

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column9: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column17: 13 June. FNDC members demonstrated in Nzerekore against a third presidential term, which led to violence with RPG members, as well as police forces who intervened. One person was killed, 32 were injured, 38 people were arrested, and many buildings were vandalized. [size=at least 40]

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: 16 June. FNDC members protest against a third presidential term in Yimbaya of Matoto. Police forces intervene by making arrests and using tear gas to disperse the demonstration. [size=no report]

19 June. Young people demonstrated in Yomboya area of Boke, creating road barricades and hitting civilians with sticks. The demonstrators were angry with poor government provisions of electricity. [size=at least 400]

22 June. Youths demonstrated by constructing barricades and burning tires in Conakry against ongoing electricity shortages. Police forces intervene with tear gas to disrupt the demonstration. [size=no report]
25 June. Gendarmerie forces looted property from a school under construction in Kobaya area of Conakry.

26 June. Demonstrators erected barricades and blocked roads in Matoto Commune, Conakry over lack of electricity provision. Police and gendarmerie forces intervened with tear gas to disperse the demonstrators. [size=no report]
29 June. Young people protested in Kankan against lack of electricity and theft of fuel, gathering near the electricity headquarters. [size=many]

05 July. Students demonstrated over scholarship funds by building barricades and blocking traffic near Julius Nyerere University in Kankan, with police and gendarme intervening to disperse the demonstration. A journalist was beaten by police forces during the intervention. [size=no report]
08 July. Sub-contractors demonstrated against lack of salary payments by building barricades and blocking streets in Siguiri, Kankan. [size=hundreds]
08 July. Fishermen protest in Kaloum, Conakry against new regulations of fishing. [size=no report]
11 July. Cotton workers protested over salaries by blocking entrance to the factory and turning off the generators in Kankan. [size=60]
14 July. Protesters demonstrated in the streets of Briqueterie area of Kankan against the poor quality of roads. [size=no report]
16 July. Protesters demonstrated in Kankan against the lack of electricity provision. [size=100]
26 July. Protesters demonstrated near the French embassy in Conakry against the killing of Mamoudou Barry. [size=dozens]
31 July. A group of women demonstrated against the lack of infrastructure in the Lero, Siguiri. [size=massive]

01 August. A group of women and young people demonstrated against lack of infrastructure for a second day where they destroyed buildings of the mining department. Police intervened by using tear gas and making arrests. 5 were injured in the demonstration. [size=no report]
04 August. The leader of the Liberal Block political opposition group, Faya Millimouno, was arrested by police in Conakry and held for several days, suspected as a method for intimidation.
23 August. A group demonstrated in Boffa, Boke against the appointment of a government prefect by barricading the streets and blocking traffic. [size=no report]
26 August. Journalists demonstrated in front of the High Authority for Communication in Conakry against the detention of two journalists from Radio Lynx and for freedom of journalists. [size=dozens]

27 August. Women and young people demonstrated by blocking roads with tables and disrupting traffic at the Sonfonia market in Conakry against the market management. Police intervened by firing tear gas to disrupt the demonstration. [size=no report]
02 September. A group of young people demonstrated against police forces after the killing of a civilian, by blocking roads and clashing with police. [size=no report]

On September 11, 2019, two groups of violent demonstrators supporting various political parties (further information not provided) clashed during meeting about the revision of Guinean Constitution. [size=no report]
On September 12, 2019, There was a violent demonstration against the firing of 7 employees of the Anglogold Ashanty mining company in Siguiri. [size=no report]

column7: USTG: United Trade Union of Guinean Workers
column17: On September 12, 2019, two camps of USTG rioters clashed during a protest in Mamou. Police Forces of Guinea intervened making use of teargas.

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On September 17, 2019, youths of the FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution blocked a road and demonstrated to prevent a group of supporters of the revision of the Constitution from holding a meeting in Boffa. [size=no report]
On September 19, 2019, Police Forces of Guinea (2010-) intervened in Macenta to stop a concert that was starting in protestation against the revision of the Constitution. [size=no report]
On September 24, 2019, a group of people protested in Siguiri against the decision of the mayor to subdivide the District of Dankakoro. [size=no report]
On October 3, 2019, a group of protesters staged a protest in Kerouane, against the revision of the constitution. [size=no report]
On October 7, 2019, a Gendarmerie patrol killed one young man in Sonfonia, as he was attempting to escape an arrest.

On October 8, 2019, a group of angry youths protested against the killing of a one young man by a Gendarmerie patrol the day before. The Gendarmerie intervened firing teargas at the protesters. [size=no report]

column7: CNTG: National Confederation of Guinean Workers; Labour Group (Guinea)
column17: On October 11, 2019, the CNTG and an independent union of carriers clashed in Kankan after suspected members of the CNTG stoned their vehicles of the rival union that they accuse of refusing to join a large regional station located in the Airport district.
On October 12, 2019, a group of youths threw stones at the Police officers in Conakry, as they tried to arrest one of them. The Police replied firing tear gas at the demonstrators.

column9: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On October 12, 2019, 7 leaders of the FNDC and members of the civil society were arrested in Conackry after they called for demonstrations against a possible revision of the constitution.

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On October 14, 2019, members of the FNDC clashed with the Police in Kindia, as they were demonstrating against a possible revision of the constitution.
On October 14, 2019, members of the FNDC barricaded roads and burned tyres in Lelouma as they were demonstrating against a possible revision of the constitution. [size=no report]

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On October 14, 2019, the Police intervened to disperse a protest of members of the FNDC that was gathering in Boke, against a possible revision of the constitution. [size=no report]

column7: RPG: Rally for the Guinean People Party
column9: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On October 14, 2019, Police Forces and some members of the RPG political party ransacked the headquarters of the UFR political party as the members of the FNDC were preparing for a protest in Kankan.

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On October 14, 2019, members of the FNDC set fire to an armed post (PA) of Guinean Police in Koloma, as they were demonstrating against a possible revision of the constitution.

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On October 14, 2019, one person was killed in Cosa, as the Police intervened during a protest against a possible revision of the constitution. [size=no report]

column7: FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On October 14, 2019, violence broke out between Police Forces and young supporters of the FNDC in Yimbaya, after the rioters erected barricades in the process of a demonstration against a possible revision of the constitution.

column17: On 19 Feb. 2020, supporters of the FNDC demonstrated in several neighbourhoods of Conakry city (Kaloum, Conakry) against the revision of the constitution and a possible third term of the President. column16: Africa Guinee; Aujourd'hui (Guinea); Guinee Matin; Guinea News; Guinee 7; AFP; Xinhua; Kaba Bachir; Africa 1
column17: On 26 March 2020, the government of Guinea declared the state of health emergency to combat the coronavirus for 30 days, banning gatherings of more than 20 people, and closing places of worship for 14 days. This measure was reinforced on 30 March, by a curfew from 9 p.m to 5 a.m.
On 28 March 2020, residents demonstrated in Labe town (Labe-Centre, Labe) against the results of 22 March constitutional referendum. [size=no report]

On 3 April 2020, residents of Sofenidou village engaged in fire fights with residents of Niagassola village (Siguiri, Kankan) over a land dispute. The fight involved firearms, leaving 5 people severely injured.

On 3 April 2020, residents demonstrated in Dubreka town (Coyah, Kindia) after they found out that at least 7 shops were robbed during the first night of coronavirus related curfew. Some demonstrators accused the police patrols of perpetrating these robberies. The police forces intervened and fired tear gas to disperse the demonstrators who replied with stones. Several demonstrators were reportedly injured. [size=at least several]

On 4 April 2020, for the second day in a row, residents of Sofenidou village engaged in fire fights with residents of Niagassola village (Siguiri, Kankan) over a land dispute. The fight involved firearms, resulting in 5 people severely injured.
On 4 April 2020, residents captured and beat a person to death in Boke town (Boke-Centre, Boke). The victim was accused of stealing. [size=no report]

On 5 April 2020, police forces in charge of enforcing the coronavirus curfew attacked a house in Koundara town (Koundara, Boke). They beat up and severely injured the head of family and damaged several belongings.

On 5 April 2020, for the third day in a row, residents of Sofenidou village engaged in fire fights with residents of Niagassola village (Siguiri, Kankan) over a land dispute. The fight involved firearms, resulting in 5 people severely injured.

On 6 April 2020, for the fourth day in a row, residents of Sofenidou village engaged in fire fights with residents of Niagassola village (Siguiri, Kankan) over a land dispute. The fight involved firearms, resulting in 5 people severely injured. The security forces (assumed Police Forces) intervened to settle the situation.
On 6 April 2020, a several youths demonstrated in Koundara town (Koundara, Boke), against police violence during the enforcement of coronavirus curfew measures. [size=several]

On 7 April 2020, military forces in charge of enforcing coronavirus curfew measures attacked one house in Kankan town (Kankan-Centre, Kankan). They beat up and severely injured several people, damaged several belongings, and reportedly took away goods.

column7: UFDG: Union of Democratic Forces of Guinea; FNDC: National Front for the Defense of the Constitution
column17: On 8 April 2020, supporters of the FNDC, and UFDG (opposition) party demonstrated in Koundara town (Koundara, Boke) after gendarmerie forces arrested a local leader of the party. The leader was subsequently released. [size=no report]

On 9 April 2020, a group of farmers destroyed grazing fields belonging to herdsmen in Yende and Kondiadou villages (Kissidougou, Faranah). The reason of this incident is unclear. The gendarmerie forces intervened and arrested at least 12 perpetrators. [size=at least 12]
On 9 April 2020, several shop owners accused military forces in Nzerekore town (Nzerekore-Centre, Nzerekore) of breaking into and robbing their shops during the coronavirus curfew.

On 11 April 2020, several farmers demonstrated in front of the gendarmerie post in Kissidougou town (Kissidougou, Faranah), to demand the liberation of 12 farmers arrested two days before for destroying grazing lands. The gendarmerie forces fired tear gas to disperse them. [size=several]

On 12 April 2020, residents of Kambalia village clashed with residents of Wondeleya village in Kindia subdivision (Kindia-Centre, Kindia) over a land dispute. The security forces (assumed Gendarmerie Forces) intervened to arrest suspected perpetrators of property destruction during the clash, but residents of Kamabalia opposed those arrests, resulting in clashes with the gendarmes who made use of tear gas. Two people were killed during the intervention. [size=no report]
On 13 April 2020, military forces reportedly beat up two suspected violators of the coronavirus curfew in Coyah town (Coyah-Centre, Kindia).

On 14 April 2020, workers of the Diamond Cement mining company demonstrated in Sougueta town (Kindia-Centre, Kindia) against what they say was the unfair dismissal of about 143 workers 'due to the coronavirus crisis'. [size=no report]

As reported on 15 April 2020, unidentified individuals threw stones at a gendarmerie patrol in charge of enforcing the counter coronavirus curfew measure in Kissidougou town (Kissidougou, Faranah). [size=no report]

On 15 April 2020, unidentified individuals threw stones at a gendarmerie patrol in charge of enforcing the counter coronavirus curfew measure in Siguiri town (Siguiri-Centre, Kankan). One gendarme was injured, and the patrol vehicle damaged. [size=no report]

As reported on 16 April 2020, security forces (assumed police forces) reportedly attacked several bakeries in Conakry city (Kaloum, Conakry), beating up and injuring several people, as they were enforcing the coronavirus related curfew.

On 16 April 2020, military and gendarmerie forces fired tear gas to disperse a market in Sagale village (Lelouma, Labe), as gatherings were banned in order to combat the coronavirus. Several people were injured and others arrested. Several stalls were destroyed.

column16: Guinee Matin; Africa Guinee; Aminata; Guinea News
column17: On 17 April 2020, taxi bike drivers clashed with communal security guards in charge of preventing anarchic parking in Labe town (Labe-Centre, Labe). One person was injured. The police forces intervened and made use of tear gas to disperse the rioters. [size=no report]

On 18 April 2020, workers of the China Gold Exploration mining company demonstrated in Tinkolen village, Siguiri subdivision (Siguiri-Centre, Kankan) to denounce their working conditions, and demand the dismissal of an HR officer. [size=no report]

On 19 April 2020, security forces (assumed Police Forces) in charge of enforcing the coronavirus curfew reportedly beat up and injured several curfew violators including women in Lola town (Lola, Nzerekore).
On 20 April 2020, several youths demonstrated in Boffa town (Boffa, Boke) against lack of electricity. [size=several]

On 20 April 2020, a group of students demonstrated in front of the Chinese Embassy in Conakry city (Kaloum, Conakry), against xenophobic violence targeting African students accused of spreading coronavirus in China, and to denounce the Guinean government's inaction. [size=no report]
On 21 April 2020, scores of youths demonstrated in Faranah town (Faranah-Centre, Faranah) against a lack of electricity. [size=scores]

On 21 April 2020, hundreds of taxi bike drivers demonstrated in Labe town (Labe-Centre, Labe), against a decision of the authorities to ban parking in several places where they use to park before. [size=hundreds]
On 23 April 2020, residents demonstrated in Kangoleah village in Dubreka subdivision (Coyah, Kindia) to demand the dismissal of the newly appointed officer of the prefecture. [size=no report]
On 24 April 2020, suspected police forces looted a shop during the counter coronavirus curfew in Conakry city (Kaloum, Conakry).

On 27 April 2020, a group of taxi bike riders threw stones at two soldiers, injuring them in Nzerekore town (Nzerekore-Centre, Nzerekore). This happened after an accident of a taxi rider and his passenger as they tried to escape the soldiers who wanted to arrested them for not wearing counter coronavirus masks. [size=no report]

On 27 April 2020, the police forces beat up and arrested 13 people in Bonfi neighbourhood of Conakry city (Kaloum, Conakry). They also damaged a house and forced 6 women among those arrested to work in the police station. The reason of this incident was not reported.

On 28 April 2020, residents demonstrated in Labe town (Labe-Centre, Labe), against the arrest of 4 retired military officers accused of building speed bumps on a main road without due authorisation. [size=no report]

They threw stones, damaged a military truck and freed 23 quarantined workers. [size=no report]

Police were present against the demonstrators and in the process of intervening killed a civilian who was walking by the demonstration on his way home from a soccer game. [size=no report]

column16: Guinee Matin; Africa Guinee; Le Djely
column17: On 2 September 2020, unidentified individuals poured excrements and burned copies of the Quran in 6 mosques in Kankan town (Kankan-Centre, Kankan). They also destroyed some goods.

column17: On 16 October 2020, soldiers opened fire in Samoreyah and Keme Bourama military camps of Kindia town (Kindia-Centre, Kindia), killing the Samoreyah camp commander, and injuring several soldiers. They also attacked the local prison, injuring a prison guard and freeing several prisoners. Some sources say it was a revolt against the mismanagement of bonuses of soldiers deployed at UN peacekeeping missions. The military forces intervened to settle the situation, and reportedly arrested 10 of the mutineers, killing 3, and losing one man (total of 5 fatalities).

column17: An unidentified armed group attacked a police station in Abidjan, killing one prisoner. The offices of the Brigade were destroyed and several vehicles burnt. One guard was wounded (Agence France).

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Motivated by a soldiers injury to an Abidji civilian during a personal dispute, a mob of Abidji townspeople from Sikensi attacked a military barracks, killing two soldiers.
Following violence the previous day, Malinke and Abidji groups battled with stones and machetes in Sikensi. Two youths died over two days.
Following violence the previous day, Malinke and Abidji groups battled with stones and machetes in Sikensi. Two youths died over two days.

Demonstrators from both the pro-Gbagbo Coalition of Young Patriots for Peace and Reconciliation and a youth group supporting Ouattara protested together against violence committed in recent attacks from unidentified armed groups on military barracks and police stations. The two groups advocated for peaceful reconciliation.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Movement of forces: Joint deployment of Ivoirian and Liberian military to the countries border began. The deployment is an effort to quash insurgent cross-border attacks from pro-Gbagbo Ivoirians and Liberian mercenaries hiding in Liberia. Military patrols will last until Jan. 3 and involve 1,600 Ivoirian troops as well as 414 Liberian soldiers. Military will patrol Ivoirian territory between the towns of Tai and Toulepleu, and along the Cavally River.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: An attempt to seize a police headquarters, the largest in Abidjan, occurred following two attacks on security posts the previous week. Forty people from the headquarters were arrested for purposes of investigation.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Security Measures: Security controls heavily intensified in response to recent attacks on Abidjan military and police bases. Electricity cordons, night patrols, bans on fireworks, and reinforced local squadrons began Dec. 18 but intensified particularly during the Christmas holiday, and in anticipation of New Years.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: 10 soldiers heavily beat a transgendered prostitute after attempting to extract bribes from a group of prostitutes in which she was found. Human rights abuses against sex workers by the army regularly occur.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Report of the harassment and torture by military personnel after he filmed their attempt to extort passengers on a minibus on his mobile phone

Protests against an Indian-owned manganese mine demonstrated against destructive mining practices by forming a barricade against the passage of mining workers. The rioters threw rocks and assaulted the workers, killing three, before police intervened.

Pirates seized a Panamanian vessel as it was preparing to deposit 5,000 tons of jet fuel cargo at the Ivory Coast port of Abidjan. None of the 16 Nigerian crew members, who were locked up in a dining room while the hijackers looted the boat, were injured.
At least one died in a land conflict between two unidentified communal groups inhabiting the classified forest of Blolequin. Three were wounded. Xinhua later reported three dead.
At least three were wounded in a land conflict between two unidentified communal groups.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: A military troop pursuing a recalcitrant soldier who siphoned a large sum of money from his former base clashed with the military post housing the soldier in Angre. Gunfire erupted but none were reported injured or killed.
Armed men robbed two Senegalese boutique owners in Yamoussoukro, killing one.

column7: FPI Youth: Ivorian Popular Front Youth Faction
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Police in Ivory Coast fired tear gas to disperse a march by supporters of the country's former President Laurent Gbagbo. Fifty young people shouting ""Free Gbagbo"" were pushed back while they tried to charge a barrier set up by police, who fired tear gas and caused the protesters to disperse before they reached Yopougan square, in a part of Abidjan that has long been a pro-Gbagbo stronghold.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Confrontations erupted in the village of Affery, between an angry crowd and military forces accused of extortion. At least one villager was killed when security forces fired on an angry mob beating a soldier who allegedly demanded taxes from business owners in the village.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Confrontations erupted in the village of Affery, between an angry crowd and military forces accused of extortion. A second villager died and three were injured as clashes continued early on Monday morning.

Some 200 victims of the post electoral violence of 2010-2011 demonstrated in Abidjan to demand justice from the International Criminal Court on the last day of the courts hearing to confirm charges against former President Laurent Gbagbo.
A conflict between farmers and herders resulted in at least one death in Bako (north), said inhabitants.

column17: Gunmen from Liberia carried out an attack against a village in western Cote dIvoire, near Toulepleu.

Workers at the Ministry of Economy and Finance and the Budget engaged in a short work stoppage, which was suspended at 12pm although it was meant to last for three days.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Gunmen attacked a military post in Sikensi, seriously injuring one FRCI soldier before retreating into the bush.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

column7: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Police dispersed a protest by about 30 young PDCI supporters in which they attempted to block access by the leaders of PDCI to their HQ. column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

column7: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Protests over soldiers pay spread to Bondoukou. Soldiers protesting regarding a pay dispute fired their weapons in the air. The protesters are believed to be primarily former rebels integrated into the army.

column7: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

About 50 soldiers also took over the state TV and radio station in order to broadcast a message, but the workers fled. The protesters are believed to be primarily former rebels integrated into the army.

column17: Protests over soldiers pay spread to Abengourou. Soldiers protesting regarding a pay dispute fired their weapons in the air. The protesters are believed to be primarily former rebels integrated into the army.

column17: Unarmed soldiers protesting over a pay dispute blocked traffic in Abidjan. The protesters are believed to be primarily former rebels integrated into the army.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Police used tear gas and beat a crowd of water sellers who organized a protest against a ban on plastic bags. One was injured and several detained.

Several hundred young people rioted Nov.27-28 after the suspicious death of a friend of theirs while in police custody. They looted police and gendarmerie buildings.

A group of wives of prisoners arrested during the 2010-2011 post-election crisis demonstrated in front of the Ivorian Ministry of Justice, two days after beginning a hunger strike. to demand the release of their husbands who they say are held under inhumane conditions. Their husbands in jails around the country also started a hunger strike at the same time.
Residents of villages in the Jacqueville area, including the Adoukro, Sassko, Abrebi and Avagou villages, among others, have engaged in two days of protest against the subdivision of Adoukro village.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Men in military uniforms attacked a police station, causing several injuries. They are believed to be demobilized soldiers.

column7: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

Between 200 - 300 Muslims protested against the recent French publication Charlie Hebdos caricatures of the prophet Mohammed. The protest caused traffic jams but ended quickly and peacefully.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

The sit-in had initially been organised by the Alliance of Democratic Forces (AFD) but postponed for security reasons following its prohibition by officials.

Several isolated incidents were reported on the day of voting for a new Constitution project, which the opposition called to boycott, in Gagnoa, Divo, Alepe, Bangolo, Duekoue and Yopougon in Abidjan. FPI opposition supporters damaged the electoral material.

Unknown group threw rocks at opposition Front du Refus supporters attending a rally by the coalition in Yopougon, leaving more than 10 injured, including several seriously.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Clashes between youth and police forces in Yamoussoukro, as youth members attacked the Dioulabougou police post, burning tyres on the road to prevent reinforcements to come in, after a man died in a police raid the day before.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Clashes between youth rioters and members of the military's Gendarmerie in Niamoin locality in Bouna left four people killed, including two soldiers.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Clashes between populations and members of the military's Gendarmerie in Doropo department after the death of two civilians during a raid by the security agents. Two gendarmes were killed in the clashes.

column7: RENADVIDET-CI: National Network for the Defence of the Rights of Toxic Waste Victims in Ivory Coast
column17: Nearly 100 victims of toxic waste, represented by the National Network for the Defence of the Rights of Toxic Waste Victims in Cote d'Ivoire (RENADVIDET-CI), protested in front of the United States embassy in Abidjan and renewed an unlimited hunger strike demanding the resumption of indemnity payments and the issuance of arrest warrants against several officials from the association of victims with which the indemnity funds were entrusted. Previous such strikes were launched over the past few months.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Unknown gunmen killed two members of the Gendarmerie in Gbanhui as they were patrolling on the Bondoukou-Bouna axis.
military officers from Guinea have attacked the village of Kpeaba in the Ivory Coast and have killed one person.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Ivorian soldiers stage a mutiny in six towns in Ivory Coast (Bouake, Daloa, Daoukro, Korhogo, Odienne and Man) and take control of the towns by blocking road access, firing sporadic gunshots and reportedly forcing loyal forces to flee their posts. The mutineers are calling for better working conditions, including higher salaries, bonuses, and better career opportunities.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

The mutineers are calling for better working conditions, including higher salaries, bonuses, and better career opportunities.

The mutineers are calling for better working conditions, including higher salaries, bonuses, and better career opportunities.

The mutineers are calling for better working conditions, including higher salaries, bonuses, and better career opportunities.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
