The mutineers are calling for better working conditions, including higher salaries, bonuses, and better career opportunities.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Ivorian soldiers' mutiny expands to Akouedo military camp in Abidjan and other areas where roads are blocked and shots fired, and continues in Bouake, where they briefly detain the Minister and its delegation at the sub-prefect's residence during negotiations, and fired shots in the air. A deal is reached but re-discussed later the following week.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Ivorian soldiers' mutiny expands to Akouedo military camp in Abidjan and other areas where roads are blocked and shots fired, and continues in Bouake, where they briefly detain the Minister and its delegation at the sub-prefect's residence during negotiations, and fired shots in the air. A deal is reached but re-discussed later the following week.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Mutineering soldiers fire shots in the air and force shops to close in Daloa as the deadline for implementation of the deal nears.

column8: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Mutineering soldiers disperse a protest by around 200 people in Bouake calling for an end to their revolt. A deal is reached between the soldiers and the government later that day.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-); Journalists (Ivory Coast)
column17: Mutineering soldiers block roads leading to Bouake while negotiations are ongoing with authorities at the prefect's residence, fire shots in the air near the residence and force journalists gathered there to leave. A deal is reached between the soldiers and the government later that day. The day before, they fired shots in the air in the town during the night and morning to put pressure on authorities as the deadline for implementing the deal approached.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Mutineering soldiers block roads into Korhogo while negotiations are ongoing with authorities in Bouake. A deal is reached between the soldiers and the government later that day.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Gunfire is heard at two military camps in Abidjan (Akouedo and Gallieni) as mutineering soldiers reportedly seek to remove soldiers from their posts, but also at Odienne and Bondoukou. Negotiations were taking place at the same time with authorities in Bouake.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Gunfire is heard at two military camps in Abidjan (Akouedo and Gallieni) as mutineering soldiers reportedly seek to remove soldiers from their posts, but also at Odienne and Bondoukou. Negotiations were taking place at the same time with authorities in Bouake.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Gunfire is heard at two military camps in Abidjan (Akouedo and Gallieni) as mutineering soldiers reportedly seek to remove soldiers from their posts, but also at Odienne and Bondoukou. Negotiations were taking place at the same time with authorities in Bouake.

Generalized communal clashes between Malinke and Abbey communities in Azaguie, Agboville department, in January left one person killed. The clashes followed rivalry between two men of each community over a girl.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column9: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column17: A group of mutineered soldiers abducted a pro-government coalition (RHDP) member in Bouake after criticising their revolt the week before. He was released later that day.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Mutiny of soldiers raided an armoury at a training academy in Yamoussoukro and the following day drove through the streets firing shots in the air, forcing many businesses to close down and stealing vehicles. Later, they clashed with soldiers from the Republican Guard, leaving four killed, including two who died of their wounds.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Presidential Security Unit
column17: Mutiny of soldiers raided an armoury at a training academy in Yamoussoukro and the following day drove through the streets firing shots in the air, forcing many businesses to close down and stealing vehicles. Later, they clashed with soldiers from the Republican Guard, leaving four killed, including two who died of their wounds.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Mutiny of soldiers raided an armoury at a training academy in Yamoussoukro and the following day drove through the streets firing shots in the air, forcing many businesses to close down and stealing vehicles. Later, they clashed with soldiers from the Republican Guard, leaving four killed, including two who died of their wounds.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Mutiny of soldiers and gendarmes in several towns of Ivory Coast (including Daloa, Man, Dimbokro, Bondoukou and Bouake), with soldiers driving through the towns in pick ups, firing shots in the air. These soldiers were not involved in the deal reached between mutineers and the government the week prior. In Bouake the Gendarmes' base was surrounded by the former mutineers.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Mutiny of soldiers and gendarmes in several towns of Ivory Coast (including Daloa, Man, Dimbokro, Bondoukou and Bouake), with soldiers driving through the towns in pick ups, firing shots in the air. These soldiers were not involved in the deal reached between mutineers and the government the week prior. In Bouake the Gendarmes' base was surrounded by the former mutineers.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Mutiny of soldiers and gendarmes in several towns of Ivory Coast (including Daloa, Man, Dimbokro, Bondoukou and Bouake), with soldiers driving through the towns in pick ups, firing shots in the air. These soldiers were not involved in the deal reached between mutineers and the government the week prior. In Bouake the Gendarmes' base was surrounded by the former mutineers.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Mutiny of soldiers and gendarmes in several towns of Ivory Coast (including Daloa, Man, Dimbokro, Bondoukou and Bouake), with soldiers driving through the towns in pick ups, firing shots in the air. These soldiers were not involved in the deal reached between mutineers and the government the week prior. In Bouake the Gendarmes' base was surrounded by the former mutineers.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Gunfire heard at a Gendarmes' base in Abidjan's Abobo district.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: A mutiny of gendarmes occupied the port of Abidjan calling for the same benefits as those received by former rebels who mutinied the week before, firing shots in the air which closed access to the port and forced businesses to shut down.

column7: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Veteran soldiers blocked the main northbound highway to Abidjan, erecting barricades, asking for payment of arrears as the ones obtained by mutineers in the previous weeks. At the same time, angry firemen blocked circulation in a neighbourhood of the capital, over unclear reasons.

Hundreds of schoolchildren blocked traffic and protested in Bouake to show their support to teachers who launched a strike action on 9 January for better working conditions, and call for classes to resume.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Clashes between soldiers and schoolchildren in Bangolo as students blocked circulation and ransacked public administration offices in the town to protest lack of teachers in classrooms. The teachers launched a strike action on 9 January calling for better working conditions. At least five people were injured in the clash.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Angry special forces soldiers fired their weapons in Tengrela over pay.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Angry special forces soldiers fired their weapons and blocked roads in Adiake over pay. At least two people were injured by strayed bullets.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Angry special forces soldiers fired their weapons and blocked roads in Adiake for the second day, after which an agreement was found with their commanders.
Some cocoa producers in Ivory Coast began an unlimited strike to protest a slowdown in exports and a reduced buying price. Protests followed in Abidjan and San Pedro the next day.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Dozens of cocoa producers staged a demonstration in Abidjan and in San Pedro to protest a slowdown in exports and a reduced buying price. In Abidjan, police fired teargas to disperse the protest.
Dozens of cocoa producers staged a demonstration in Abidjan and in San Pedro to protest a slowdown in exports and a reduced buying price. In Abidjan, police fired teargas to disperse the protest.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Hundreds of protesters erected barricades at Cocody neighbourhood of Abidjan to protest the national Prosecutor's freezing of agribusiness companies' assets in January. Police fired teargas to disperse the protesters and chased them through the neighbourhood. Several people were injured and two movement leaders arrested.

column7: FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Clashes between students led by the Student and Scholar Federation of Ivory Coast (FESCI) and policemen at Riviera suburb in Abidjan. Hundreds of students were arrested the following day at Riviera and Daloa. Students were protesting the detention of several classmates during recent rounds of protests.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Around ten unknown gunmen robbed a military police office at Bingerville outside Abidjan during the night, leaving two officers injured and stealing weapons and other material.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Clashes between forest police and non-native communities illegally living in and exploiting preserved areas of Tao forest in the west left several people injured.
Hundreds of students protested in Bouake against the murder of a fellow student in an armed robbery the previous day. Secondary and technical schools also closed their doors to follow the movement.

Generalized communal clashes between Malinke and Abbey communities in Azaguie, Agboville department, left at least one person killed and several others injured. The clashes followed a dispute over market space. A curfew was imposed on the town the following day.

Hundreds of protesters, mainly women, prevented access to Bouake's airport to protest expulsion from their homes in one part of the city, despite years of negotiations to become owners of their homes.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Gunmen ambushed a police patrol at Bondoukou, leaving one policeman killed.
Teachers' movement struck to protest against the financial treatment provided by government in both the cities of Abengourou and Agnibilekrou.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Clashes between students led and policemen at the Plateau suburb in Abidjan. Police intervened with teargas once the students blocked the public road. Students were protesting the lack of a date to discuss their internship report and obtain their diploma.
Journalists gathered in front of the television broadcasting centre to denounce political pressure on the freedom of press, notably after the arrest of six journalists some weeks ago.

A youth group threw stones at a cultural centre that the prefect of Ouangolodougou was visiting with a delegation and later looted his home in the area. Gunshots were heard (unclear from whom). The reason seems to be a misunderstanding on some land issues.

column7: FNCI: New Forces of Ivory Coast
column17: Some hundred of former members of 'Forces nouvelles' blocked the southern access to Bouake to ask for their integration to the army and 18 million FCFA per head. These former rebels were left out from the several measures taken, including those taken in January to calm down the mutiny.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Rebel soldiers surrounded Ivory Coast's army headquarters in Abidjan on Friday, firing shots in the air. The shots came just hours after national television broadcast a ceremony in which a soldier presented as a spokesman for 8,400 former rebels, apologised to President Ouattara for the mutiny.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Sporadic gunfire erupted overnight in a military barracks in the country's second city of Bouake. The shots came just hours after national television broadcast a ceremony in which a soldier presented as a spokesman for 8,400 former rebels, apologised to President Ouattara for the mutiny.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: FNCI: New Forces of Ivory Coast
column17: Ten mutinous soldiers with Kalashnikovs opened fire on the former FNCI rebels not integrated in the army who demonstrated on Monday. Their demonstration allegedly hindered the soldiers' chances to get their money. 2 people were wounded in the clash.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Residents of Bouake said the entrances to their cities had been blocked by mutinous soldiers.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Residents of Daloa said the entrances to their cities had been blocked by mutinous soldiers.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Residents of Korhogo said the entrances to their cities had been blocked by mutinous soldiers. One person was wounded. Later on, they went back to their barracks.

column8: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Six people, including a mother of three, were wounded when renegade soldiers in Ivory Coast opened fire at a protest against an army mutiny in Bouake, according to witnesses. Two other protesters, who had been beaten up, were also being treated. One person died on Sunday from bullet wounds.

Al Jazeera's Ahmed Idris, reporting from Abidjan, the economic capital of Ivory Coast, said opposition to the three-day revolt was gathering momentum. ""People were able to organise demonstrations yesterday and today, even in areas held by the rebels,"" he said

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Bingerville was paralysed by renegade soldiers of Akouedo military base, country's biggest. After shots were fired, renegade soldiers blocked the road linking Bingerville and Abidjan.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Heavy gunfire rang out Monday in Abidjan and Bouake, Ivory Coast's two biggest cities, as a four-day mutiny by disgruntled soldiers demanding bonuses spread countrywide. Banks, offices and department stores closed their doors in the heart of the economic capital, Abidjan, as gunfire erupted in San Pedro, the second biggest port in the world's top cocoa-producing nation. The situation was also tense in Man in the west and Bondoukou and Daloa in the centre of the country, where sporadic shooting could be heard.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Heavy gunfire rang out Monday in Abidjan and Bouake, Ivory Coast's two biggest cities, as a four-day mutiny by disgruntled soldiers demanding bonuses spread countrywide. Banks, offices and department stores closed their doors in the heart of the economic capital, Abidjan, as gunfire erupted in San Pedro, the second biggest port in the world's top cocoa-producing nation. The situation was also tense in Man in the west and Bondoukou and Daloa in the centre of the country, where sporadic shooting could be heard.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Agreement: A four-day mutiny by ex-rebel soldiers in Ivory Coast has ended after they accepted a government offer, the mutineers say. The rebellion paralyzed cities and towns across the country. Renegade soldiers in Ivory Coast who have carried out a four-day nationwide mutiny said on Tuesday that they were ending their rebellion after accepting an amended offer from the government on bonus payments. The government had offered an immediate payment of 5 million CFA francs (7,500 Euros) and an extra 2 million to be paid at the end of next month, other spokesmen said.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: In Bouake, as well as into the key northern city of Korhogo, the former fighters blocked the main road south to the Ivorian economic capital, Abidjan, as well as the northern highway to neighbouring Burkina Faso.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: In Bouake, as well as into the key northern city of Korhogo, the former fighters blocked the main road south to the Ivorian economic capital, Abidjan, as well as the northern highway to neighbouring Burkina Faso.

column7: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Four people were killed and many hurt when police clashed with mutinous soldiers barricading the road into Bouake, in the spill over from a corrosive army mutiny over pay. The protesters said security forces opened fire to disperse them, but the government denied responsibility.

column6: Police Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Six people have been killed near the town of Arrah by gendarmes. The security officers were hunting down suspected armed robbers when they opened fire. Five funeral home workers and a passerby died. Four gendarmes and their commander were arrested.
People gathered to protest against soldiers' mutiny.
Opposition demonstrated against government's social policies.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Former soldiers blocked the northern access to Bouake claiming the payment of their primes, in continuity with the mutinery of May, 2017.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Soldiers 15 July fired shots and clashed with fellow soldiers at two military camps, in Abidjan in south and Korhogo in north after military leaders said they would not receive bonuses. Three soldiers were killed in Korhogo, six soldiers arrested in total.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Soldiers 15 July fired shots and clashed with fellow soldiers at two military camps, in Abidjan in south and Korhogo in north after military leaders said they would not receive bonuses. Three soldiers were killed in Korhogo, six soldiers arrested in total.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Mutinous soldiers attacked the police school of Cocody seizing weapons and material. Government forces quickly reacted and clashed with mutinous soldiers in Yopougon neighbourhood getting back the equipment that was stolen. One policeman dead.

column6: Mutiny of Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Police office was attacked and robbed by mutinous soldiers, policemen were locked up: no casualties.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Police station in Fresco was attacked by gunmen in military uniform. They held the policemen, took weapons and vehicles, and later robbed local treasure and banks.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Around 30 masked gunmen ambushed a police patrol in Adzope in La Me, took them to the police station and locked them in cells while they stole armaments. On their way out, they freed prisoners and looted local shops.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: Five prisoners escaped from the Gagnoa prison threatening one of the guard with a gun. Five guards were later arrested for complicity.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: 20 detained escaped from the Abidjan Court after harassing the guards. Seven guards were later arrested.
Youth with machetes allegedly terrorised people and pursued passers-by for unclear reasons. Wounded are reported.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Students went on strike to protest the lack of student housing. There were clashes between police and students leading to several protesters sustaining wounds.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Songon National Guards' station was attacked by armed men: a policeman was wounded, and weapons seized. Suspicions target mutinous soldiers' groups.
People blocked the Northern route linking Ivory Coast to Burkina Faso and Mali to protest against bad route conditions and general insecurity.
People went to the street to protest against bad route conditions and general insecurity.

column7: FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Students protesting high registration fees and police forces clashed. 3 students were wounded.
A situation between two youngsters triggered some clashes between autochthonous and non-native communities. People of both parts were wounded, and some houses were burnt down.

column7: FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Students protesting high registration fees and police forces clashed: students blocking the streets and throwing stones were dispersed by teargas by police forces.
In the last two weeks, two people died and several were wounded when a land conflict sprung up in the Western part of the country.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Weapons Seizure: Armed men attacked a police post in Abobo neighbourhood and seized weapons. No gunshot was heard.
Inter-community clashes for the exploitation of Goin-Debe forest during several weeks: 10 dead, 28 wounded, 2 rape cases and 4 campements burned.
Former rebels demonstrated in front of Man and Bouake prefectures claiming a bonus of 18 millions of FCFA per head.
Former rebels demonstrated in front of Man and Bouake prefectures claiming a bonus of 18 millions of FCFA per head.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: A journalist was beaten by police while covering the eviction of the occupants of the slaughterhouse site in the Abidjan commune of Port-Bouet.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Customs officer went on a 48-hours strike: those gathering at Abidjan port were dispersed by police using teargas.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Thousands of Bethleem schools students set up a march to protest the lack of teaching, as schools were destroyed Thursday by a conflict between the school founder and locals. Students were armed with clubs. They interrupted teaching in several school and blocked northern axis. They were eventually dispersed by police.

Further deterioration of relations between communities in the Cavally region and more particularly in Guiglo: on Thursday, November 2, 2017, in the village of Glopahoudy, the young Sronhon Evariste, president of the young people of Beoua and Gouehi Sede Marius went to the field and fall into a trap laid by strangers.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Tense situation in Massakro between the military and the population. A 25-year-old man was killed by a soldier: the man was transporting cocoa to neighbouring Ghana despite the ban. Questioned by the soldier, disputes ensued when the villagers came out to lynch the element. To defend himself, the latter made two warning shots in an attempt to dissuade them.

Occupiers of a protected area ransacked Ivorian offices of Water and Forests and conservation agencies in Katiola to protest against their expulsion from the Haut Bandama reserve. ""People attacked the offices of Water and Forests"" of SODEFOR (Forest Development Corporation) and OIPR (Ivorian Office of Parks and Reserves).

Clashes of a rare violence between the students of the high school governor Abdoulaye Fadiga (Gaf) and those of the private secondary school, Kone Mamadou (Ckm), made several wounded and the two institutions ransacked

column7: FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Students threw stones at police and dislodged teachers and other students of high schools and colleges of Korhogo with stones and clubs. The protesters denounced in particular the lack of tables and benches in the high school Dominique Ouattara of the city.

Suspected Yacouba killed a Lobi in Mahapieu. The Lobi killed a Yacouba civilian in retaliation, leading to wider clashes between the two groups, leaving several people injured. All the incidents occurred in the space of one day.

Young Ivorians protested at the Lagnonkaha mining company in Guiembe, Korhogo, against the exploitation of a manganese mine by an Indian company, demanding their recruitment within the company. They set up barricades on the main road that leads to the exploitation site.

Students in Touba, Korhogo, Ferkessedougou and Abengourou threw stones on the roof of classrooms and loud darts of firecrackers to call for an earlier end of classrooms before the holidays. Police intervened to disperse them with tear gas or batons. In Korhogo, the students threw stones at professors and students, leaving some of them injured.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Students in Touba, threw stones on the roof of the classrooms and loud darts of firecrackers in Touba to urge the end of classrooms. They attempted to dislodge their comrades at a professional centre but were prevented by the police.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Students in Touba, Korhogo, Ferkessedougou and Abengourou threw stones on the roof of classrooms and loud darts of firecrackers to call for an earlier end of classrooms before the holidays. Police intervened to disperse them with tear gas or batons.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Students in Touba, Korhogo, Ferkessedougou and Abengourou threw stones on the roof of classrooms and loud darts of firecrackers to call for an earlier end of classrooms before the holidays. Police intervened to disperse them with tear gas or batons.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Clashes between police officers and parents of students earlier arrested for violence in Korhogo. The parents reportedly threw stones at the police and invaded the police post. Police responded by firing tear gas.
The head of Morofe, Nanan Tanoh Kouassi Georges and his wife were assaulted by individuals armed with machetes

Five dead in clashes between residents of Falikogo and Karga neighbourhoods in Kanakono, in the sub-prefecture of Tingrela (northern Ivory Coast). Reasons for clash: rumours about the beginning of the work and the choice of the site of the college.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Urban transport experienced a disturbance in the municipality of Treichville as two groups of young trade unionists protested at Bassam Station. Security forces arrested several people as they intervened to avoid a clash.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: One soldier was killed and another was wounded in the shootings between soldiers at the Bouake Artillery Battalion's base on the night between Thursday and Friday. ""During the ensuing quarrel, gunfire were fired by the protagonists, causing the death of Sergeant Dembele Yacouba and wounding another soldier"" said a statement from the Ministry of Defense.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: An exchange of fire killed two people in the night from Thursday to Friday at a checkpoint in Bangolo. Unidentified gunmen broke into the checkpoint usually held by soldiers. In the absence of the security forces, the attackers opened fire on two young villagers who are used to assist security guards in the surveillance missions.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Gunshots were heard again Saturday in an area of Bouake (north), the epicentre of Ivorian soldiers' mutinies in 2017, following an exchange of fire between defence and security forces that resulted in the death of a soldier.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: A soldier from the Armed Forces of Cote d'Ivoire (Faci) was killed during an intervention.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: An attack was perpetrated on the night of Tuesday 9 at the Coordination Centre of Operational Decisions (CCDO) by some mutinous soldiers in Bouake. A light casualty, a burned down vehicle and the CCDO annex looted were the result.

column6: Police Forces of Ivory Coast (2011-) Customs Office
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On 27 Jan. 2018, customs officers and police agents clashed over the arrest of a custom agent. Shooting was reported in Yamoussoukro city (District Autonome De Yamoussoukro, Yamoussoukro). No fatality and/or casualty reported.
The access points of the village of Zuenoula were blocked by the transport labour unions.
Demonstrators accused the mayor of having sold the central market: they ransacked the Soubre mayor's office building and his residence before setting fire to them.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: A gendarme and a civilian were killed during violent protests that led to the looting of the gendarmerie. A gendarme attempting to racket a young trader is considered to be the initial spark of the situation.
Following the aggression of a policeman by a youngster, the crowd lynched him, wounding him severely.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: Mbahiakro's post was set on fire by student rioters after the murder of one of them. Several wounded were reported.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column9: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie
column17: On 12 March, some unidentified men on a motorcycle opened fire on soldiers at the Beoue-Zibiao checkpoint. One of the assailants died, and one civilian was wounded.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On 13 March, after a disagreement with police, a group of residents set fire to the Beoue-Zibiao checkpoint. They were dispersed by the security forces.

column7: EDS: Together for Democracy and Sovereignty
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On 22 March, opposition supporters attempting to gather for a planned march announced by the EDS platform were dispersed by police forces throwing teargas. The demonstration planned to be held 48 hours ahead of the 24 March senatorial elections.

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On 6 April, unknown armed men attacked a military post at Baou, Bangolo-Kouibly axis. Soldiers' reprisal killed one assailant.

column7: CEECI: Committee of Pupils and Students for the Ivory Coast
column9: CEECI: Committee of Pupils and Students for the Ivory Coast
column17: On 9 April, student CEECI members clashed at the Alassane Ouattara campus in Bouake over the division of CROU funds. Several were wounded.
On 21 April, Malinke and Baoule communities clashed in Diegonefla: the conflict was triggered by a wedding ceremony. 10 wounded and several houses burned down.
On 7 May, clashes between Kondrobo and Konankro villages (Tiebissou department) erupted around a land issue. Several people were wounded.

column7: CNEC: National Coordination of Higher Education Teachers and Researchers; Teachers (Ivory Coast); Students (Ivory Coast)
column17: On 4 June, students and teachers blocked access to the University Felix Houphouet-Boigny, protesting the bad economic conditions.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On 6 June, police fired tear gas at stone-throwing students in Abidjan after they blocked a key bridge to protest living conditions.
On 24 June, clashes took place between candidates' supporters in Abidjan: several people were wounded.
On 7 July, a RACI event in Korhogo was interrupted by some youngsters who attacked the participants killing one and wounding several.

column7: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) University Police
column17: On 13 August, university police demonstrated in the court of Bouake's prefecture, Gbeke, against bad working conditions.

On August 27, an armed group armed with Kalashnikovs and dressed in military fatigues looted a school and sequestered the guardian of the establishment, hitting him with rifle butts, tying him up and gagging him with pieces of torn curtains.
On August 28, youth from Katiola set the village of Atienkaha on fire, Humbol, protesting the disappearance of a young driver.
On August 30, a group of women from several neighbourhoods in the city of Katiola, Hambol, marched to protest the disappearance of a young driver.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On September 7, Adjame residents demonstrated against the local government decision of evicting them to extend the construction works for the fourth bridge. According to the demonstrators, police forces dispersed them with tear gas causing wounded.
On September 11, women held a protest to demand garbage collection in Blolequin.

column7: FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) University Police
column17: On September 11, Ivorian university police clashed with stone-throwing students protesting education fees outside the economic capital Abidjan's Houphouet-Boigny University. Police used tear-gas but there are no information about injuries.
On September 20th, two youth groups clashed in the village of Odienne, killing one person and injuring two others.
On Sept 26 Adiake Municipal High School students demonstrated across the city contesting the extra fees they have to pay after registration.

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column7: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Gendarmerie; Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Between Sept 28 and 30, army and police forces organized joint exercises in Abengourou, Agnibilekrou and Bettie of Indenie-Djuablin region to show cohesion ahead of the joint municipal and regional elections of October 13th.

On Oct 2, workers from the Rubber Company of Grand-Bereby (SOGB), who have been on strike for more than two weeks to demand an increase in wages, demonstrated in front of the entrance of the offices of the company in San Pedro.

column6: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column17: In the night between Oct 13 and 14, a man was stabbed to death in clashes between supporters of the ruling RHDP coalition and supporters of Samy Merhy, the independent mayor of Lakota town in Lakota.

column7: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column17: In the night between Oct 13 and 14, supporters of the ruling RHDP coalition and supporters of Samy Merhy, the independent mayor of Lakota town clashed in Divo. Two injured.
On Oct 13, electoral voting boxes were smashed up and set on fire in Bonoua, east of the commercial capital Abidjan.

On October 13, after the release of the provisional results of the national elections, the buildings of the Independent Electoral Commission (CEI) in Sangouine (26 km from Man), were ransacked. Nobody was injured.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: In the night of Oct 15, clashes between police and rioters left some people injured in Grand-Bassam, near Ivory Coast's main city Abidjan. Riot police used teargas to disperse the crowd of demonstrators asking for the release of results for the elections in the country.

column9: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On October 16, the vehicle of the father of PDCI candidate Vremen Serge Yvon, was destroyed by rioters in Tanda. Nobody was injured and the police intervened soon after to stop these acts of vandalism.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On October 16, clashes between police forces and rioters in Agboville paralyzed the city after the release of the electoral results.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On October 17, Lakota residents protested against the elections results that gave candidate Kouyate Abdoulaye winner of the municipal elections. Police dispersed the protesters with tear gas and made some arrests.

column7: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On October 17, clashes between supporters of the elected mayor, Fany Karim and Ginette Ross, PDCI candidate after electoral results in the city of Issia. Looting and massive destruction were reported.
On October 19, a teacher was killed by an unknown armed group in Bonon.
On Oct 22, students marched in the city of Madinani to protest teacher shortages in their school.
On Oct 22, the teaching staff serving in the three public secondary schools in the city of Seguela has launched a march in the streets of the city to protest the insecurity.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Oct 24, teachers and students stormed Tengrela police station after a dispute between a teacher and the police in which a woman was assaulted.
On Nov 2, an unknown gunman opened fire on participants at a funeral vigil in Gloplou village in Bangolo Department, resulting in four wounded by bullets.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On November 8, in Korhogo, human rights activist Carton Noir was arrested by police forces while he was allegedly filming policemen extorting money from drivers. He was taken to an unknown destination, his where about remain unknown.

On Nov 10, people with disabilities organized a demonstration in front of the premises of the Gagnoa community rehabilitation centre for the handicapped (RACH) to demand the resignation of the board of directors of the structure.

On Nov 21, students clashed in the streets with drivers in Zouan-hounien, in western Cote d'Ivoire, after the death of a 12-year-old, at the Zouan-Hounien Municipal High School who was reportedly beaten by a driver.
On 23 Nov 2018, unidentified armed assailants ambushed three cars and about a dozen motorcycles on the road between Bettie, Yakasse and Attobrou. The passengers were stripped of their possessions.

On or around 26 Nov 2018, several young people attacked each other with machetes over the control of a smoking room in Kpimbly neighbourhood, Yopougon, Abidjan. The clash resulted in the death of one of the youth involved.

On 26 Nov 2018, a group of youth aggressors involving drivers and apprentice drivers also known as ""gnambro"" armed with knives and machetes ransacked a high school in Duekoue. The attack was allegedly a retaliation for a teachers' strike the week before, during which students damaged vehicles. One student was allegedly killed and about a dozen others wounded, including four with bullet wounds.
On 27 Nov 2018, a man was stabbed to death by unidentified assailants in Angre, Abidjan. The attack was allegedly carried out as a settlement for a previous conflict.
On 27 November, a student went missing in Dabakala. He was found dead a week later, on 7 December.
On 28 Nov 2018, trainee teachers staged a sit-in in front of Odienne's treasury offices, protesting against the non-payment of their scholarships during the entire year.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-) Prison Guards
column17: During the night from 28 to 29 Nov 2018, a row erupted between students of Bouake campus 2 and prison guards in Bouake. The prison guards used their Kalashnikovs and machetes, which resulted in eight people wounded, including five with bullet wounds and three stabbed.

On 10 Dec 2018, students from Dabakala high school demonstrated against the killing of one of their peers in Dabakala. The demonstrators threw stones and blocked the main road. The student, who had been missing since 27 Nov, was found dead on 7 Dec.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On 10 Dec 2018, ex-combatants from Cell 39 who claim 18 million CFA from the Ivorian government gathered near the northern corridor of Bouake and started to barricade the roads. Police dispersed them with teargas.

column7: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column9: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On Dec 16, in Mondoukou, PDCI militants clashed with RHDP militants in the village polling station, reportedly a primary school.

column9: Journalists (Ivory Coast); Government of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Dec 16, unidentified armed men destroyed urns and shot in the air in Bassam1 during municipal elections. They also assaulted RTI journalists covering the elections and destroyed a camera. Another source mentions attacks in 15 polling stations in total in Grand-Bassam
On Dec 16, unidentified men (assumed unarmed) destroyed urns in 15 polling stations in total in Grand-Bassam

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column9: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On Dec 16, unknown gunmen clashed with Police forces and PDCI militants after attempting to attack candidate Emmou Sylvestre headquarters in Port-Bouet for the second time, the same day. 5 of them were arrested.

column9: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On Dec 16, in the morning, a group of unidentified men beat and molested a PDCI militant in Port-Bouet while he was on his way to a polling station.

column7: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column9: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On Dec 16, around 30 unidentified men threw stones at PDCI candidate Emmou Sylvestre headquarters in Port-Bouet, breaking a window. They also reportedly stole mobile phones and injured several.

column7: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column9: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: Around Dec 17, young RHDP militants damaged the cars and took the mobile phones of PDCI supervisors in Grand-Bassam. They were accused of organizing fraud.

column7: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On Dec 17, in the afternoon, in Grand-Bassam, France neighbourhood, around 200 people protested to demand continuation of votes in polling stations where urns were destroyed by unidentified men.

column7: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Dec 17, early in the morning, police dispersed a group of RHDP supporters who had gathered in front of the mosque to prevent the handover of power following the PDCI candidate's victory.

column7: Former Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Dec 18, in Abidjan, newly retired soldiers protested close the Ministry of Defense to demand end of career indemnities, barricading the street. They were dispersed reportedly peacefully by Police Forces.

column7: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On Dec 19, hundreds of Grand Bassam inhabitants, among whom PDCI militants, wearing white tee-shirts marched to demand to the losing candidate Philippe Ezaley to accept the Sunday elections results.

column7: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column9: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column17: On Dec 21, in Grand Bassam, in France neighbourhood, a group of PDCI militants marched towards the Prefecture to protest against electoral irregularities, following the destruction of polling stations during the elections in the city. A group of crudely armed RHDP militants built barricades to prevent access to the Prefecture and clashed with PDCI militants. Several people were reportedly injured.

On Dec 25, in Grand Bassam, more than 6,500 people marched to claim their voting right, following the destruction of polling stations during municipal elections on Dec 16. Unknown crudely armed men interrupted the march and reportedly threw stones at the protesters, injuring 7 and leading to destructions of goods.
On Dec 29, a group of Tokro inhabitants attacked Allokokro civilians, injuring 15 and putting fire to 10 houses following land dispute.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Jan 1, Grand Bassam Prefect Amakou Kassi Gabin banned public protests related to elections in Grand Bassam, reportedly until Jan 31, following clashes between RHDP militants and PDCI militants.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Jan 4, in Korhogo, taxi owners clashed with Police Forces, denouncing Police corruption and Police block roads.
On Jan 5, in Nouvelle Boulangerie neighbourhood in Abobo, Microbes, a street gang composed of young people clashed with a vigilante group of inhabitants during two hours.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Jan 5, a group of taxi owners barricaded several streets in Danane town, and physically assaulted Police Forces, denouncing police roadblocks and corruption. They reportedly burned down three security checkpoints in Danane-Zouan Hounien, Danane Guinee, and Danane-Man.

column7: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Jan 7, a group of young people from Abobo Doume and Locodjro neighbourhoods, Attecoube, blocked the main road with barricades, demanding that Jacques Ehouo, PDCI-RDA winning candidate in Plateau in October, officially take up his post as Mayor. They also reportedly blocked boat traffic between Abobo Doume and Plateau. Police Forces used tear gas, and arrested several. Several people were injured.

On Jan 14, in Sarala village, a group of naked women and young people reportedly blocked the road and threw sticks and stones at Bougousso Sous-Prefet Kouame Ben Serge's car, following land disputes between Sarala and Benko villages.

column7: CVCI: Group of Victims of Cote dIvoire
column17: On Jan 14, in Abidjan, militants from the Group of Victims of Cote d'Ivoire, wearing white tee-shirts, protested against the ICC's decision to release ex President Laurent Gbagbo and ex Minister Charles Ble Goude.

column7: CVCI: Group of Victims of Cote dIvoire
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column9: Former Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2000-2011)
column17: On Jan 15, in Abidjan, hundreds of militants from the Group of Victims of Cote d'Ivoire, wearing white tee-shirt, protested against the International Criminal Court's decision to release ex President Laurent Gbagbo and ex Minister Charles Ble Goude. Police Forces interfered to disperse protesters.

column7: CVCI: Group of Victims of Cote dIvoire; Women (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column16: Agence de Presse Africaine; AIP (Ivory Coast)
column17: On Jan 15, in Abobo, militants, mostly women, from the Group of Victims of Cote d'Ivoire, marched to protest against the International Criminal Court's decision to release Laurent Gbagbo. They blocked roads building barricades at Abobo-Banco roundabout. They were reportedly dispersed by Police Forces.
On Jan 15, in Anyama village, North of Abidjan, a number of people protested against the release of Laurent Gbagbo, former Ivory Coast President, by the International Criminal Court.

column7: CVCI: Group of Victims of Cote dIvoire
column17: On Jan 16, in the morning, in Abobo, at Abobo-Banco roundabout, militants from the Group of Victims of Cote d'Ivoire protested against the International Criminal Court's decision to release Laurent Gbagbo.
On Jan 17, in Korhogo, a group of young people protested against the International Criminal Court's decision to release ex President Laurent Gbagbo and ex Minister Charles Ble Goude.

On Jan 17, in the morning, a group of young people in Bouake protested against International Criminal Court's decision to release ex President Laurent Gbagbo and ex Minister Charles Ble Goude. They reportedly put fire to tires.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Jan 22, in Ekressinville area, close to Bonoua, Police Forces asked inhabitants to leave the area, following a land dispute. Some expelled inhabitants reportedly staged a protest and barricaded the highroad to Grand Bassam with their luggage.

column7: SYLACIL: Free Syndicate of Logistic Agents of Ivory Coast
column17: On Jan 30, Sylacil militants protested in Abidjan, in front of Marcory zone 4, demanding payment of indemnities and salaries.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column9: PDCI: Democratic Party of Ivory Coast
column17: On Jan 31, PDCI deputies protested in front of Abidjan Tribunal, after Police Forces prevented them to assist to Alain Lobognon's trial. Deputy Alain Lobognon was sentenced to one year of prison for publishing a tweet where he accused Ivory Coast justice of attempting to arrest PDCI Deputy Jacques Gabriel Ehouo.

column7: CVCI: Group of Victims of Cote dIvoire
column17: On Feb 3, militants of the Group of Victims of Cote d'Ivoire staged a protest at Banco roundabout, in Abobo, against the International Criminal Court's decision to release former President Laurent Gbagbo.
Between July 2-3, at night, in Kanoukro village, a group of young people assaulted and beat the village chief, accusing him of being responsible for the detention of several inhabitants.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 11, in the morning, public school students (Nangui Abrogoua high school, Williamsville high school, and Harris high school) attempted to interrupt courses in Djedji Amondji Pierre high school, throwing stones, bottles and sticks at the students, injuring 3 of them and forcing them to leave their classrooms. They were protesting against the interruption of public school following professors' strike since three weeks. Police Forces interfered, using tear gas to disperse the rioters.

On Feb 11, in Soubre, students from several high schools protested against the interruption of public school following an ongoing professors' strike. They interrupted courses in Charles Bauza Donwahi private high school, Modern 1 private high school, Modern 2 private high school and Bernard Zadi Zaourou private high school, forcing the students to leave their classrooms.

On Feb 11, a group of students, protesting against the interruption of public school following a professors' strike, attempted to interrupt courses and force students of Nangui Abrogoua high school to leave their classrooms, in Abidjan.

On Feb 11, Alepe Modern high school students protested against the interruption of public school following an ongoing professors' strike. They threw stones at students from other schools, forcing them to leave their classrooms.

On Feb 11, in Bouake, taxi bikers protested against new road regulations, setting up barricades in front of the train station. Train station workers clashed with them. Several vehicles were damaged. Police Forces interfered to disperse the protesters. Several were reportedly injured.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 11, in Botro, a group of high school students protesting against the interruption of public school following professors' strike tried to interrupt courses in the Mayor's private school and to force students to leave their classrooms. Police forces clashed with the students and allegedly beat one of them and arrested 11.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 11, in Botro, following the arrests of several students the same day, and following a rumour alleging that police officers killed two students, an angry mob attacked Botro's police station, using machetes and axes. Policemen from Bouake came as backups and dispersed the mob. Three policemen were injured and police equipments were damaged.

column7: CVCI: Group of Victims of Cote dIvoire
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 11, in Abidjan, CVCI militants staged a protest in front of the Solidarity Ministry Cabinet, demanding indemnisations from the State. They were planning to go on a hunger strike for three days but Police Forces interfered to disperse them.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 11, in Guiglo, a group of students protested against professors' strike, which has been interrupting public school for three weeks. Students set up barricades and destroyed several statues. Police Forces interfered, using tear gas. One student was injured.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 12, in Bonon, a group of students protested against professors' strike, which has been interrupting public school for three weeks. Students set up barricades on the main road. Police Forces clashed with the protesters, and used tear gas. Students reportedly threw stones at them. One police officer was injured.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 13, Police Forces raided Abattoir neighbourhood in Port Bouet. During this operation, they reportedly beat a young man to death.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 13, in Port Bouet, a group of people threw stones at Police Forces and clashed with them. They were protesting against the killing of a young man earlier the same day by Police Forces during a raid. The source mentions ""many"" left injured.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 17, a group of people from Campement Gri neighbourhood, in Bingerville, set up barricades on the main roads, seeking to get revenge from the murder, the day before, of a young man by his girlfriend following a dispute. They were dispersed by Police Forces. The number of rioters is unknown.

column7: CNEC: National Coordination of Higher Education Teachers and Researchers; Teachers (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On Feb 18, CNEC militants entered Cocody University and prevented students from finishing an exam session. Police Forces intervened to make them leave. Tensions between Police Forces and militants were reported. 2 leaders of the CNEC were arrested. The number of protesters is unknown.

column7: CNEC: National Coordination of Higher Education Teachers and Researchers; Teachers (Ivory Coast)
column16: Afrique sur 7; Koaci News; Soir Info
column17: On Feb 21, in Cocody, in Felix Houphouet Boigny University's campus, hundreds of CNEC militants and professors marched to protest against recent government's decisions regarding researchers and professors. They also demanded the release of two CNEC leaders arrested on Feb 18.

column7: CNEC: National Coordination of Higher Education Teachers and Researchers; Teachers; PFN: National Platform of Professional Organisations of Ivory Coast's Public Sector; Labour Group (Ivory Coast)
column17: On Feb 22, in Bouafle, at the Prefecture, civil servants from the National Platform of Professional Organisations of Ivory Coast's Public Sector set up a protest to demand the release of two CNEC leaders arrested on Feb 18. Number of protesters unknown.

On Feb 25, in Bouake, Ahougnanssou neighbourhood, a group of unidentified men, crudely armed, assaulted striking teachers. Several of them were injured. The assaulters also put fire to motorbikes. [size=no report]
On Feb 26, some students marched in Marcory to protest against the national education strike, which has led to an interruption of classes. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast
column16: Ivoire Soir; Agence de Presse Africaine; Soir Info
column17: On Feb 26, around 3,000 FESCI students marched in Cocody to demand the restart of classes, following an ongoing national strike in the public sector which has led to an interruption of school. Protesters allegedly damaged several SOTRA buses and beat up a SOTRA worker (FESCI's leader denied this allegation). [size=3000]

On March 3, in Cocody, Cocody Mayor and a group of inhabitants, dressed in white, silently marched to denounce the Feb 26 violent acts in public transports which killed one person and injured several. [size=no report]

On March 3, in the afternoon, in Doubasso, several Dozo, armed with sabres and rifles, angry after one of their spots was burned down allegedly by a group of young people from Doubasso, clashed with a group of young people in a bar and killed one.

On March 4, in Marcory, a group of students and people armed with machetes prevented some Isfop and Loko students from accessing their schools. Some were reportedly beaten and their phones stolen. [size=no report]

On March 4, in Bouake, in the morning students blocked the international road linking Bouake to Abidjan, protesting against the ongoing strike in the education sector, that has led to an interruption of most public schools. [size=no report]

column9: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On March 4, in Koumassi, a group of high school students, helped with other young people from the area, forced Bad middle school students and Modern Highschool students to leave their classes, throwing rocks at them. Rioters protested against the national strike in the public education sector which has led to an interruption of most public schools. Police Forces interfered to disperse them. [size=no report]

column16: Ivoire Soir; Ivoire Times; Koaci News
column17: On March 11, in the morning, in Bekuefin village, a group of students blocked the road to Abengourou using tree trunks. They were demonstrating against the interruption of school, which has been ongoing for several weeks, following a national strike in the education sector. Rioters also reportedly broke car windows. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On March 12, in Cocody, in front of the RTI building, a group of students protested against the interruption of classes following the national professors' strike that has been going on for a month. Police used tear gas to disperse protesters, leaving several injured, and arrested FESCI's leader, Stephen Jemoh. [size=no report]
On March 15, in Abobo, Abobo Plaque 1 neighbourhood, in the evening, Microbes, a street gang composed of young people, attacked and killed one man, and severely injured a woman.

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column17: On March 18, in Aboisso, a group of students protested against the ongoing professor's strike which has led to an interruption of public school. They blew whistles to force Modern Highschool students to leave their classrooms [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On March 19, in Fresco, a group of students demonstrating against the interruption of school due to an ongoing strike in the public education sector threw stones at Police Forces. Police used tear gas to disperse them. One policeman, one employee and two students were injured. The headmaster's house was damaged by rioters. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On March 19, in Abengourou, a group of students marched against the interruption of school, following the professor's strike in the public education sector. They threw rocks and clashed with Police Forces. Police fired tear gas to disperse them [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

column17: On March 19, in Cocody, a group of students demonstrating against the ongoing professors' strike in the public education sector in the Classique and Moderne high schools threw rocks at Police Forces. Police Forces used tear gas to disperse the rioters. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast; Students (Ivory Coast)
column17: On March 19, in Aboisso, a group of students demonstrated for the second day against the ongoing professor's strike which has led to an interruption of public school. They blew whistles to force primary and secondary schools students to leave their classrooms [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast
column9: Students (Ivory Coast); FESCI: Student Federation of Ivory Coast

On March 21, in Belleville, Microbes Youth Militia members clashed with members of FM Youth Militia, using machetes. One was killed and several injured. Police later that day arrested 39 people suspected to have links with the Microbes.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On March 22, in Niakaramandougou, a group of nuts merchants protested against the government's decision to set up lower selling prices for their products. Police Forces intervened to disperse the protesters. [size=no report]
On March 29, in Cocody University campus, during a meeting, politician Zasso Patrick was beaten by a group of people, among whom alleged students. [size=no report].

column9: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-); Students (Ivory Coast)
column17: On April 1, in Cocody, close to Lycee Classique, 4 students armed with knives attempted to attack other students during a sport exam. 17 of them were injured. Police later intervened and arrested them.

On April 1, in Bin Houye, following the death of a young Yacouba by a Malinke after a car accident, a group of Yacouba seeking revenge clashed with members of the Malinke group and looted houses and shops. A number of people were injured. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); Dioula Ethnic Group (Ivory Coast)
column9: Students (Ivory Coast); Dida Ethnic Group (Ivory Coast)
column17: On April 6, in Zikisso village, Dioula students and Dida students threw stones at each other following a dispute between several Dioula young men with a Dida girl. Police intervened and attempted to disperse the rioters. Several people were injured, among them two policemen. Several shops were also reportedly destroyed and looted. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On April 7, in Vridi village, policemen beat several Rastafaris with batons. Report mentions that some Rasta got their hair cut by the police. Number of injured unknown.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On April 9, inhabitants in Felix Houphouet-Boigny, among which Youth Solidarity with Kagoussi activists, marched to protest against Plastica's backfilling project in the laguna. Police interfered but no clashes were reported. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On April 10, students from Adjame village attempted to force students to leave their classrooms in College Moderne area, Cocody. Police intervened to disperse them. [size=no report]

column16: Conseil National des Droits de l'Homme; Koaci News
column17: On April 11, a high school Abbey student was severely beaten by unidentified young men in front of Agboville Modern high school.

column17: Between 11-13 April, clashes between Abbey men and Malinke men were reported in Ndouci, following a dispute over the control of smokehouses. (coded as 3 events) [size=no report]

column17: On April 12, following the beating of an Abbey high school student the day before, clashes between Abbeys and Malinkes were reported in Agboville and left ""many"" injured. The source also mentions destruction of goods and shops. [size=no report]

column17: Between 11-13 April, clashes between Abbey men and Malinke men were reported in Ndouci, following a dispute over the control of smokehouses. (coded as 3 events) [size=no report]

During the night of April 16-17, in Sessenouan, close to Bouake, a group of young people from Sessenouan village raided the village chief's house, contesting his authority following land disputes (unclear). [size=no report]

column9: Government of the Ivory Coast (2011-); Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-); Women (Ivory Coast)
column17: On April 24, in Anyama administrative office, around 300 landlords from Ebimpe and Akoupe-Zeudji villages demonstrated following land issues. The sub-Prefect's secretary was assaulted by several rioters while she was preventing them to enter the sub-Prefect office. Police later intervened to disperse rioters.

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On April 24, in Cocovico Market, Angre neighbourhood, in Cocody, Police Forces used tear gas to disperse local sellers during a demolition exercise.

On May 2, inhabitants from Bohizra village, located 10km away from Zuenoula, staged a protest in Zuenoula Prefecture in support of Bohizra chief Robert Dje Bi Dje and against the nomination of a new chief in their village. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 8, on the Felix Houphouet Boigny bridge, in Abidjan, one man, allegedly a policeman member of the Republican Guard, assaulted a driver, drove him to a police building and beat him up. Report mentions that the driver's whereabouts are unknown.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 8, following the beating of a taxi driver by Narcotic Control policemen close to Hire train station, in Konankro neighbourhood, a group of taxi drivers damaged a police vehicle and entered the Narcotic Control Police Office, reportedly destroying goods. A number of them demonstrated against police violence, blocking traffic in Divo. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 8, in Divo, Narcotic Control policemen assaulted a taxi driver, close to Hire train station, in Konankro neighbourhood. The taxi driver was reportedly left unconscious.

On May 14, in Koumassi, small clashes were reported between a group of crudely armed syndicate activists and another group of syndicate activists. The first group was allegedly seeking revenge following their dismissal by their syndicate's secretary (unclear). Police interfered and arrested ""many"". [size=no report]

On May 14, in Abidjan, a group of artists, wearing white clothes, entered the Artists' Syndicate's building (Burida), demanding the departure of Burida's Secretary Irene Viera, denouncing her mismanagement of the Syndicate. [size=no report]

On May 14, Imam Moriba Traore and a group of his followers attempted to take control of Danane's main Mosque. Small clashes were reported with followers of the Mosque's Imam Sanogo Moriba. Police Forces interfered to close the Mosque. [size=no report]

column7: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

column17: On May 14, in Plateau neighbourhood, in Abidjan, a group of RHDP/RDR activists gathered in front of the Ministry of Interior to demand the arrest of Plateau Mayor Ehouo Jacques, accused of financial corruption. Police used tear gas to disperse protesters. 9 were reportedly arrested. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 14, in Sipilou, following the killing of a taxi driver by a policeman earlier the same day, an angry mob destroyed Sipilou's police station. [size=no report]

column6: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 14, in Sipilou, close to the Guinean border, a taxi driver was reportedly killed by a policeman. He reportedly refused to pay twice a fine regarding the state of his vehicle. While he was driving away, the policeman shot at his vehicle.

column16: Agence de Presse Africaine; AIP (Ivory Coast); Soir Info
column17: On May 15, in Beoumi, following a dispute between a Baoule moto taxi driver and a Dioula moto taxi driver close to Massa train station, the Dioula driver severely injured the other driver with a machete. Seeking revenge, Baoule men clashed with Dioulas, some using firearms. Police forces attempted to interfere using tear gas. Clashes killed 14 and injured 108, among which students and policemen. 300 people fleeing clashes took refuge in the town's hospital. Many shops, cars and houses were also reportedly destroyed.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 15, Imam Moriba Traore and a group of his followers renewed their attempt to take control of Danane's main Mosque. Small clashes were reported with policemen. Police Forces closed the Mosque. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 16, following clashes in Beoumi the day before between Baoules and Dioulas, on the road between Beoumi and Bouake, carriers burned tires and a truck. Minister Sidi Toure and his delegation, as well as journalists, were blocked by barricades and assaulted by armed men in several villages (notably in Assouafe village, close to Beoumi, and in Golikro, and in Assekro) on their way to Beoumi. Security Forces interfered to help the delegation. (coded as 3 events - Assouafe's location not accessible, coded as Beoumi geo precision 2)

column16: Koaci News; Soir Info; Radio PDCI RDA; Alerte Info
column17: On May 16, unidentified rioters burned houses in N'Zueda village, located 500m away from Beoumi, following clashes the day before in Beoumi between Baoules and Dioulas. A curfew was announced by the government in Beoumi.

On May 17, tensions remain high in Beoumi following clashes on May 15 between Dioulas and Baoules which killed 14 and injured 108. A car attempting to cross the city was attacked by inhabitants in the commercial area of the city. The vehicle was reportedly set on fire. A group of people reportedly established checkpoints.

On May 17, a group of inhabitants, among which naked women, blocked Zinzenou roads, demonstrating against the arrival of gold miners in their village. A number of them put fire to 30 gold miners' vehicles. [size=no report]

column16: Conseil National des Droits de l'Homme; Koaci News
column17: On May 18, in Abengourou, a land dispute between two Muslim groups led to clashes. Many reported severely injured. [size=no report]
On May 18, for the second day, inhabitants in Zinzenou demonstrated against gold miners' activities in their village and blocked road. Rioters also assaulted and injured a goldminer. [size=no report]

On May 18, following the sudden death of a student for unclear reasons, 30 students attending his funerals, along with the student's relatives, destroyed chairs in the church, and assaulted several people, demanding transparency regarding their classmate's death.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 19, in Kokoumbo, following the death of a Malinke during a police raid, a group of Malinkes seeking revenge burned down the police station. [size=no report]

column9: Baoule Ethnic Group (Ivory Coast); Malinke Ethnic Group (Ivory Coast)
column17: On May 19, in Kokoumbo, during a police raid in a bar, a young Baoule was shot dead by policemen (circumstances of his death unclear). A Malinke was also arrested.

On May 18, following the sudden death of a student for unclear reasons, 30 students attending his funerals, along with the student's relatives, destroyed chairs in the church, and assaulted several people, demanding transparency regarding their classmate's death. Small clashes and tensions were reported on May 19 as well.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column16: Agence de Presse Africaine; Fratmat; Koaci News
column17: On May 20, a group of people demonstrated in Attecoube neighbourhood, Abidjan, against insecurity. Police forces attempted to disperse the crowd, but rioters threw rocks at them. Policemen used tear gas. Clashes lasted several hours. At least 3 people were injured. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 20, in Kokoumbo, following the shooting of a Malinke during a police raid in a bar the day before, a group of Malinke rioted for the second day and attacked and damaged the sub prefecture, the town hall and several shops belonging to Baoules, generating tensions between Malinkes and Baoules. [size=no report]

column7: Students (Ivory Coast); Teachers (Ivory Coast); Health Workers (Ivory Coast)
column17: On May 20, in Daloa, following, the day before, the killing of an English teacher by thieves on the road between Daloa and Bediala, teachers, health workers and students marched in the streets to denounce a growing state of insecurity. [size=no report]
On May 22, a group of students protested in Boga Doudou high school, in Lakota, to demand their grades following the professors' strike in the education sector. [size=no report]

Between May 22-23, at night, in Marcory, Alliodan neighbourhood, a young Christian man sleeping in an evangelical church was beheaded by unidentified men. His headless body was discovered on May 23, in the morning.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On May 24, in Bonon, following a land dispute between Bognouzra inhabitants and Gobazra inhabitants, a number of people from Gobazra gathered on the disputed territory. Tensions were reported between the two communities. Police Forces interfered to peacefully disperse protesters. [size=no report]

On May 26 (or May 25), in Bouna, followers of politician Bitate Hien clashed with politician Binsare Hien's followers during the appointment of Binsare Hien as the new Lobi chief. Bitate Hien's activists interrupted the ceremony and forced the Committee's President to flee. Rioters reportedly put fire to his car. [size=no report]

column16: Afrique sur 7; Koaci News; Soir Info
column17: On May 27, in Agboville, following a dispute between a young Abbey and a young Dioula, a number of young people entered Agboville schools (Nakoi Institute, Ate Yavo school), allegedly asked students which ethnicity they belong to, before attacking them, armed with machetes and knives. At least 5 students were injured, with several windows broken and doors smashed. Clashes between students were also reported in Eden school. Another source affirms that clashes were drugs-related. (unclear)
On May 28, in Zou, young people staged a protest against the non respect of a contract signed by the Wooden Compagny Thanry. [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)

Police Forces interfered to prevent the victim's relatives to put fire to the killer's parents' house. [size=no report]

column6: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: Beginning of June - end of May, in Abidjan, security forces of Ivory Coast, with the help of French security forces, arrested ten Katiba Macina militants from Mali and Burkina Faso. Several plans of attacks, notably targeting Novotel Abidjan Hostel and Galieni military headquarters were thwarted. (date unknown, coded as June 1st, time precision 3)

On June 5, in the evening, in Bohizra village, following rivalries between local leaders, Bohizra chief Robert Dje Bi Dje was shot by an unidentified armed man while he was heading to Zuenoula on his motorcycle. (location of Bohizra unknown, coded as Zuenoula geo precision 2)

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column16: AIP (Ivory Coast); Alerte Info; Afrique sur 7
column17: On June 6, in Zuenoula, hundreds of inhabitants from Bohizra village, located 10km away from Zuenoula, destroyed Zuenoula Prefecture, accusing the Prefet of planning the murder. Rioters also burned 20 houses in Bohizra, notably the house belonging to his political opponent Tra Bi Youan. They were reportedly armed with machetes and firearms. Police forces reportedly clashed with rioters. [size=hundreds]

On June 7, teachers and administrative workers wearing red clothes gathered in front of the Prefecture in Niakara in support of a teacher who was insulted by a woman a few days before (unclear). [size=no report]

column16: Koaci News; Soir Info; Alerte Info
column17: On June 10, in Koumassi, members of two transport syndicates clashed over the control of Koumassi's main stations. A 16 years old was killed and several injured. Koumassi Mayor later decided to close the stations. [size=no report]

column7: RHDP: Rally of Houphouetistes for Democracy and Peace
column17: On June 12, in Cocody, around 100 young RHDP supporters from Iffou region gathered in front of PDCI President Bedie's house, protesting against Bedie's last allegedly xenophobic speech on June 5, asking him to apologize. A red liquid, similar to blood, was poured on the ground by protesters. [size=100]

During the night between June 13-14, fights were reported between groups of secondary school students crudely armed, coming from neighbouring villages, notably Cotongouine, Nelagouine and Kassiapleu. Several were injured. Police later arrested a number of students. (locations of Cotongouine and Nelagouine villages unknown, coded as Kassiapleu geo precision 2) [size=no report]

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On June 15, in Yopougon, Gesco neighbourhood, two armed men attacked a police station. They were shot and killed by policemen. Two policemen were also injured during clashes. The attackers were allegedly former members of BE BOYZ music group.
On June 17, in Cocody, at the University of Felix Houphouet Boigny, students wearing white clothes marched to demand the reopening of academic registration. [size=no report]

column8: Military Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On June 20, in Tehini, unidentified armed men shot dead two soldiers riding a motorcycle.

column8: Police Forces of the Ivory Coast (2011-)
column17: On June 23, in Grand-Bereby, Kroumen men blocked roads with barricades to demonstrate against an attack the previous day by a Guinean man following a dispute. Police intervened to disperse the demonstration. [size=no report]

column17: On July 12, in Grand-Bereby, a Baoule accusing a Kroumen of stealing his stock of rubber, shot and killed him.
